note_models.name: Art learn

fields: Joseph Wright of Derby, A Philosopher Giving a Lecture on the Orrery, in which a Lamp is Put in Place of the Sun, 176466

British Enlightenment

  1. Joseph Wright of Derby trained as a portrait painter in London but returned to Derby. He is the first major English painter to build a career outside the capital.
  2. This large-scale genre painting shows figures around an orrery, an early mechanical model of the solar system used for demonstrating the movement of the planets around the Sun.  
  3. The orrery creates a play of shadows on the sitters and walls. The effects of light fascinated Wright, he was known for his use of chiaroscuro, which emphasizes the contrast of light and dark. The light source comes from the inside, which takes the role of the sun, directing your view to the center and the active enlightenment the figures are participating in.
  4. This painting captured the interest in astronomy and natural philosophy that was widespread in England during the Age of Enlightenment in the 18th century, a philosophical shift away from traditional religious models of the universe and a belief that empirical observation grounded in science and reason would best advance society.
  5. The large scale signifies how Wright is heroizing the search for knowledge and pushing the boundaries of genre painting. His paintings of the birth of science, often based on the meetings of the Lunar Society of Birmingham, a group of scientists and industrialists, are a significant record of the struggle of science against religious values then.
The individuals have not been identified, but their faces have been likened to the phases of the moon.
Angelica Kauffman, Portrait of Johann Joachim Winckelmann, 1764

Swiss Neoclassicism

1.    While 18th century Neoclassicism was centred in Rome, its proponents were spread across Europe, including Swiss Neoclassical artist, Angelica Kauffman. 
2.    The daughter of a painter, Kauffman spent much of her youth in Italy, where her father urged her to study Classical sculpture and the works of Renaissance masters. While in Rome in her early twenties, she befriended the German scholar, Johann Joachim Winckelmann and painted his portrait. 
3.    The portrait shows the notable archaeologist and art historian reading from a book, resting on a bas-relief showing the Three Graces. Winckelmann was a pioneering Hellenist who first articulated the difference between Greek, Greco-Roman and Roman art. He was one of the first scholars to apply the categories of style on a large, systemic basis to the history of art, and was thus considered by many as the father of the discipline of art history.
4.    Kauffman, the queen of neoclassical art, received considerable critical acclamation for her portraits, and earned large sums of money from her sale of pictures, commissions, and the reproduction of her compositions in a variety of media. She was described by the German writer Goethe as the foremost woman painter of the century. 
5.    Kauffman was renowned for her fashionable oil paintings for international clientele in a range of mythological, religious and literary subjects. Her paintings were successful in pleasing a varied audience from aristocratic patrons to intellectuals as Winckelmann and Goethe. 
6. Her paintings, while depicting Classical subject matter, are not as formally innovative as those of Mengs or Vien.
JosephMarie Vien, Seller of Cupids, 1763

Neoclassicism

  1. Reimagining of Roman fresco of the Cupid Sellers that intended to update the ancient original for the taste of 18th century Paris. The fresco had been reproduced as an engraving in a book devoted to the excavations of Pompeii and Herculaneum, which had generated a great deal of excitement. 
  2. In the image, a poor woman attempts to sell a Cupid to a wealthy woman that would give her the power to attract love. 
  3. Vien updated the imagery adding furnishings that resemble a Neoclassical salon; figures adopt contemporary poses and gestures; classical cage is replaced with 18th century basket. 
  4. Composition is shallow and dominated by verticals and horizontals, giving it a static, austere feeling
  5. Engravings of the work were widely distributed inspiring imitations in other media such as cupid seller themed fabrics, marble reliefs and other household goods establishing the motif as a part of the publics visual vocabulary. 
  6. While invoking neoclassicism stylistically, the work was criticized for its immoral content, particularly the central cupids obscene gesture, most notably by Diderot who described it as no different from the frivolity of rococo painting.
  7. Vien was Bouchers student
Hyacinthe Rigaud, Portrait of Louis XIV, 1701

French Baroque

  1. By the early 18th century, Louis XIV (1638-1715) of France was the most powerful ruler in Europe. Known as the Sun King, he was an absolute monarch who consolidated and retained power over his vast kingdom despite challenges from French nobles and other rulers. Louis XIV is shown here in his coronation robes, although he was 63 years old at the time that the portrait was painted. The blue-and-gold fleur-de-lys pattern on the textiles and the ermine fur over Louis shoulders are symbols of the French monarchy, which held that it was the divine right of kings to rule. The royal sword hanging from his left hip, the royal scepter in his hand, and the crown resting behind the scepter underscore his power. At 92 x 63, the painting is massive, its imposing scale making the petite monarch tower over viewers. 
  2. The voluminous periwig, cravat, and red shoes worn by Louis in the portrait were signatures of Baroque style, over which Louis exerted substantial influence: strict codes dictated what people could wear at court, based on their standing. 
  3. The portrait was commissioned for Louis grandson, King Philip V of Spain. It was was such a success that Louis kept the original and sent him a copy instead. The original became Louis official portrait and hung over Louis throne. In his absence, courtiers were forbidden from turning their backs on it, as they would have been forbidden from turning their backs on the king. 
  4. Louis XIV was a great supporter of the arts, and used them to gather political capital. The palace at Versailles was his grandest and most expensive undertaking. By moving the French court in 1682 from Paris to Versailles, a former hunting lodge located 12 miles from the city, Louis was able to isolate nobles from the economic hub of Paris. By the time this portrait was painted, Louis had commissioned massive expansions at Versailles from various architects, as well as many new works of theatre, music, dance, painting, and sculpture which premiered at court. 
  5. This portrait of Louis XIV - influenced by Anthony Van Dycks Charles I Dismounted (1635) - cemented Rigauds reputation within Europe as a painter of state portraits. His style was emulated in France until the French Revolution (1789). The painting was so popular that Rigaud, with the help of assistants, made many copies at varying scales, at full as well as half length. 
  6. The painting was shown at the Salon in 1704, and remained in the royal collection until the Revolution (1793), after which it entered the collection of the Muse Central des Arts de la Rpublique, later known as the Muse du Louvre.
Francois Boucher, Gracious Shepherd, 17369

Rococo

1. This is an encased painting which is part of the interior design of the the Htel de Soubise, a htel particulier, or a grand private residency for aristocrats in the center of Paris, typical of the architectural shift after Louis XIVs death: the aristocracy moved back to Paris from the golden cage of Versailles, to the comparatively modestly scaled apartments which were intimate, light and playful rather than grandiloquent.
2. The htels architect Boffrand redecorated it in the 1730s to include new oval salons for the prince and princess apartments as transitions from the grand staterooms to convey a feeling of privacy and intimacy. His architectural designs were instrumental for disseminating the French style across Europe.
3. The htel was decorated with encased paintings and carved wood paneling with organic, winding forms, unfurling leaves (Rococo comes from rocaille = rockeries of contemporary gardens).
4. The painting represents first phase in courtship through gift of a caged bird prefiguring the capture by love. It shows aristocratic subjects in an idyllic pastoral scene portraying escapist fantasies and nostalgia for country life.
5. Boucher was one of the most famous decorative painters during the reign of Louis XV and a fine arts entrepreneur: he made decorative embellishments, designs for Svres porcelain, Gobelin tapestries. He depended on wealthy patrons and earned a good fortune through his commissions.
6. Boucher was working in the footsteps of Watteau who revitalized the waning Baroque style and shifted it to the less formally classical, more naturalistic Rococo.
JeanBaptiste Chardin, Saying Grace c. 1740

Enlightenment

  1. Reinterpretation of the Dutch theme of prayer before meals. 
  2. Moralizing subject emphasizes a contented life of duty, humbleness and virtuosity in opposition to the extravagance of Rococo. Establishes the ideal of the intimate family structure through the petite bourgeois family of Paris.
  3. Subdued color scheme and lighting emphasizes the humbleness of this scene. It is an exaltation of simple family life. 
  4. Stability of the composition lends tranquility to the scene triangular structure of the figures; the circularity of the table repeated throughout the scene in the plates, the drum, the pot in bottom right and the pot hanging on the wall. Some scholars have described this as a circle of tenderness that lends an emotional intimacy to the scene.
  5. Painting was purchased by Louis XV and remained in royal collection until French Rev. when it entered what would become the Louvre. 
  6. This is one of many versions of the work, and it was reproduced widely as a print which Chardin captioned to create a compelling narrative to the scene which added to popularity and marketability of the print. In this way, Chardin was producing directly for the art market rather than for wealthy commissioners (despite the fact that Louis XV bought this version).

William Hogarth, The Death of the Countess
From the series Marriage--la-Mode, c.1743

British satire painting, Rococo

1.   This painting is one from a series, Marriage a la Mode, by English artist William Hogarth, painted between 1743 and 1745, created as a satirical commentary on the upper-class. Hogarth was a painter, printmaker, pictorial satirist and editorial cartoonist, best known for his series of paintings of modern moral subjects. 
2.   The series focuses on the misery of an arranged marriage between the daughter of an upper-class merchant family and the son of a destitute noble family attempting to maintain their societal status. As the couple pursue their private pleasures, the earl contracts a venereal disease and the wife gets caught with her lover. The marriage ends with his death and her suicide. 
3.   This painting is the final scene in the narrative, in which the unfaithful wife poisons herself in grief (the empty vial lies on the floor) and poverty-stricken widowhood, shown here as collapsed in a chair. While the doctor feels her pulse, an old nurse brings over her child for a farewell kiss, but the mark on the childs cheek and the caliper on her leg suggest that the disease has been passed on to the next generation. The countesss father, whose miserly lifestyle is evident from the bare house removes the wedding ring from her finger. 
4.   Marital ethics were the subjects of several debates in the 18th century; this series represents Hogarths belief in the dangers of arranged marriages as he depicts the unflattering and tragic events that result from it. 
5.   Although this series of paintings are works of art in their own right, their original purpose was to be translated to engraved copper plate prints. By the nature of the process, the image engraved on the plate is reversed by viewing it in a mirror. Hogarth, being a master engraver himself, produced this painting already reversed so the engraver could directly copy them.
Dominikus and Johann Baptist Zimmerman, Wieskirche (Wies Church), 174554

Bavarian Rococo

  1. Designed by Dominikus Zimmerman, an architect and stuccoist, together with his brother, Johann Baptist Zimmermann, an architect and frescoist.
  2. Beautifully preserved in the Bavarian countryside, this pilgrimage church is a masterpiece of Bavarian Rococo exuberant, colorful and joyful.
  3. It is an exceptional testimony of the religious tradition of pilgrimage. The hamlet of Wies, in 1738, is said to have been the setting of a miracle in which tears were seen falling down a wooden figure of Christ. A wooden chapel housed the statue for some time.  However, pilgrims from Germany, Austria, Bohemia, and Italy became so numerous that the Abbot of Steingaden decided to construct this splendid sanctuary.
  4. Rococo aesthetic provides sensory pleasure. The church is oval-shaped, unique in its harmony between art and the countryside. The architecture, sculpture, painting, stucco work, carving, and ironwork, were melded into a unified whole to create a diaphanous spatial structure of light and form.
  5. The interior's dominant colors (white, pink and gold) give a sense of lightness and airiness despite the unprecedented richness and refinement of its ornamentation. Rococo decoration was used to create a sense of flow with the use of abstract and asymmetrical detail with wave like lines; this exuberant interior was meant to unleash the divine, and evoke sensual delight to bring the soul closer to God.
  6. Religion remained undisputed mainstay in society at this time, as the Enlightenment was limited to a small group of philosophers.

Sources:
https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/271/video

Strawberry Hill
Remodeled for Horace Walpole by Richard Bentley, John Chute, Robert Adam, James Essex, Thomas Pitt, and others, 175376

Gothic Revival 

An early example of Gothic Revival architecture, called Strawberry Hill Gothic. Notice the arched windows and crenellations (the gaps in medieval castles used for defensive architecture), cloisters, turrets, and battlements, he filled the interior with pictures and curios, and amassed a valuable library. 

Another option besides Classical revival, medieval-focused revival that incorporated the heritage of the English world, the gothic and medieval past that also suggested sublimity and confusion (in contrast to beauty and order of Classicism). The interior incorporates the dark, opulent, eerie gloomth that Horace Walpole wanted. 

Inside was designed to be truly gothic, filled with many paintings from his collection, other antiques and antiquarian objects. Made for Horace Walpole, who wanted to live in the past and wrote the first Gothic novel - dark, stormy, supernatural in direct contrast to the rationalism of the Enlightenment. 

Strawberry Hill was an elaborate architectural fantasy, designed as an evocative gothicizing space for an eclectic writer (Walpole, who also had a printing press on the grounds, was a prolific letter writer to Horace Mann, and studied art history, in addition to his literary writing like the Castle of Otranto). 

Strawberry Hill was the stimulus for the Gothic Revival style in English domestic architecture.

Walpole took a leading role in the design, choosing the monuments he wanted copied. He also published about the architectural and garden design in an effort to promote this Gothic picturesque style in Britain.

Maurice-Quentin de la Tour 
Portrait of Madame de Pompadour, Salon of 1755

French Enlightenment / Rococo (?)

  1. Mme de Pompadour was the official mistress of King Louis XV of France 1745-50, after which she remained his adviser and friend. She exerted considerable political influence, unusual for a woman at the time. 
  2. Mme de Pompadour commissioned this unusually large pastel portrait from Maurice-Quentin de La Tour, the most famous pastelist of the period. He and Madame de Pompadour met while he was creating a pastel portrait of the king, exhibited at the 1748 Salon. De La Tour was apparently reticent to create this portrait, perhaps as a result of her shifting demands, delivered to the artist over the course of his lengthy correspondence with her brother Marquis de Marigny, who acted as her interlocutor with de La Tour. 
  3. Mme de Pompadour is painted in a collectors cabinet, and the objects surrounding her in the portrait point to her status as a supporter of artists and intellectuals. These include Guarini's Pastor Fido, the Encyclopdie (banned in france in 1752), Montesquieu's De l'esprit des lois (Spirit of the Laws, banned by the Catholic Church), Voltaire's La Henriade, a globe, and Le Trait des pierres graves (Treatise on Engraved Stones) by Pierre-Jean Mariette. The marquise hoped to lead Louis XV to consider the recent developments in philosophy, science, and the arts, which had not yet penetrated the court. The king almost certainly saw the portrait at the Salon in 1755, but it is unknown if/how he responded to its allusions to contemporary intellectual life. 
  4. Mme de Pompadour was a musician (indicated by the sheet music in her right hand) and also enjoyed creating engravings. De La Tour included an inscription on an engraving on the table reading Pompadour sculpsit, although the plate was actually engraved by the Comte de Caylus, and was from the aforementioned Trait des pierres graves (Treatise on Engraved Stones) by Pierre-Jean Mariette.
  5. Mme de Pompadour is depicted in sumptuous clothing, indicating her status and her devotion to fashion. She is shown without jewellery, other ornament, or complicated hairstyle, indicating the intimate nature of the portrait and also perhaps its subjects focus on internal riches. (Compare this to Franois Bouchers painting of Mme de Pompadour from 1756--one year later--which is a Rococo confection of pink ribbons that shows the marquise applying blush at her vanity.)

Sources:
https://www.louvre.fr/en/oeuvre-notices/full-length-portrait-marquise-de-pompadour
http://musee.louvre.fr/oal/marquise_pompadour/marquise_pompadour_acc_en.html
Etienne-Maurice Falconet, Seated Cupid, 1757

Rococo decorative statue

1. Venus and cupids, as well as shepherds and shepherdesses, were favored subjects of Rococo decorative statues
2. It was commissioned for the residence of Louis XVs mistress Madame de Pompadour (which today is the French Presidential Palace): Marquise de Pompadour was one of the most influential hostesses of the 18th century, the leading mistress of Louis XV, known for her good taste (patron of literature), worldliness and sophistication, held salons for high society including leading Enlightenment intellectuals like Voltaire or Diderot
3. The exhibition of the cupid at the Salon of 1757 was Falconets moment of success; he later became the head of the Svres Manufactory
4. This cupid is different from earlier versions by Boucharon and Saly because it is younger and has an air of deception, makes the viewer complicit in Cupids attack on an invisible victim
5. Cupid incarnates the attraction and deception of love, his lifted finger implies both discretion and secrecy; depicts the ambiguity of love: between conspiracy and threat
6. Known by various nicknames in the 18th century, like menacing love
JacquesGermain Soufflot, Panthon (formerly Church of Ste. Genevieve) 175790, Paris

Neoclassicism

  1. Soufflots Ste-Genevive was built to replace a decrepit medieval abbey, that was to house the remains of Ste. Genevieve, patron saint of Paris, an idea first proposed during the time of King Louis XIV. 
  2. The project fit with Louis XVs program to aggressively promote his role as avatar of the nations greatness. The king saw the churchs rebuilding as a token of his munificence and as material confirmation of the French Catholic Churchs quasi-independence from the Roman Catholic Church. 
  3. It was hailed as a masterpiece of Neoclassical architecture with centralized plan, dome based on St. Peters in Rome, and Classically inspired interior and exterior such as the tall Corinthian columns. 
  4. The Churchs design was meant to unite the purity and magnificence of Greek architecture with the lightness and daring of Gothic construction. The classical forms were joined with a Gothic type of structure that included the use of concealed flying buttresses and relatively light stone vaulting.
  5. Architectural historians have interpreted this approach to historical models as stemming from the Enlightenments view of history, which saw the past as an unfolding, linear progression of events that could be studied in a rigorous, almost scientific way to extract lessons or models useful to the present generation. 
  6. The building has been rededicated between church and secular temple throughout the 19th Century. It was conclusively secularized in 1885 under the name Panthon as a dedication to the memory of great Frenchmen who are interred there. As a result of back and forth, the sculptural pediments have been recarved four times from religious scenes to the allegorical representations of Fatherland, History and Liberty by Pierre-Jean David dAngers which stands there today. 
  7. After the Revolution Quatrmere (sculptor and revolutionary) transformed the church Ste Genevive into a temple of the nation, a mausoleum for the nations greatest men: blocked up windows, replaced religious sculptures with reliefs of revolutionary themes (i.e. triumph of faith by triumph of the motherland)
  8. Jacques Louis David orchestrated funeral processions to bury or re-bury great men of the nation: i.e. the transfer of ashes of Voltaire by a horse-drawn carriage inspired by Classical processions; nothing of these revolutionary festivals remains other than the design of the chariot (ephemeral happenings)
  9. It contains a copy of the Foucault Pendulum, which demonstrated the rotation of the Earth in 1851.

Giovanni Battista Piranesi, Aqua Marcia Aqueduct
Illustration in Della magnificenza e darchitettura de Romani (pl. xxvi), 1761

1.   Piranesi, an Italian printmaker, archaeologist and art dealer, advocated for the artistic importance of Roman art and culture, in counter to the Greek revivalism promoted by the German scholar, Johann Joachim Winckelmann, who thought Roman art was merely derivative of Greek art, Piranesi instead tracing their artistic origins back to the Etruscans. 
2.   He published the Della magnificenza e darchitettura de Romani (On the Grandeur and the Architecture of the Romans) to support his argument that the Romans had created the greatest architectural monuments of Classical antiquity, superior to those of the Greeks in size, form and engineering. 
3.   This work combined his essay on the superiority of Roman architecture with his series of 38 etched illustrations. While rooted in careful archaeological studies, Piranesis etchings were intended to flaunt the grandeur of Roman architecture. Piranesi's reproductions of real and recreated Roman ruins were a strong influence on Neoclassicism.
4.   His illustration of the Aqua Marcia Aqueduct emphasizes the enormous size of the ruined structure, both by exaggerating the perspective view and by juxtaposing the monument with tiny human figures, clearly dwarfed by the dimensions of the architecture. 
5.   The debate about the relative importance of Greek and Roman art was restricted to the discipline of archaeology, and does not seem to have had an impact on artists. Most artists followed in Piranesis footsteps, believing that they should not be bound to the a single artistic model, such as the Greek style, but should explore all forms of Classical art.
Svres Manufactory, A pair of potpourri vases with lids, 1761

Rococo porcelain vases

  1. Porcelain vases, candlesticks, and figurines were essential to French 18th century decor for the more intimate Rococo style that emerged under Louis XV.
  2. This pair of potpourri vases were made to contain fragrant flowers and spices.
  3. Svres was the preeminent porcelain factory in Europe by the middle of the eighteenth century. The factorys success was largely due to the financial support provided by Louis XV and the patronage of Madame de Pompadour, his mistress. It focused on manufacturing luxury porcelain for the royal family, court, and aristocracy.
  4. The vases demonstrate the highest achievements in porcelain production. The openwork panels, which comprise two thirds of the design, illustrate the extraordinary skill of the Svres workers. To cut the openings in the raw clay and fire the vase successfully without having them warp or collapse reflects technical mastery. Equally impressive is the three-dimensional modeling of the flowers on the lids.
  5. The rich ground color, lavish gilding, inward and outward curves, and superb painted decoration underscore its decorative function.
  6. The front of each vase depicts a fanciful scene of Chinese life, reflecting the love of Chinoiseries, exotic fantasies about Chinese life informed by the scarce knowledge Europeans had about China.  The sides depict a bouquet, matching with the flowers atop the vase.
Anton Raphael Mengs, Apotheosis of Hercules, 17629 and 1775

Early Neoclassical
  1. Mengs was an 18th century painter stradling the Rococo and Neoclassical periods. He was active in Dresden, Rome and Madrid, who while painting in the Rococo period of the mid-18th century became one of the precursors to Neoclassical painting.
  2. Spain's power had greatly diminished by the 18th century. Carlos III, an enlightened monarch, curbed the power of the church and aristocracy, promoted education, economic development, science, and the arts. Mengs was invited to decorate Carlos III's newly built palace, Palacio Real, in Madrid.
  3. In great contrast to fresco executed by Tiepolo for the same palace because it lacks the illusionist quality of Tiepolo's rococo fresco. Instead of creating a dramatic build-up to the center of the ceiling, there is action concentrated on the edges, where figures are arranged in frieze-like manner. 
  4. The Apotheosis of Hercules, along with other scenes of figures elevated into the heavens, was a commonly depicted subject in Baroque art, used for decorative cycles and in particular for ceiling paintings. Hercules, the traditional protector of Spain, was a symbol of valour and physical force.
  5. The neoclassical style is also present through the central view up to heaven in contrast to the illusionistic Rococo fresco style. 
  6. Through this artwork and his portraits of the royal family, Mengs became First Court Painter and reformed the Spanish Royal Academy of Fine Arts in accordance with the Classical precepts he learned in Rome and from his acquaintance with Winckelmann.
JeanBaptiste Greuze, Filial Piety (The Paralytic), 1763

French Enlightenment / Academic 

  1. The work is from series by Greuze on family morals, and shows an elderly paralyzed man who instilled good morals in his son, and is consequently surrounded by generations of his loving family. 
  2. Enlightenment thinkers condemned Rococo art for being immoral, and called for an art that would teach morality. This morally-didactic art would operate as an extension of philosophy and science: with the application of scientific thought and reason (as opposed to superstition and mythology), Enlightenment thinkers believed, society would improve. In France, Jean Jacques Rousseau, Denis Diderot, and others also questioned the divine right of kings to rule. 
  3. Purchased by Catherine II of Russia (Catherine the Great) on the recommendation of Denis Diderot. Diderot wrote, "to make virtue attractive, vice odious, ridicule forceful; that is the aim of every honest man who takes up the pen, the brush or the chisel" (Essai sur la peinture). Diderot called the painting The Benefits of a Good Education. 
  4. Exhibited in the Salon of 1763: by this time, Salons were visited not only by the aristocracy, but also by the upper-middle-class. The painting addressed (in accordance with Enlightenment ideals) morality for a broader public, rather than simply for the elite. 
Studied drawing at the Acadmie under rococo master Charles Joseph Natoire (1700-1777), but was among the artists to usher in a more realistic (naturalistic?) mode of depiction (as opposed to the fanciful, often physics-defying aesthetics of Rococo). Made many drawings and studies of expressive poses and gestures.
Thomas Gainsborough, Portrait of Mary, Countess Howe, c.1763

English Rococo

1. Rococo flourished mainly in central and southern Europe but failed to really take root in the North (where it was confined to easel painting depicting aristocratic family members)
2. This is one example of a many family portraits of members of the British nobility: it shows a countess taking an evening stroll
3. Gainsborough met the Howes in the fashionable retreat city Bath and offered to paint their portrait as an opportunity to establish himself as one of the leading painters of the British aristocracy
4. It is carefully engineered to illustrate her station in life: pale complexion, costly silks, laces and pearls unfitting for a walk in nature, depiction of the land in the background which was the source of her wealth and social status (freely sketched like in the Rococo of the European mainland), despite this careful orchestration the portrait retains a sense of spontaneity
5. Gainsborough made his fortune as a portrait painter, depending on the commissions of wealthy patrons (kings, nobles, religious institutions) for a living; he did not produce directly for the market as artists like Chardin did
Benjamin West, Agrippina Landing at Brundisium with the Ashes of Germanicus, 1768

Neoclassical

  1. West was a British North American history painter around the time of the Seven Years' War for this painting specifically, an American colonial (born in Pennsylvania) who moved to London in 1763 and became court painter to George III.
  2. This tragic picture presents a moral lesson in stoic heroism, notably in the restraint and dignity of those mourning. The crowds of mourners suggest Rococo style because of its dramatic light, colorful dress, and diagonal line. The mourners contrast with Agrippina, heightening difference between virtuous widow and ordinary followers.
  3. Based on a passage from Annals by Roman historian Tacitus: young wife Agrippina brings back her husband's remains to Italy. Agrippina, a distinguished and prominent Roman woman of the first century, is depicted as a model of virtue: she honors her husband and heroically travels to Syria to retrieve her husband's ashes so that they can be buried on Roman ground. Moral quality of Neoclassical painting. 
  4. Composition centred on the procession with the white dress symbolic of mourning and these figures are on shallow plane. Their heads and feet are on two horizontal lines, resembling a Classical marble bas-relief.
  5. He did not confine his borrowing to ancient sources. We can identify several other quotations in the painting. The boy who has climbed the column of the temple on the left is reminiscent of the boy who has climbed a tree to watch the entry of Christ into Jerusalem in the paintings of Giotto and Duccio. The standing man seen from the rear in the left foreground is based on a figure in Raphael's Disputa in the Vatican. The figure seated near him with her hand to her head takes on a position traditionally associated with sorrow. The best-known example is the engraving of Melancolia by Drer, but as Professor Erwin Panofsky has said about Drer's print, the motif can be traced back to ancient Egypt. In Poussin's Death of Germanicus, Agrippina grieves in similar fashion. 
  6. Still the Age of Enlightenment, so the classical ideas are important as well as the forms. To the Roman people, Germanicus, a Roman General, was the Roman equivalent of Alexander the Great due to the nature of his death at a young age, his virtuous character, his dashing physique, and his military renown. Germanicus was cremated in Antioch and she transported his ashes to Rome where they were interred at the Mausoleum of Augustus. Agrippina was vocal in claiming her husband was murdered to promote Tiberius' son Drusus Julius Caesar ("Drusus the Younger") as heir.
Thomas Jefferson, Monticello, Charlottesville, VA, 17691809

American Neoclassicism
  1. Designed by Thomas Jefferson (United States  third president, signer of Declaration of Independence in 1776), who was not trained formally as an architect. Studied at William + Mary beginning 1760, purchased James Leonis The Architecture of A. Palladio (1715-1720) and James Gibbs Rules for Drawing the Several Parts of Architecture (1732). Palladio and Gibbs architecture--rather than vernacular American architecture--inspired designs for Monticello. 
  2. Jefferson spent time as Minister to France 1784-89; architecture shows influence of European classical and neoclassical architecture like Maison Carre (16 B.C.E.), a Roman temple in Nmes, and the Pantheon. Solidarity with French Republic (founded 1792). 
  3. Neoclassical architecture like Monticello: recall the Roman Republic, help to establish a legacy for fledgling country. 
  4. Thought could express ideals through architecture: inspire democracy, education, rationality, civic responsibility. 
  5. Plantation: Jefferson enslaved 400 people at Monticello, made to work in a combination of domestic labor, agriculture, and trades including blacksmithing, textiles (to clothe the slaves), and woodworking. Jefferson also employed some 100 free workers. White masons and their apprentices did the brickwork and woodwork on the building. 
  6. Building was made primarily from materials made at Monticello (bricks, nails, mortar) and timber and stones from Jeffersons land. (Window sashes and window glass were from Philadelphia and Europe respectively)

Jean-Honor Fragonard, The Secret Meeting 
From the series The Progress of Love, 17713

Late Rococo decorative painting

1. Fragonard was the younger colleague of Boucher, painted similar mythological and aristocratic scenes
2. Commissioned by Comtesse du Barry, the last of Louis XVs mistresses, one of four canvases depicting the four ages of love for her neoclassic pleasure pavilion designed by Ledoux: the Progress of Love series shows a flirtatious proposal (offering a rose), a furtive meeting (this example), the consummation of marriage (crowning lover with roses), a happy union (reading of love letters)
3. Represents the playful lives and loves of the aristocratic youth, depicts a contemporary scene although in a highly contrived and fantastic setting
4. Builds on the tradition of Watteaus ftes galantes: pictures of leisure set outdoors, painting of and for the aristocracy
5. Comtesse du Barry returned the canvases: maybe because there was a too embarrassing likeness between the red-coated man and Louis XV, or because their exuberance appeared old-fashioned amid the cool neoclassicism of the pavilion
6. Later, Fragonard added 7 more canvases and installed the series in a villa in Southern France, it then passed through collection of J.P. Morgan and finally became part of the Frick
7. After the death of Louis XV, she was exiled by Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette and became one of the victims of the Reign of Terror during the French Revolution, targeted by the Jacobins as a symbol of the hated old regime
Claude Nicolas Ledoux, Royal Saltworks at Arc-et-Senans, Doubs, France, 1773-79

French Enlightenment
  1. Construction began in 1775 during reign of Louis XVI as the first major achievement of industrial architecture
  2. The Royal Saltworks functioned as an integrated plant where most of the working community would also live. Built in the shape of an arc, it housed living quarters and production facilities, 11 buildings in all: the director's house, stables, salt and office buildings, cooperage, building guards, blacksmithing.
  3. Ledouxs plan reflected the spatial philosophy of the Enlightenment: The semicircular complex was designed to support a rational and hierarchical organizations of work.
  4. It was meant to be the center of an ideal circular city designed by Ledoux that followed these standards but the city was never realized. The unfinished Utopian architecture of the Saltworks still carries the full impact of its futuristic message.
  5. The Royal Saltworks of Arc-et-Senans bears witness to the extraction of salt, then an essential commodity used to preserve food, and a fundamental cultural change in Europe at the end of the 18th century: the birth of industrial society.
The support of salt works by a state monopoly probably explains why this building is so grand. The gabelle (salt tax) was very unpopular and was one of the complaints that led to the French Revolution. The Revolution itself probably curtailed the building of the ideal city.
Robert Adam, Etruscan Dressing Room, C. 177576

Neoclassical

1.   In the late 1700s, numerous manufacturers of houseware and home furnishings began moving away from Rococo designs towards the simpler Neoclassical decorations. England, being the first nation in Europe to industrialize played a leading role in this development, and middle-class Englishmen were able to emulate the Neoclassical designs that were in vogue among the wealthy. The break from Rococo represented not only a change in taste, but also a break away from the decadent culture that had produced it, representing a social return to order, harmony and simplicity.
2.   Robert Adam, the second son of a successful and wealthy Scottish architect, traveled to Italy to study its Classical monuments and skillfully cultivated wealthy British clients, becoming a leading architect for interior architecture and remodeling upon his return to Britain. So busy was his practice that he formed a partnership with his two brothers to carry out commissions across the country. 
3.   The Etruscan Dressing Room in Osterly Park House near London was remodeled by Adam between 1765 and 1780. His designs show his complex adaptation of Classical sources that came to be known as the Adam-style. The rooms are characterized by elaborate but restrained plasterwork, rich and highly varied colour schemes, and a degree of coordination between dcor and furnishings that were unusual in English Neoclassical interiors. 
4.   The room was inspired by the Etruscan vases in Sir William Hamiltons collection, illustrations of which had recently been published at the time. It also draws inspiration from Classical Greek vases, Greek and Roman architecture, Pompeian wall paintings and Renaissance decorative arts. 
5.    In spite of the numerous influences, the dominant impression is one of order and geometry. Most decorations are painted or molded in low relief stucco so that the walls and ceilings look flat. The room lacks mirrors that open up the interior space, so that the overall effective is decorative but reserved.
Francisco Goya, The Parasol, 1777

Rococo
  1. This is an early work by Goya, who moved to Madrid in 1774 at the invitation of German painter Anton Raphael Mengs, to work for the Royal Tapestry Manufactory, producing huge cartoons (sketches), preliminary paintings that were then converted into tapestries that would hang on the walls of the royal residences. Goya worked with the factory for two decades, producing 63 cartoons while establishing his position as court painter.
  2. The Parasol tapestry hung in the dining room in El Pardo, the royal hunting palace outside Madrid. It is from a series of works rooted stylistically in Rococo, that explored countryside subjects and themes like hunting, dreams, the four seasons, music and dance, and the open air. They stand out for their happy, placid scenes and bright colors.
  3. The scene depicts a pair out for a fanciful nature walk, the woman sitting is a maja, holding a folding fan with a little dog on her lap. The young man is holding a parasol to shade the woman's face from the Iberian sunshine. 
  4. Goya's cartoons reflected the diversity of the common people in a series of scenes packed with merriment, amusements, children and festivities, but also with violence and sadness, scenes in which desire and seduction serve as the backdrop for life.
Angelica Kauffman, Zeuxis Selecting Models for his Painting of Helen of Troy C. 1778

Neoclassical
  1. Kauffman was captivated by the ideas of Johann Joachim Winckelmann, whom she befriended while in Rome.  Kauffmann (1741-1807) was the first woman painter to challenge the masculine monopoly over history painting exercised by the Academicians. After visiting Italy, Kauffmann began to acquire a Neoclassical manner, basing her style on Herculaneum and the romantic classicism of the German painter Raphael Mengs. Remembered primarily as a history painter, Kauffmann was a skilled portraitist, landscape and decoration painter.
  2. Zeuxis Selecting Models for His Painting of Helen of Troy, is based on a Roman copy of a Greek Venus Kallipygos in the Museo Nazionale in Naples. It suggests both an early awareness of the most popular antique themes among English painters and a keen attentiveness to prevailing societal construction of women and femininity.
  3. The painting tells the story of Zeuxis, who attempts to portray the world's most beautiful women. Kauffmann shows Zeuxis in the act of anatomical study, inspecting one of the models. The woman behind Zeuxis, has a paintbrush in her hand, facing toward the blank canvas. She is analogous to Kauffmann, as she takes the position of the artist, rather than a passive model and is attempting to actively create art. This woman is often seen as Kauffmann's commentary on her own identity.
  4. This myth is a model of artistic creation - legendary stories of Zeuxis + Pygmalion reveal the infrastructure of the creative act and define it in clearly gendered terms - reaffirm the status of the man as artist/subject and the woman as model/object. The active model claims the canvas and in doing so seems to enact what Kauffman herself performs. The analogy is given substance by the inclusion on the fictive canvas of a signature: Angelica Kauffman pinx
  5. Little public interest in UK in historical matter except for decorative purposes. Compositions to be reproduced by copyists for wall and ceiling decoration, decorate furniture and china, or made into prints.
  6. This scene is central to the theory and practice of idealism; subject is essential Neoclassical art theory, but the execution is Rococo decorative style (chiaroscuro exaggerated, sfumato outlines). Neoclassical but w/ Kauffmann's original touch. Decorative History Painting that rejected the overstated frigidity of the purest forms of neoclassicsim and added sensuous lines soft contour.
lisabeth Vige-LeBrun, Portrait of Marie Antoinette, 177879

French Rococo 
  1. Queen Marie Antoinette of France commissioned this oil-on-canvas painting after her mother, Empress Maria Theresa of Austria, wrote to her in 1777 and requested a portrait. (Vige-LeBruns first of many commissions from the queen. Artist was 22 years old, as noted in her inscription on the painting.)
  2. Bust of Marie Antoinettes husband, Louis XVI, is shown atop a pedestal at the upper right of the painting, behind a table on which a crown sits on a blue and gold pillow (the colors of the French monarchy). For context: c. 10 years before the storming of the Bastille (July 14, 1789)
  3. Queens skirt held up by paniers (whalebone frame) - Marie Antoinette set court fashions at the time. 
  4. Vige-LeBrun (1755-1842) was trained by her father, portraitist Louis Vige. Helped support family with her painting practice after his death. Married Jean-Baptiste-Pierre LeBrun in 1776, who was a painter and art dealer. Joined the Royal Academy (1783) in part due to Marie Antoinettes influence (usually forbidden to artists married to art dealers). 
  5. of Vige-LeBruns portraits were of women (made over 600 paintings); known as a painter of sympathetic portraits of noble and wealthy women (also made many self-portraits). 
  6. Style: not quite Rococo (more naturalistic) but also not neoclassical (less serious and sculptural). 
Compare with Jacques-Louis Davids sketch Queen Marie Antoinette on the Way to the Scaffold, 1793: queen in a simple shift and bonnet, seated on cart on way to guillotine. Vige-LeBrun fled the French Revolution b/c of her ties to the court.
JeanAntoine Houdon, Admiral de Tourville, 1781

French Enlightenment

1. Part of a series of monumental full-body sculptures of the great men of France, commissioned by Comte dAngiviller, director of Buildings under Louis XVI (roughly the Minister of Culture), intended to inspire virtue and instill pride and patriotism amidst its viewers
2. Tourville was a well-known admiral under Louis XIV who won a series of naval battles against the English before being defeated in the notorious battle of La Hogue
3. Paradigmatic of the shift away from depicting French heroes as nude gods and towards historic authenticity: each sculpture is clearly situated in a specific period of French history (detailed by his dress and attributes), paralleled by the high regard for history painting
4. Part of a mid-18th century call for a more serious, noble and moral art, turning away from the perceived frivolousness of Rococo, a turn led amongst others by the philosopher Diderot, and exemplary of a conflict of power between the newly-ascended, hardworking middle classes and the bored and debauched aristocracy
Henry Fuseli, The Nightmare, 1781

Late Georgian British 
  1. Was first displayed at annual royal academy exhibition in London in 1792 where it shocked, titillated and frightened exhibition visitors and critics and established his reputation. Unlike many of the paintings shown at the Royal Academy, this had no moralizing subject and instead appealed to the 18th Century British fascination with the sublime
  2. It is an entirely invented scene in which a sleeping womans dream takes physical form in the shape of a wild, angry horse and a mare, an evil spirit thought to lie atop, molest and torture people while they sleep. 
  3. Fuseli adopts the chiaroscuro lighting scheme typical of enlightenment paintings, but rather that using it to symbolize the enlightening power of rational observation, Fuselis painting demonstrated the futility of light to penetrate or explain the darker irrational side of the unconscious. 
  4. Very theatrical: shallow space of the painting along with the curtains resembles a stage, along with the red fabrics beneath the body of the woman which alludes to the theatrical tactic of simulating blood. 
Contemporary critics were taken aback by the overt sexuality of the painting, since interpreted by some scholars in the connection it makes between dreaming and sexuality as anticipating Freudian ideas about the unconscious.
Joseph Wright of Derby, The Corinthian Maid, c. 17825

British Neoclassicism

1.  The 18th century search for the ideal was closely tied to a preoccupation with contour or outline. Recognizing its absence in nature, Winckelmann advocated for contour in Neoclassicism as the path to the ideal and supreme means of artistic expression. Contour enabled artists to purify reality by purging it from all physical particularities and reduce it to its formal essence the highest beauty human beings could achieve.
2.  The renewed emphasis on outline during the 18th century led to a revival of interest in the Classical legend of the origin of art. According to the Roman writer, Pliny the Elder, the first drawing in history was made by a Dibutades, the daughter of potter from Corinth who, saddened by the imminent departure of her lover, who was leaving the city, traced the shadow cast by his face on the wall. Her father filled the silhouette with clay and fired it in his kiln, which became the first relief sculpture. This story, which is the subject of Wrights painting, therefore establishes contour drawing as the beginning of all art, and was retold numerous times including in Diderots Encyclopdie. 
3.  English painter Joseph Wright is notable for his use of chiaroscuro effect, which emphasizes the contrast of light and dark, and for his paintings of candle-lit subjects. Showing his mastery in artificial illumination here, Wright conceals a hanging lamp behind the curtain, suggesting the source of the beams that cast the youths shadow. 
4.  The figure of the youth is modeled after a sleeping Endymion that Wright had drawn from a relief in Rome, during the two years he spent there sketching ancient monuments and sculptures. The sparse furnishings, garments and even the womans hairstyle are all based on archaeological evidence. The figures are arranged with a carefully measured rhythm along a narrow stage, as in a frieze or vase painting. 
5.  The painting was commissioned by Josiah Wedgewood, a pioneer of pottery manufacturing in England. His pottery copied the shapes and decorations of ancient vessels, borrowing motifs from ancient glass and relief carvings. Wedgwoods fired clay vessels, decorated with low reliefs can be seen as the descendants of Dibutades first relief sculpture.
Sir Joshua Reynolds, Portrait of Mrs. Siddons as the Tragic Muse, 1784

Grand Manner
  1. Founder and first president of British Royal Academy, Sir Joshua Reynolds advocated for a more serious, noble, and moral art.  He promoted a Grand Manner style, giving the term currency in his Discourses on Art fifteen lectures delivered at the Royal Academy. Reynolds argued that painters should not slavishly copy nature but seek a generalized and ideal form, drawing on the style of ancient Greek and Roman art (classical) and the Italian Renaissance masters such as Raphael and Michelangelo.
  2. Originally applied to history painting, regarded as the highest of genres, Reynolds adapted Grand Manner very successfully to portraiture, inventing the high art portrait.  The Grand Manner came to be applied to portrait painting, with sitters depicted life size and full-length, in surroundings that conveyed their nobility and elite status. 
  3. This painting tells two stories: that of the real-life Mrs. Siddons, the leading tragic English actress in the 18th century, known for her role as Lady Macbeth; and her identification with the Greek Muse of Tragedy, Melpomene, which was commonplace at the time. Mrs. Siddons, who lost 5 of 7 children was said to channel her despair into her roles.  Here Reynolds translates this into a solemn Michelangelesque icon, whose attributes of a dagger and chalice are held by allegorical figures of Pity and Terror, standing behind her on deeper planes.
  4. Reynolds painted Siddons' conflicted expression yet with a very elegant and noble air that exudes grace.
JacquesLouis David, The Oath of the Horatii, 1785

French Neoclassical
  1. David was a French painter in the Neoclassical style, considered to be the preeminent painter of the era. In the 1780s his cerebral brand of history painting marked a change in taste away from Rococo frivolity toward classical austerity and severity and heightened feeling, harmonizing with the moral climate of the final years of the Ancien Rgime. In 1774, David won the Prix de Rome with his work rasistrate dcouvrant la cause de la maladie d'Antiochius. This allowed him to stay five years (1775-1780) in Rome as a student from the French government. Upon his return to Paris he exhibited his work, which Diderot greatly admired; the success was so resounding that King Louis XVI of France allowed him to stay in the Louvre, a very ancient privilege desired by artists.
  2. Oath was the first royal commission by Louis XVI for a painting depicting a subject from Roman history. The scene shows the Horatii brothers taking an oath that they will win triple-duel with the Albans or die trying (one wins); this particular scene is one of David's own invention, not in Roman historical accounts but references the moral character of the story.
  3. This painting marks turning point in David's career and earned him lasting and international fame. It exemplifies Winckelmann's ideal of noble simplicity and quiet grandeur. The drama of the scene is expressed through bodies: vigorous, muscular bodies of Horatii, and lethargic soft bodies of the women.
  4. Introduction of intense attention to line and contour.
  5. Also highlights the two faces of war: Glory and triumph, but also loss and despair. Questions whether the individual's primary duty is to serve the public or private, to the nation or family?
  6. Oath stresses the importance of patriotism and masculine self-sacrifice for one's country. As revolution in France loomed, paintings urging loyalty to the state rather than to clan or clergy abounded. Painted five years before the Revolution, the Oath of the Horatii reflects the political tensions of the period.
  7. David's picture manifests a progressive outlook, deeply influenced by Enlightenment ideas, that eventually contributed to the overthrow of the monarchy.
tienne-Louis Boulle, project for a cenotaph for Isaac Newton, c. 1785

French Neoclassicism
  1. Boulle (1728-1799) was a French neoclassical architect, almost no surviving built works. Known mostly through his drawings. 
  2. Boulle rejected Rococos sumptuous aesthetics, as well as the Vitruvian notion of architecture as the art of building. He wrote, In order to execute, it is first necessary to conceive It is this product of the mind, this process of creation, that constitutes architecture
  3. Believed that architecture should express its purpose (termed architecture parlante - talking architecture - by his critics). 
  4. Isaac Newton (who had died 150 years earlier) was regarded by Enlightenment as a hero. Boulles cenotaph (monument to a person who has died) for Newton was designed to be a sphere 500 in diameter. Cypress trees (assoc. with mourning in Greek + Roman cultures) lined each of 3 levels of exterior. Interior: void with Newtons sarcophagus at center. Visitors would have entered via tunnel which ran underneath sphere. Inside would have been dark during the day with points of light like stars from outside, and lit artificially at night via a large hanging fixture. 
  5. Cenotaph was not built. The drawings, originally done in ink and wash, were included in Boulles treatise Architecture, essai sur lart, published in the 20th century. 
  6. Boulles drawings like these were not built but were widely-circulated. Influenced cole de Beaux-Arts in mid-to-late 19th century, has resonances in modern design (think of Bauhaus unadorned designs, form follows function).
John Soane, Bank of England, 1788-1833

English Neoclassical
  1. Soane was an English Neoclassical architect. The son of a bricklayer, he rose to the top of his profession, becoming professor of architecture at the Royal Academy and an official architect to the Office of Works.
  2. His best-known work was the Bank of England (today largely destroyed), a building which had a widespread effect on commercial architecture. His main legacy is the eponymous museum in his former home and office, designed to display his obsessive and eccentric art collection and architectural artefacts.
  3. The Bank of England went through an extreme expansion because it financed the revolutionary and the Napoleonic wars. Shown here is the Tivoli Corner, a semi-circular portico which still partly exists today. 
  4. An enormous number of models and drawings were made for it by Soane and his collaborator Gandy, most famously The Bank of England represented as a ruin (1830), which bespeaks the contemporary fascination with Roman ruins (compare the etchings of Piranesi)
  5. Soane rebuilt the entire bank and vastly extended it, with a central rectangular space, vaulted ceilings with pendentives, iron-framed windows to ensure the rooms are fireproof 
  6. In the early 20th century Sir Herbert Baker rebuilt the bank and demolished most of Soanes earlier building, which Pevsner described as the greatest architectural crime in the City of London of the 20th century.
Jeremy Bentham, Panopticon, c. 1790

1. The Panopticon was the architectural plan conceived by English philosopher and sociologist Jeremy Bentham that would allow a single guard to observe an entire prison or other institution e.g. hospitals, schools, asylums. The circular structure would allow for all prisoners, workers etc. to be overseen without their ability to tell whether they are being watched, motivating them to self-discipline under the assumption they are being watched at all times. 
  2. Originating as a way to restructure the prison system, Bentham expanded his concept for a way to manage an ever-growing factory workforce in a rapidly industrializing England. 
  3. He commissioned architect Willey Reveley to draw up these panopticon plans in order to garner support for a prison he sought to build. This project was never realized.
  4. Bentham's proposal for a panopticon prison was met with great interest among British government officials because Bentham joined the emerging discussion on political economy. In his plan, prisoners would also labor for the state, so that while imprisoned they were still contributing to the economy.  
  5. The concept of the panopticon has been metaphorized by critical thinkers throughout the past centuries, including Foucault who discussed it extensively in term of panopticism in Discipline and Punish as a metaphor for modern disciplinary society.
Anne-Louis Girodet, Sleep of Endymion, 1791

French Romanticism

1.  Student of Jacques-Louis David, and was trained in the Neoclassicism but deviated from the style of his teacher in several ways, reflective instead of early romantic style. The dark, mysterious and sensuous character of his painting, Sleep of Endymion differs greatly from the virtuous, edifying nature of Davids works. Its dynamic composition, guided by the two crossing diagonals is unlike the static construction of Davids paintings in which horizontals and verticals dominate. Most strikingly, the soft effeminate body of Endymion is distinct from the heroic male bodies featured in the work of David.
2.   The painting depicts Endymion the shepherd as a man of ideal beauty being visited at night by the goddess Diana in the form of moonbeam, who puts him in eternal sleep so she could love him forever. A prepubescent Eros parts the branches that admit the light into the thicket where Endymion rests. In attempting to break away from the footsteps of his teacher, Girodet chooses a mythological love scene more likely to have fascinated a baroque or rococo painter than David.
3.   Androgynous bodies such as Endymions were not unknown in Classical art. Winckelmann had argued that there was a duality in the Greek ideal of physical beauty the first mode was masculine, heroic and austere; the second was feminine, graceful and sensuous. Feminine traits were particularly pronounced in adolescent youths who became lovers of the gods, such as Endymion. 
4.   The theatrical lighting in this painting also differs from that in Davids works. The deep woodland shadows are traversed by a curiously blue-tinted shift of light. The light on Endymions body shows Girodets taste for the bizarre: his moonlit torso is bathed in a vaporous effect evoking renaissance works. It is this strangeness which heralds the emerging romantic sensibility.
5.   The increased preoccupation of Davids students with androgynous bodies from the early 1790s onwards has been attributed to various factors. On one hand, it has been interpreted as an act of rebellion against Davids relentless emphasis on the heroic nude. On the other, the new emphasis on sensuality rather than heroism was seen as a reflection of a larger psycho-cultural change following the revolutionary years. In the wake of thousands of executions during the revolution, the new generation preferred sensitivity over heroism and sympathized with the victim rather than the perpetrator.
John Flaxman, The Judgment of Paris, Illustration of Homers Iliad, 1793

English Neoclassical 
  1. John Flaxman studied at the Royal Academy, then stayed in London working for the Wedgewood ceramic factory where he studied Classical vase paintings and learned to think of form in terms of contour. 
  2. He traveled to Rome where he was commissioned to illustrate Homer's Iliad and Odyssey.  His economical line drawings produced a sensation and were reproduced in engravings and albums, first published in Italy by Piroli in 1793. Flaxman relied on pure line with no color, shading or tone. The results were rhythmic, elegant, and were described as poetry in visual form. Their simplicity made a good match to Homer's epic poems, considered to be the origin of literature.
  3. The composition alludes to the Judgement of Paris, the Greek mythological figure whos given the task of choosing the loveliest female goddess between Hera, Athena, and Aphrodite. Here, Paris wears a Phrygian cap, his common attribute from the Renaissance onwards, and bestows the golden apple to Aphrodite, while Athena and Hera are looking on.
  4. The story was popular in Greek and Roman art, enjoying a significant revival in the Renaissance and again during Neoclassicism.
JacquesLouis David, Death of Marat, 1793

French Neoclassical
  1. At this point in Davids career, he was a leader of the French Revolution, a prominent member of the radical Jacobin party, and a close friend of leader (and infamous tyrant) Maximilien Robespierre. 
  2. On his own initiative, painted three commemorative paintings representing the corpses of men who died for the revolutionary cause. Best known is this image, which depicts Marat, a Jacobin journalist who was murdered in his bathtub. David knew Marat well; represents him in an unusual way, lying naked in a tub, Marat looks vulnerable, even pitiful, but David transforms ridiculous into sublime.
  3. Pose of right arm resembles Christ's in Michelangelo's Pieta; compare Marat's death with that of Christto see it as a martyr's death for the "salvation of the people."  By eliminating all action, all allegorical references, and almost all allusion to Marat's violent death, he has created a true icon of the revolution, a new martyr for a new world. 
  4. Interesting composition choice, a very tall vertical dominated by darkness. Emphasizes the only horizontal part, the pale corpse of Marat hanging over his bathtub with a quill in his hand.
  5. 1794 Jacobins freed from power and David, imprisoned twice, narrowly avoided death; ironically went on to become a favourite artist of Napoleon, the embodiment of imperialism.
  6. French Revolution began in 1789, when citizens stormed the Bastille prison in Paris. Within a few years, France had adopted and overthrown several constitutions and executed its former king. It found itself at war with most of the Continent and endured horrible violence at home during the Reign of Terror.
  7. With the revolution, French painting resumed its moral and political purpose and embraced the style known as neoclassicism. Even before 1789, popular taste had begun to turn away from the disarming, lighthearted subjects of rococo; as revolution neared, artists increasingly sought noble themes of public virtue and personal sacrifice from the history of ancient Greece or Rome. They painted with restraint and discipline, using the austere clarity of the neoclassical style to stamp their subjects with certitude and moral truth.
  8. Neoclassicism triumphedand became inseparably linked to the revolutionin the work of Jacques-Louis David, a painter who also played an active role in politics. As virtual artistic dictator, he served the propaganda programs first of radical revolutionary factions and later of Napoleon. As a young man David had worked in the delicate style of his teacher Franois Boucher, but in Italy he was influenced by ancient sculpture and by the seventeenth-century artists Caravaggio and Poussin, adopting their strong contrasts of color, clear tones, and firm contours. David gave his heroic figures sculptural mass and arranged them friezelike in emphatic compositions that were meant to inspire his fellow citizens to noble action.
Francisco Goya, El Sueo de la razn produce monstruos, 17978

Spanish Enlightenment/Proto-romanticism
  1. Francisco Goya y Lucientes (1746-1828) was trained as a painter in Madrid. Diego Velzquez was his role model. Became First Court Painter in 1799, painted life-size portrait of family of Carlos IV in 1800. 
  2. On 6 February 1799, Goya placed a notice in the Madrids main newspaper Diario de Madrid, advertising A Collection of Prints of Capricious Subjects, Invented and Etched by Don Francisco Goya. 80 etchings critiquing societal ills, with the last 20 or so, including El Sueo (#43), incorporating fantastic imagery. El Sueo may originally have been frontispiece of the album. 
  3. Enlightenment ideals (see Diderot and Greuze) at a time when they were under attack. Since the artist is convinced that the censure of human errors and vices (though they may seen the province of Eloquence and Poetry) may also be the object of Painting, he has chosen as subjects adequate for his work, from the multitude of follies and blunders common to civil society, as well as from vulgar prejudices and lies authorized by custom, ignorance or interest, those that he has thought the most suitable manner for ridicule. Pictorial satire in British tradition of William Hogarth (widely exported throughout Europe at the time). 
  4. Caption reads imagination abandoned by reason produces impossible monsters; united with her, she is the mother of the arts and the source of their wonders: artistic creation = imagination tempered by reason.  
  5. Emergence of Romanticism: Goya as transitional figure. El Sueo - caption indicates that artists not governed only by reason, but by imagination too: central to Romanticism. 
  6. Aquatint: creates hazy/murky quality of background. Invented 17th century by Dutch printmaker, Jan van de Velde, Los Caprichos often seen as one of first works to make best use of process. (process description can be found at Khan Academy link below if you need a refresher)
  7. Later (c. 1810-15) - Los Desastres de la Guerra (The Disasters of War), deepening social commentary regarding abandonment of reason to violence. Prompted by Napoleons 1807 attempt to conquer Spain, war of independence.
Antonio Canova, Monument to the Archduchess Maria Christina, 17981805

Italian Neoclassical

1. Canova was the only Italian artist to excel when Rome was perceived the center of the European world; he reached international fame for his marble sculptures and was one of the first stars of the artworld
2. Designed tombs for two popes and numerous famous aristocrats, this one is for the daughter of Empress Maria Theresia and sister of Marie-Antoinette
3. Replaced the symbolic pyramidal shape with an actual pyramid, the most ancient funerary monument, with an open door leading to the interior (disregarding evidence that the pharaohs made all efforts to hide this entry); based on Pyramid of Cestius in Rome; evoking an old project, never realized, for a monument to Titian in Venice
4. At the top a female deity and a putto are holding Maria Christinas portrait, the figures in the lower left represent the course of life from youth to old age, on the lower right the spirit of death leans on the lion, symbol of authority, a cortege of young women carrying the urn into the black void of death
5. Inscription reads To the Best Wife/Albert (her husband was Prince Albert of Saxony)
6. Remarkable for the absence of any Christian symbols of death and redemption; is not a glorification of the deceased but is a quiet, timeless meditation on death
7. Canova excels at reconciling the ideal (Classical) and the real and specific (contemporary): Maria Christina is not at the center of the work but merely an inspiration for a meditation on death
8. During the first French occupation of Vienna in 1805, Napoleon was so impressed by the monument that he requested the services of Canova
Charles Wild, Fonthill Abbey, 1799

Late Georgian British
  1. Wild was an English watercolor artist who specialized in architecture. Throughout his career he painted several series of works on cathedrals and abbeys throughout England including Westminster Abbey and Christ Church, Oxford.
  2. Fonthill Abbey was a large Gothic revival country house in England, conceived by William Thomas Beckford, the wealthy son of an English plantation owner along with architect James Wyatt.
  3. The refurbishment included the building of a 6 mile wall around the property, conversion of garden building into a monastery and the erection of a central medieval tower of more than 250 ft, which collapsed in 1825.
  4. It was an unparalleled realization of a Gothic fantasy, epitomizing the sublime as defined by Burke.
  5. The architecture reflected the romantic properties of the landscape of hills, lakes and grottoes. This painting similarly emphasizes the pastoral setting for the abbey, which built on the aesthetic theory of the sublime which at the end of the 19th century was being supplemented by the Picturesque which had greater concern for nature.
JacquesLouis David, Madame Rcamier, 1800

French Neoclassical

1.   While Salons during the 19th century were dominated by large-scale historical paintings, small-scale genre paintings, landscapes and portraits were more extensive in terms of number. As the middle class began to grow and thrive in the wake of the Revolution, there was a new demand for such works, which were, because of their modest size, perfectly suited to domestic interiors. Of these, portraiture was the most in demand as the new bourgeoisie liked to furnish their homes with portraits of themselves and their families. 
2.   Davids Portrait of Madame Rcamier portrays a well-connected Parisienne. Her salon attracted many well-known political figures, intellectuals and artists of the day. She is portrayed from some distance and her face is rendered small, indicating its significance to be less as a portrait of a person, but rather that of an ideal feminine elegance.
3.   Davids portrait does not focus on the sitters social status but rather on her natural beauty. Barefoot and simply dressed in a white antique style sleeveless dress, she is shown in Roman fashion, reclining on a settee. The room is empty except for the sofa, stool and candelabra. One of the innovative features of this painting is its horizontal format, unusual for a portrait and habitually reserved for history paintings. The bare space around the figure emphasizes the elegant form of her reclined body. 
4.   Her white dress is brightened up by the warm hues of the furniture, assigning a clear harmony to the composition. Her antique pose, the bare dcor and light dress all epitomize neoclassical ideals.
5.   The limited colour scheme, white undercoat showing through in certain places, and the lack of highlights to the impasto of her dress indicate that the portrait was left incomplete, supposedly due to Davids exasperation. However, the austerity and the simplicity of colors lends this painting a refreshing purity that is distinct from other portraits of the period.
Francisco Goya, The Family of Carlos IV, 18001

Realism/Romanticism?
  1. This life-size, full-length portrait of the royal family was painted in Aranjuez and Madrid in 1800, shortly after Goya was named First Court Painter (1799).
  2. The scene shows Queen Mara Luisa de Parma and King Carlos IV at the center, surrounded by their siblings and their children, united as a strong regal monarchy. On the left is their son, the Prince of Asturias and future King Fernando VII in blue.
  3. Of interest are the individualized characters, the careful rendering of the latest fashion, and the jewels, as well as the honors, such as the sashes and crosses worn by the men.
  4. Goya's uncompromising realism was done with virtuoso strokes, a style of painting that he developed from his early occupation as a tapestry designer, which required broad virtuoso strokes and rapid execution.
  5. This brought new informality and naturalism to court painting that anticipates 19th century portraiture and photography, and Romanticism's interest in human personality and its moods.
  6. Goya's presence in the back left implies the royals are standing in front of a mirror and he is painting their reflection, also recalling Velasquez's Las Meninas
Rembrandt Peale, Rubens Peale with a Geranium, 1801

Neoclassicism
  1. Peale was an American portraitist who did a famous portrait of George Washington when he was 17. As a young artist, he benefited from his father's friendships and patronage in Federal America.
  2. The sitter is his brother who holds the reported first geranium in the US and first exotic specimen grown in the New World, his brother maintained a museum of natural history in Baltimore, although later in life turned to paint still lifes. Rubens Peale (sitter) had a fascination with the natural world, which is made clear as the human subject shares the spotlight with the exotic plant.
  3. Work could be described as a double portrait because the geranium is as lovingly portrayed as the painter's brother is. A great example of the unaffected naturalism that marked the artist's early maturity as a painter.
  4. Peale's style was influenced by French Neoclassicism after a stay in Paris in his early thirties.
  5. This is a departure from traditional European portraiture, and valued for its "embodiment of an ideal in American art that favors candor over pretension, clarity over complexity, and the natural over the conventional."
  6. Stylistic aspects of the plant are mirrored in the young man's posture, as two of his fingers rest on the lip of the pot, the two pointed fronds at the top of the plant are close to his hair.
Antoine-Jean Gros, Bonaparte Visiting the Plague House of Jaffa, Salon of 1804

French Neoclassicism
  1. Commissioned by Napoleon: used war painting as propaganda - Napoleon as brilliant, strong general and humane leader. This moment at Jaffa: in 1799, Napoleons troops massacred its inhabitants after failure to conquer Egypt. Napoleon received negative press. Napoleon and some staff visited the sick at hospital May 11, 1799 - unclear whether he wanted to see if soldiers should be transported or left to die, or if he wanted to boost troops morale. (British press accused him of wanting to execute the plague-stricken). Napoleon wanted his visit to be seen in a positive light. 
  2. Gros was student of Jacques-Louis David, continue tradition of Ingres and others of showing Napoleon as Christ-like figure touching a patients bubo (lesions of the bubonic plague) (similar to Christs healing touch to lepers). Napoleon removes glove to touch, while his generals are disgusted by the plague surrounding them. (Not much known about spread of disease by fleas at the time: danger)
  3. Shown in Salon of 1804 - very successful b/c brought drama of contemporary events into history painting (vs. the neoclassical calm of artists like David). Emotion of subjects, viewer meant to feel horror + sublime: herald Romanticism. Influenced next generation of painters, like Gricault and Delacroix. 
  4. Exoticized setting. Stained glass, Islamic arches, minaret, colorful and ornate clothing and turbans of hospital staff. 
  5. Lower left: figures pose of despair references Michelangelo's Last Judgment at the Sistine Chapel, Rome.
  6. Revolutionary flag in center background, where diagonal lines of composition lead: Napoleons actions for the peoples cause
  7. Idealism and classicism were abandoned in favour romanticism. In effect, this is suffering in painted form, which was a novelty - previously only noble deaths were painted.
Antonio Canova, Perseus, 18046

Italian Neoclassicism

1. Canova was the only Italian artist to excel when Rome was perceived the center of the European world; he reached international fame for his marble sculptures and was one of the first stars of the artworld, often regarded as the greatest Neoclassical artist
2. Was a generation younger than the Neoclassical painters Mengs, Vien or West; ironically, Classical influence came late to sculpture due to the conservatism of the medium (expensive materials and thus dependence on commissions and less freedom to experiment); the challenge was to make sculptures that did not simply resemble those of Antiquity but conveyed a modern spirit
3. Canova excelled because he managed to capture the ideal forms of Classical sculpture (perfect proportions, textured flesh, calm grandeur) and the spirit of modernity (a sensual interpretation conditioned by the writings of Winckelmann)
4. The sculpture is based freely on the Apollo Belvedere, which came to Paris under Napoleon, where it was bought by Pope Pius VII to replace the Apollo (but was so popular that it remained as a companion statue when the Apollo returned)
5. Perseus is the slayer of the monster Medusa, whose stare turns anyone looking at her into stone; her head is based on the antique Rondanini Medusa
6. Represents the aftermath of battle rather than battle itself, as Baroque and Rococo artists would have done
Philip Otto Runge, The Times of Day, (Morning, Midday, Evening, Night), 1805

German Romanticism 
  1. Runge rejected the tradition of academic art in favor of a radical, highly personal vision that symbolically expressed the essential harmony of nature, humanity, and the divine. He was particularly perceptive to the writings of Jacob Bhme which was a fusion of Lutheran theology and renaissance nature mysticism. This helped shape Runges belief that the highest expression of the divine in art is achieved not in history paintings but in paintings of nature. Landscape, he argued was the art form of the future.
  2. This series that Runge saw to be his legacy to the world preoccupied him for most of his career (died at 33 of tb). He intended the paintings (never completed) to be the main element of a Gesamtkunstwerk to be viewed in a gothic-style room accompanied by music and poetry readings. 
  3. 4 times of day are represented by symmetrical stylized plants surmounted by women and putti. Flowers, per Bhme, are symbols of states of awareness. As in his other works, Runge establishes connections between dawn, light, purity, spring, birth, Christ and love suggesting that everything in the universe is related within a divine scheme.
  4. The elaborate frames enhance the religious message: in Morning two putti emerge from an earth blackened by sin, and across the frame seem to symbolize souls redeemed from sin by the Passion of Christ. The frames reinforce the cyclical nature of life from birth through death and resurrection, metaphorized also by the times of day. 
  5. Much of the imagery of this series is pulled from traditional Roman Catholic theme of the Assumption (entrance of Virgin into heaven) and Morning in particular pulls from Renaissance imagery (Raphaels Sistine Madonna). 
  6. Runges gestural use and contortions of amaryllises and lilies in Times of Day have been described as a predecessor to Art Nouveau movement almost 100 years later.
