That each of these units was identical significantly expedited the building process and lowered the cost of construction. They were prefabricated in different locations and then assembled on the spot over the course of 6 months in Hyde Park. This was a breakthrough in technology and design: being able to make buildings that are both gigantic and easy to construct.
  3. With the structure, Paxton demonstrated a highly sophisticated roofing system, ridge-and furrow, and ventilation system.
  4. Airiness and exposure of all structural elements perfectly expressed the spirit of the new Industrial age and were unprecedented in a period where elaborately decorated historical revivalist buildings were the norm. It received mixed reviews at the time: some thought it monstrous, others were in awe and anticipated its profound influence on modern architecture; others thought of it as a fancy temporary structure, but not Architecture proper
  5. Each nation had a section for industrial and design products, and any objects/art that showed up their distinct national character (i.e. Indian teepee in the US section). They also included newest industrial machines (esp. of textile industry) and design products for the bourgeois home imitating the style of 18th century aristocracy)
  6. The main body of the building was over 1,848 feet long with a transept 108 feet high.
  7. The Crystal palace established an architectural standard for later international fairs and exhibitions that were likely house in glass conservatories.
  8. The exhibition was criticized for its stylistic eclecticism and homogeneity: all objects looked similar, imitating the European worn-out styles of the past instead of creating a new language of design
William Holman Hunt, The Hireling Shepherd, 1851

Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood
1.     English painter who was one of the founders of the pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, modelled in part on the Nazarene movement. The group rejected the artifice of the Mannerist and Baroque artists, and sought a return to an abundance of detail, intense colours and complex composition.
2.     The group called for a return to early renaissance idea of serious subjects like Biblical and literary themes, such as The Hireling Shepherd based on Shakespeares King Lear. This painting depicts a shepherd neglecting his flock in favour of a country girl to whom he shows a moth. 
3.     Hunt painted this image when he was living and working with John Everett Millais, who was painting Ophelia at the time. Both paintings draw from Shakespeares work and depict English rural scenes, in which natural harmony is disturbed through subtle violations. In Hunts painting, the shepherd ignores his flock, causing them to wander over a ditch into a wheat field. This violation is paralleled by the shepherds physical intrusions into the personal space of the woman. 
4.     Hunts painting was criticised for its vulgarity, with audiences objecting to its portrayal of red-faced and sexually uninhibited lower-class country people. 
5.     Hunt himself has asserted that he intended an underlying meaning behind the work meant to symbolise the pointless theological debates which occupied Christian churchmen while their flock went astray due to lack of moral guidance.

John Everett Millais, Death of Ophelia, 185152
Tate Gallery, London

Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood
  1. Member of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, a secret society of young artists (and one writer), founded in London in 1848. Like the Nazarenes, they looked to the Early Renaissance (before Raphael), Botticelli and Ghirlandaio, in a return to serious subjects. They painted literary themes (Shakespeare, Arthurian legend, Biblical scenes) rich in Christian symbolism and religious themes, which elevated the imagery above the materialism of the Victorian age. They scorned the middle-class taste for eclecticism, sentimentality, and sensationalism and criticized the Royal Academy for bending to these tastes.
  2. Pre-Raphaelites goal was to combine idealism of the subject matter with truthful, meticulous and realistic details, garnered from observing nature. Even the occasional genre scenes were intensely moralizing and rich in symbolic meaning, developing a mode of painting referred to as Symbolic Realism. 
  3. When applied to the Pre-Raphaelites, realism is more of a stylistic term used to describe its sharply focused almost photographic painting irrespective of subject matter, as seen in Ophelia. 
  4. Millais initially painted Biblical subjects but was not successful at exhibition (seen by critics as blasphemous). Shifted to themes inspired by literature, history, and contemporary life, like this one based on Shakespeare's Hamlet. It depicts Hamlets scorned lover committing suicide by drowning herself in a pond. Pre-Raphaelites took care to select episodes with psychological content rather than action, while striving for historical accuracy in settings and costumes. 
  5. Ophelia was very successful at exhibition in 1852: it serves as the embodiment of the historical and naturalist focus of the group, combining attention to detail with beauty of subject, a literary theme breaking away from classic representations, shimmering colours, and natural setting. Millais follows Shakespeare's depiction of Ophelia closely, who was "mermaid-like," as the water bore her up repeatedly, at "which time she chanted snatches of old tunes."  Millais was made an Associate of the Royal Academy in 1853, and a full member in 1863. In 1885 he was created a baronet and in 1896 was elected President of the Royal Academy, but died shortly thereafter.
  6. PRBs principal members were William Holman Hunt, John Everett Millais, and Dante Gabriel Rossetti. After initial heavy opposition the Pre-Raphaelites became highly influential, with a second phase of the movement from about 1860, inspired particularly by the work of Rossetti, making major contributions to symbolism.

John Martin, Great Day of His Wrath, 1852
Tate Gallery, London

English Romanticism
  1. Martin was an English Romantic painter, engraver and illustrator. He was celebrated for his typically vast and melodramatic paintings of religious subjects and fantastic compositions, populated with minute figures placed in imposing landscapes
  2. Subject/Work: his son has said it was inspired by a trip to Black Country (coal mining part of England), which has led some scholars to hold that the rapid industrialisation of England in the early nineteenth century influenced Martin.
  3. Terrifying image of God's punishment of the world. A belated example of sublime art, but more closely related to popular entertainment; inspired by contemporary panoramas, dioramas, and magic lantern shows
  4. Giant size not suited for sale to middle-class public; Martin relied on exhibition of painting and sale of black and white print reproductions; image reproduced as a mezzotint by printmaker Mottran and widely sold. Like West and Fuseli, he relied on the success of his paintings at exhibitions and marketed black-and-white print reproductions to the middle class.
Ford Madox Brown, Work, 1852, reworked Between 1856 and 1863

Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood 
  1. Ford Maddox Brown was at the periphery of Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood (see Millais + Hunt)
  2. Taught painting to Dante Gabriel Rossetti (beginning 1848)
  3. Large oil-on-canvas painting (4.5 x 6.5 ft) relatively realistic depiction of working class people: unusual for PRB. (See Hunts The Hireling Shepherd; more like Courbets The Stonebreakers, perhaps). Sought to draw attention to the fate of the working class and the contrast between the rich and poor.
  4. Fenced excavation site in London; poor orphans and flower girl in foreground contrast with wealthy riders in background. 
  5. Two men at right: Thomas Carlyle (writer of Past and Present, exposing societys iniquities) and F.D. Maurice (teacher at the Working Mens College): audiences avatars, concerned with social structure of contemporary Britain
  6. Commissioned by T.E. Plint, Pre-Raphaelite patron and Christian Socialist (group included F.D. Maurice) - asked for a painting that illustrated those ideals
Charles Ngre, The Vampire, 1853

French Second Empire / early photography (?)
1. Salted paper print from a dry waxed paper negative
2. The photograph shows the famous gargoyle of Notre Dame de Paris (= a fantasy creature, a vampire having elements of a woman and a dog); the character posing in a top hat behind the sculpture is Henri Le Secq, another leading photographer of the time.
3. Importance of Notre Dame: While Haussmann was destroying the medieval fabric of Paris, Eugne Viollet-le-Duc restored the most famous medieval monuments such as Notre Dame (built by Louis IX in the 13th century and damaged during French Revolution). Viollet used a then-popular inventive restoration technique whereby he remade lost statues and reintegrated them into the Gothic faade (different from todays protection and conservation paradigm). Might the gargoyle have been one such invented/restored figure?
4. Immediately caught the attention of contemporary photographers. It is remarkable for its composition: verticality of the wall, the strong diagonal line of the balcony, the clarity with which the Gothic moldings and sculptures stand out against the background of sprawling modern Paris, the confident pose and characteristic top hat of modern man
5. The setting is testimony to the photographers shared interest in Gothic architecture, juxtaposed with modern Paris in the background. This shows that beside the new Beaux-Arts buildings of Haussmann, the Gothic still retained its attraction as Frances national style par excellence.
6. The French collector Andr Jammes chose to call this photograph The Vampire, in an analogy with a famous engraving by the painter Charles Mryon.
Rosa Bonheur, The Horse Fair, 1853

French Academic Realism
  1. Shown at the Salon of 1853, Bonheurs most famous painting represents the biweekly horse market in Paris. The painting represents the horses in life-size from various poses and angles, a tour de force of horse painting.
  2. For a year and a half Bonheur sketched there twice a week, dressing as a man to discourage attention. Bonheur was well established as an animal painter when the painting debuted at the Paris Salon of 1853, where it received wide praise. The painting served to show the possible breadth of womens painting, beyond the genres of watercolor and flowers assigned to them.
  3. Bonheurs paintings addressed the rural experience, often in idyllic way, in contrast to the representation of the hardship of peasants by contemporaneous artists such as Courbet and Millet 
  4. The extremely active middle ground is balanced by the simplicity of the bare foreground and the atmospheric perspective in the background, where we see the outline of the Pitie-Salpetriere Hospital. On the far right, potential buyers calmly look down upon the controlled frenzy from the safety of the wooded hillside, emphasizing the class divide captured by proximity to the action. 
  5. Some have argued that this painting is not only commendable for the naturalism of its portrayal of horses, but captures the psychology of both the animals and the humans who try to control them.

William Holman Hunt, The Awakening Conscience, 185354
Tate Britain, London

Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood
1.    English painter who was one of the founders of the pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, modelled in part on the Nazarene movement. The group rejected the artifice of the Mannerist and Baroque artists, and sought a return to an abundance of detail, intense colours and complex composition.
2.    The only member of the group to consistently paint religious paintings throughout the length of his career, yet, here he opts for a moralizing picture: a narrative genre scene of a young prostitute, springing from the lap of the man, as she is reminded of her country roots by the music the man plays (the sheet music to Thomas Moores Oft in the Stilly Night sit on the piano), causing her to have an awakening of conscience.
3.    Addresses the common Victorian narrative of the fallen woman, echoing the prevalence of prostitution in Victorian society. Countless other paintings of the period emphasies the perils of stepping outside the bounds of morality with the conclusion being of the woman being ostracised and suffering a premature death (eg. Richard Redgraves The Outcast, 1851). By contrast, Hunt offers the viewer the hope that the young woman in his painting is truly repentant and can ultimately reclaim her life.
4.    Around the room are symbolisms of her kept status and wasted life: the cat underneath the table toying with a bird, a clock concealed under glass, the unfinished tapestry with thread unravelling. However, a ray of light illuminates her from behind, offering the viewer hope that she may find the strength to redeem herself.
5.    This is one of the few Pre-Raphaelite paintings to deal with a subject from contemporary life, but still retains the truth to nature and attention to detail typical of the style. The texture of the carpet, the reflection in the mirror, the carvings of the furniture all speak to Hunts belief that the artists should recreate the scene as closely as possible, and paint from direct observation. To do that, he hired a room in the neighbourhood of St. Johns Wood to use as his setting.

Richard Dadd, Fairy Fellers Master Stroke, 1855-64, 
Tate Britain, London

Victorian Era / Fairy Painting
  1. Dadd was the best-known Victorian fairy painter, especially the works created later in life while in mental hospital for schizophrenia. From the early 1840s, Dadd painted Shakespearean inspired fairy paintings like The Fairy Feller's Master Stroke. Dadd's works are among the 1st by an insane artist to be preserved. He became famous in the mid20th c. with interest in 'outsider art.'
  2. Fairy paintings: uniquely British genre, originated in Shakespearean scenes; popularity may also derive from Victorian interest in prenatural, psychic, and occult. The image was painted during stay in Bedlam - the Royal Hospital of Bethlehem in London - after he murdered his father due to schizophrenia. The 'feller' may be an alter-ego of Dadd's murderous tendencies?
  3. Image epitomizes fairy painting in its highly inventive imagery and startling manipulation of size
  4. The canvas is full and has little empty space- Horror vacui (fear of emptiness) and obsession with detail are characteristic of imagery by schizophrenic patients.
  5. Dadd's work likely preserved for medical rather than artistic reasons; art hardly known in his lifetime and not re-evaluated as important artist until mid-20th c. interest in "outsider art."
  6. Only explicit characters are Oberon and Titania from A Midsummer Night's Dream; others are created by Dadd. Microscopic attention to detail. Technique was to make a detailed sketch of the composition and then paint each object and area in its entirety before proceeding. Use of fairly thick paint gives cobbled appearance to some of the surface. Strange disruptions of scale and lack of perspective enhance fantastic feel of the picture. Onlooker is further distanced from the scene by screen of tendrils and grasses.
Elizabeth JerichauBaumann, Double Portrait of the Grimm Brothers, 1855

Biedermeier Portraiture? (don't agree)
  1. Elizabeth Jerichau-Baumann (18191881) was a Polish-Danish painter. She was an atypical, forward thinking and respected artist, though her desire for artistic expression often met with opposition. She trained at the Academy in Dusseldorf (1838-45); then worked in Rome for 5 years, where she met and married Danish sculptor Jens Adolf Jerichau. In 1849, he became a professor at The Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts and they moved to Copenhagen.  He was the director of the Academy between 1857-63. In 1861, she became one of the first female members of The Academy.  However, she struggled to find acceptance within Danish art circles because of her gender, artistic idiom, and German training.
  2. Her cosmopolitan nature, frequent travels (England, France, Russia, Greece, Turkey, and Egypt) and adept networking skills, allowed her to focus on portraiture. She could not be confined to any one subject or nation, and was granted rare access to paint at several harems in Constantinople. She was also a favored portraitist of the English and Danish Royal family, politicians, and authors, like her friend Hans Christian Andersen, who would pen a biography about her and her husband. While forging an international career in a male-dominated field, she also gave birth to nine children (two died in infancy).
  3. Middle-class group and individual portraits of wealthy industrialists, professionals and intellectuals were in high demand during the Biedermeier period (Congress of Vienna-Revolutions/1815-48).
  4. The painting depicts the Brothers Jacob (in profile) and Wilhelm Grimm, whose lifelong dedication to researching the early history of German language and literature, most notably folktales, made them world-renowned. They collected and edited over 200 folk tales, published between 1812-57. Their editions helped popularize folk literature among the middle class. 
  5. The iconic bust-length double portrait (life-size) shows the brothers with a book and a quill, suggesting their occupation.
  6. Portrait shows psychological insights; the expression of intense concentration speaks to their dedication to philology and scholarship.  When painted they were working on a 32-volume German dictionary, yet still sat for Jerichau-Baumann for six days; an unusually long period given their workload and time constraints, having already refused other portrait inquiries.
Owen Jones, Plate lxvii from The Grammar of Ornament, 1856

Modern Design / British Design Revolution (?)
  1. Historical eclecticism characterized many of the hybrid hand- and machine-made goods exhibited in countries sections at the 1851 Great Exhibition in the Crystal Palace: they combined Rococo and Renaissance, for example. Decried by critics as uncreative, who urged designers to strive instead for the cultivation of pure and rational individualities of design. Exhibitions planner, Henry Cole, decried many objects universal likeness.
  2. Owen Jones was an architect, designer, and design theorist who was a leading character in the design revolution prompted by the response to the Great Exhibition at the Crystal Palace (1851): Superintendent of Works for Great Exhibition and designed the interior decoration and arrangement of displays at Crystal Palace.
  3. Jones designs included ironwork in primary colors, inspired by Alhambra and Ancient Greece 
  4. Lamented the industrial mass production: put the power of design in the hands of the market, rather than artists and thinkers. 
  5. Advocated studying the logical principles behind ornaments of the past, rather than recombining the ornaments themselves: his Grammar of Ornament, published in London in 1856, included 37 axioms of design that he developed through his own analysis of historical ornament, and 100 plates of historical designs from around the world. 
  6. Focused not only on then-trendy Renaissance, baroque, and rococo styles, but also on Medieval manuscripts and Islamic and East-Asian art.
Charles Cordier, Negro of the Sudan in Algerian Costume, c. 18567

French Second Empire ethnographic sculpture / Orientalism
1. Cordier was one of the first practitioners of ethnographic photography, an art practice linked to the rise of European imperialism during the mid-19th century. In the 1850s and 60s, Cordier travelled to Algeria, Greece and Egypt to take photographs of indigenous people, documenting different racial and ethnic types (see also Bchards 1880 photo Egyptian Peasant Girl)
2. He was employed by the Museum of Natural History in Paris and used these photographs as models to create an ethnographic sculpture gallery in the museum, with life-sized busts of different ethnographic types
3. Remarkable about this bust is its combination of bronze and striated jaspar for a polychrome effect, increasing the verisimilitude of the work; polychromy in sculpture had been discredited since the Neoclassical period; Cordier gave a major impetus to the revival of polychrome sculpture and its popularization during the end of the 19th century
4. This bust was shown at the 1857 Salon
5. Cordier was supposedly struck by the beauty of a former slave on one of his journeys. Nothing is known of the model for this sculpture except that he played the tam-tam in the festivities of Algier's Muslim community before Ramadan (a hallmark of Orientalism that the portrayed remains unnamed and unknown)
6. Cordier portrays him in an admiring, respectful manner, rendering his natural nobility, which prompted comparisons with a Roman emperor (is this politically subversive or is it cynical?)
Emily Mary Osborn, Nameless and Friendless, 1857

Victorian Realism
  1. New fashion emerged in mid-victorian period for describing how the middle class lived in a detailed documentary manner 
  2. Women were not allowed to exhibit at the Academy, and here she depicts the flight of the female artist, depicting a woman artist nervously offering a painting to a condescending art dealer while her son or brother looks on. The dealer feigns dislike so as to offer the lowest price for the image, but the interest in the painting is given away by the assistant who stares at it from the ladder. 
  3. The men behind her stare at her while holding a colored print of a ballerina, alluding to the other choices facing impoverished and desperate young women. Her vulnerability is accentuated by her downward gaze and nervously fiddling fingers. 
  4. The picture clearly addresses what art historian Deborah Cherry has defined as the sexualised encounters and economies of the modern city, its spaces of pleasure, exchange and consumption (Cherry 2000, p.28). By including in close proximity three different models of femininity the ballet dancer, the comfortable bourgeois matron confidently leaving the shop with her son, and the protagonist in the foreground the artist highlights three distinct ways in which women of all classes inhabit the urban realm: as figures of sexual desire and consumption, as invisible wives secure in a family unit, and as unmarried women struggling to earn a living.
  5. Osborn was heavily involved in womens artist groups and suffragette groups, and helped petition to the Royal Academy to open its schools to female students. Despite the limitations that faced women artists, Osborn was quite successful, supported by her wealthy family and did not share the predicament of her depicted woman artist.

And Hiroshige,
Moon Pine at Ueno from One Hundred Views of Famous Places in Edo, 1857

Japanese woodblock / ukiyo-e
1.    Considered the last great master of the ukiyo-e tradition (genre that flourished between 17th and 19th centuries, characterised by woodblock prints of beautiful women and scenes of urban pleasures). However, the subjects of Hiroshiges prints was atypical to ukiyo-e and focused on landscapes.
2.    Woodblock print from the series One Hundred Views of Famous Places in Edo, the last series Hiroshige worked on before his death. The series titled promised 100 different views of specific places in the capital city of Edo (present day Tokyo), and over the course of three years, the series grew to 118 prints, indicating the success of the series at the time.
3.    This print exemplifies Hiroshiges adept technical skill. The medium used was thick mulberry bark, a wood that accentuates the bright colours and natural textures. He was known for his subtle use of colour, often printed with multiple impressions in the same area and his extensive use of bokashi (color gradation), both of which were labor-intensive techniques.
4.    In the foreground is a tree branch, through which he frames a distant view of a daimyo (Japanese feudal lords) estate, which may indicate a more political theme than the print gives at first glance. The tree in the painting received its name due to one full-moon shaped contorted branch, a common natural phenomenon found in many old Japanese pines. It was believed that when a person examined the loop branch from different angles, the various moon phases could be observed.
5.     The print also shows Hiroshiges experimentation in the vertical format. Most Japanese prints previously had been horizontal in orientation, including those by Hiroshige and his older contemporary Hokusai, and the shift to vertical in this entire series seems to have spurred Hiroshiges composition innovation. 
6.    Hiroshiges work came to have a marked influence on Western painting towards the close of the 19th century as a part of the Japonisme movement. Artists such as Manet and Monet collected and closely studied his compositions. Van Gogh painted copies of two of Hiroshiges prints from the One Hundred Famous Places in Edo series.
JeanFranois Millet, The Gleaners, 1857

Realism
  1. Millet was born in Normandy, to a peasant family and toiled the fields for his father. The land offered his family a meek livelihood, but they were devout Catholics and religion offered them solace and Millet a solid classics education.
  2. Considered the "founder" of 19C peasant painting; he lived in a small barn with his wife and 9 children in Barbizon, near Fontainebleau, where he painted the lower class and their daily life, the hardships, the sorrow, with an expressive realism and religious fervor.  
  3. The painting shows three women who incarnate the rural working-class. Gleaners were authorized to go quickly through the fields at sunset to pick up the shafts of wheat left behind after the harvest. Millet shows them doing the back-breaking labor of picking up the remaining grains, their eyes raking the ground. The women all lie below the horizon, being embraced by the landscape, depicted in soft tones and contours, making the harshness of the subject more palatable.
  4. Millet presents the three ages through subtle differences in their faces, clothing and positions, the maiden, matron and old woman (left to right). He depicts them with reverence and respect, the poses/gestures/scale give them a sense of dignity and grandeur (sculptural feel). Visible are the little bundles they have collected on the ground on the right. Their austerity contrasts with the abundant harvest in the distance: haystacks, sheaves of wheat, a cart and a busy crowd of harvesters. The sun is high and Millet smudges the distance into a powdery golden haze, accentuating the bucolic impression of the scene in the background. The overseer on horseback, isolated in the top right, is supervising the work on the estate. His presence adds social distance acting as a reminder of the landlords he represents.
  5. The Gleaners was exhibited at the Salon of 1857. Millet's "epic hymn to labor" is famous for featuring in a sympathetic way what were then the lowest ranks of rural society and was received poorly by the upper classes, who feared a new revolution.
  6. While the act of gleaning was not a new topicrepresentations of the biblical heroine Ruth had existed in artthis new work was a statement on rural poverty and not biblical piety.
AndrAdolpheEugne Disdri, Portrait of Empress Eugnie, C. 1858

Portrait Photography, carte-de-visite.
  1. Disderi was a French photographer who started his photographic career as a daguerreotypist but gained greater fame for patenting his version of the carte de visite, a small photographic image which was mounted on a card. Disdri, a brilliant showman, made this system of mass-production portraiture world famous.
  2. Competition between Nadar and Disderi to corner the star market, the demand for celebrity photographs. Disderi developed the small carte-de-visite which printed the full size portrait on a small card the size of a calling card or baseball card.
  3. Not as much psychological insight as a close-up portrait so setting and clothing are incredibly important to the identity and depiction of the sitter. 
  4. Growing popularity of images, spread far and wide. Photography flooded the world with portraits and images of people and faraway places. 
  5. Empress Eugenie, wife of Napoleon III. Last empress of the French whose public image was tied closely with her taste in fashion. She was a trendsetter during the Second Empire and was dressed by Charles Frederick Worth and painted by Winterhalter. She was a collector and patron of the arts as well.
Philip Webb, Red House, Bexley Heath, Kent, 1859

Arts and Crafts / Gothic Revival
  1. Mid-19th Century response to Industrial Revolution: critic John Ruskin argued that the inexpensive, factory-made goods flooding the markets had a negative effect on both those who made them and those who consumed them. Believed that mechanized factory production deprived workers of satisfaction of designing and hand-making objects oneself. Looked back to Gothic as high point of craft and building.
  2. Cue Arts + Crafts movement: Red House was first designed according to principles of fine craft and utility that would be employed by the design firm that Philip Webb + William Morris co-founded in 1861
  3. Red House designed for William Morris family; the two collaborated. Webb in particular went on to be a proponent of Gothic Revival architecture; both were influenced by Ruskin. 
  4. Red House is simplified Tudor Gothic in style: steep roofs, prominent chimneys, cross gables, exposed-beam ceilings, asymmetrical plan (L-shaped) as though built over long period of time. Saw Gothic as appropriate b/c of geographic specificity: Northern Europe. (Gothic originated in France, vs Classical originating in Mediterranean)
  5. Webb worked with William + Jane Morris to design all elements of home, celebrating nature and mimicking the medieval guild ideal: stained glass, built-in cabinets, furniture. Home as spiritual and moral respite from world: Victorian cult of domesticity. 
  6. Red House: color of brick (most fashionable houses at time were stuccoed) and also dragons blood (deep red-brown paint that Arts + Crafts movement favored, seen in interior

Jules Breton, Recall of the Gleaners, 1859
Musee dOrsay

French Realism
1. Breton was the most widely-recognized master of the peasant genre during the Second Empire, his paintings frequently bought by the government, which was a major economic sponsor of contemporary art at the time
2. Unlike his contemporary Millet, Breton painted a less ambivalent or challenging, but more straightforwardly positive, even epic vision of peasant life (compare this painting to Millets The Gleaners 1857)
3. This painting shows an idyllic view of gleaning: a field-guard on the left calls the women home, the central figure resembles a traditional allegory of harvest; content looks; rich bounty; festive mood. Breton does not show the backbreaking labor of gleaning like Millet does.
4. Praised at the time for its realism: regional clothing, northern French landscape, individuality of women each painted from models
5. Despite the stronger commitment of Napoleon III to (proto-)socialist ideals and his attempts to ameliorate the economic situation of the lowest classes (i.e. by regulating the price of bread), the existence of French peasantry remained wretched and marked by poverty (the activity of gleaning is to pick up the stray ears of wheat after the harvest, an activity of the poorest of the poor)
6. As small farming was replaced by larger-scale industrial farmers in the mid-19th century, the genre of peasant painting bespoke an increasing nostalgia for the idyllic rural life of the past (see also Millets Angelus 1859 or Rosa Bonheurs The Horse Fair 1853); historians call this the bourgeois myth of rural society, a myth actively promoted by the government of the Second Empire
Frederic Church, Twilight in the Wilderness, 1860

American landscape painting (Romanticism?)
  1. Church was the only student of Thomas Cole, and while influenced by Coles naturalist take on the landscape, Churchs paintings were less moralizing and idealizing, and more scientific in their almost microscopic detail. His paintings are characterized by meticulous detail within a broad panorama, simultaneously capturing the micro- and macrocosm of the landscape. This image however, certainly held a spiritual message in its capturing of natures transcendent moments. 
  2. Painted in his New York studio, the image captures the view of a blazing sunset in Maine a composite of the sketches he had made on site 2 years prior. 
  3. The painting captures the dramatic solitude of the interminable North American wilderness, much of which he shrouds in a mysterious shadow. The shadow could be interpreted metaphorically, predicting end of Eden before the march of civilization, or the impending end of an era of American History, as it was painting just before the outbreak of Civil War. 
  4. During this time there was an increasing American interest in unspoiled nature Thoreaus Walden was published in 1854. There is no sign of human activity in this landscape.
  5. He is sometimes associated with the Luminist style, characterized by effects of light in landscape through the use of aerial perspective and the concealment of visible brushstrokes an attempt to capture the landscape almost photographically. Luminists emphasize tranquility and calm. 
  6. The painting was a huge success when exhibited at a New York gallery in 1860, appealing to the cultural sense of American exceptionalism and ushering in a uniquely American art that elevated the all-American subject of the sweeping landscape to the level and scale of history painting.
Constantin Guys, Two Women with Muffs, c.1860s

Second Empire French
1.    Guys was a relatively forgotten artist, who worked primarily in pencil and watercolor. Born in Flanders, Guys had started his career as an illustrator for two English magazines, the Illustrated London News and Punch. During the first 20 years of his career, he travelled around the world to record important historic events. Living in Paris from the late 1850s onwards, he spent the remainder of his life drawing street scenes, focusing on the daily lives of the wealthy.
2.    Guys spent afternoons and evening sauntering on Haussmans new boulevards in Paris, mingling with the crowds and at night sketching scenes and figures that caught his eye from memory. Two Women with Muffs is one such sketch.
3.    Guys was one of the few artists who answered Baudelaires call for a painter of modern life in his review of the Salon of 1846. Baudelaire considered this image to represent modernity, then a new term coined to describe the continual state of change that characterized the moment they were living in. 
4.    Like most of Guyss works, it does in pencil and thinly washed watercolour, a medium that was suited to render momentary scenes. Here, the women are almost certainly prostitutes, evident from their extravagantly wide skirts, impudently lifted and the blue feathers in their hair. However, during the second empire womens fashions changed and it becomes difficult to ascertain their (low) social class because it was fashionable for wealthy men to set up mistresses in elegant apartments and give them handsome allowances. 
5.    These kept women defined traditional class boundaries. Coming from all walks of life, they formed the demimonde, a shifting and unstable world that, to Baudelaire, was the breeding ground of modernity.

Charles Garnier, Opra, 186175,
Place de lOpra, Paris

Napoleon III style / Second Empire eclectic
  1. The Opra was constructed by architect Charles Garnier, started in 1861, but not completed until after the fall of Napoleon III in 1875 (its end delayed by financial troubles, Paris Commune, Franco-Prussian War - when the building was used as a warehouse, and a fire in 1873).
  2. It was part of Napoleon III's complete revival of Paris starting in 1853, headed by architect Georges Haussmann (turning the city from a narrow medieval city into a modern metropolis with broad boulevards and straight avenues).
  3. The site was chosen by Haussmann at the end of the Avenue de l'Opera.  A design competition was held to choose the architect. Out of 171 proposals, Garnier, a little-known 35-year-old architect won the commission.
  4. It is a Second-Empire eclectic Beaux-Arts style building with a magnificent faade and a lavish interior, characteristic of Baroque sumptuousness, including a grand staircase and a seven-ton bronze and crystal chandelier designed by Garnier. Garnier used polychromy for theatrical effect, using marble, stone, porphyry, and gilded bronze, for elaborate marble friezes, columns, and lavish statuary, many portraying Greek deities.
  5. It was the most expensive building built in the Second Empire; it has immense foyers, a library, rehearsal rooms, and a school of dance.
  6. Building epitomizes the culture of the Second Empire, a "gilded age," ruled by optimism and wealth, with a prosperous bourgeoisie that had the time for leisure and cultural activities like attending opera, theater, and concerts.
  7. Four allegorical sculpture groups made from Echaillon marble decorate the faade representing the main elements of opera: composition, instrumental music, lyric drama and dance. Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux's sculpture La Danse, is the most audacious of these, and when installed it was widely criticized as obscene, as his central figure is a young male nude, instead of the usual draped female, and because of the realism of his female entourage.
  8. Palais Garnier staged grand operas by Richard Wagner, Giuseppe Verdi, Georges Bizet and more, until the Opera moved to Opra Bastille in 1989, and now presents mostly ballet.
Mathew Brady, Dead Soldier, Civil War, c. 1863

Civil War Documentary Photography
  1. Matthew Brady was an early American photographer who started making cartes-de-visite when soldiers went off to war and photographs of politicians. Called Mr. Lincolns Cameraman. When the Civil War started, his use of a mobile studio and darkroom enabled vivid battlefield photographs that brought home the reality of war to the public. Thousands of war scenes were captured, as well as portraits of generals and politicians on both sides of the conflict, though most of these were taken by his assistants, rather than by Brady himself.
  2. Because exposure times were still so long it was impossible to document the action of war. Instead Bradys team took photos of the aftermath, fields strewn with bodies. The record of the Civil War is one of carnage and death, the ravaged corpses of fellow Americans. 
  3. The starkness of war depicted with uncompromising realism. Overwhelms any romantic or sentimental notions about the glory of war. Some of these stagings were manipulated slightly by the photographers to make the images more succinct and powerful. 
  4. Bradys 1862 New York gallery exhibit, "The Dead of Antietam, featured then-unseen photographs of some of the 23,000 victims of the wars bloodiest day, which shocked American society. Brady has done something to bring home to us the terrible reality and earnestness of war," a New York Times reviewer wrote. "If he has not brought bodies and laid them in our door-yards and along the streets, he has done something very like it.
  5. Brady is credited with being the father of photojournalism. He can also be considered a pioneer in the orchestration of a "corporate credit line." In this practice, every image produced in his gallery was labeled "Photo by Brady"; however, Brady dealt directly with only the most distinguished subjects and most portrait sessions were carried out by others. Many photographers disliked ceding credit for their images to Brady. 
  6. Although this project was important to the history of photography, Brady spent a fortune on it and lost it all when the U.S. government did not purchase them for as much as he thought. Brady died in New York and was buried in an unmarked grave.

Alexandre Cabanel, Birth of Venus, 1863
Musee dOrsay, Paris

2nd Empire French Academic Painting
  1. Standard for display nude: Ingres Grande Odalisque (1814). Shocking to the public when they were painted (at a moment when history paintings were the norm, and womens nude bodies only painted for private patrons). Standard for standing frontal nude: Ingres Venus Anadyomene, painted in 1808 and repainted in 1848 and submitted to that years salon: indication of the rise in popularity of female nude, with Ingres as its master. 
  2. By mid-1800s, history painting no longer de rigeur: female nudes had become ultimate test of artistic prowess. Salon of 1863: Salon of Venuses. Cabanel followed Ingres prototype in pose (Odalisque) and subject (Venus Anadyomene); pose was erotic, despite mythological pretext. 
  3. Birth of Venus was very popular, purchased by Napoleon III for his private collection
  4. Academic ideals exemplified here: smooth brushwork, mythological subject, careful modeling. 
  5. mile Zola criticized the unrealistic, smooth rendering of skin (Venus also lacks pubic hair that would mark her as an adult woman): the goddess, drowned in a sea of milk, resembles a delicious courtesan, but not of flesh and blood--that would be indecent--but made of a sort of pink and white marzipan.
  6. One year later: Manets Olympia, which caused a scandal.
Edouard Manet, Olympia, 1863

French Realism / Early Modern
1. Submitted to the Salon of 1865, one salon after the famous Salon of Venuses of 1863 (surge of female nudes)
2. Treats the traditional academic subject of a reclining female nude but subverts the rules of the Academy with its conventions of subject matter (emphasis on decorum), form (importance of modeling) and beauty (ideal of Greek art)
3. Subject matter: The painting references yet undermines an old master, Titians Venus of Urbino (1538): replaces the goddess with a cocotte (mistresses of the modern demimonde set up by wealthy men in elegant apartments); the black choker and fashionable slippers make clear she is not a goddess but a woman of the 19th century; Olympia has a Classical ring to it but was a common professional name for prostitutes at the time
4. Form: the painting is radically innovative in that it defies the tradition of modeling nudes with chiaroscuro effect, instead reducing shading to little more than dark contour (compare nude in Djeuner sur lherbe 1863)
5. Potential influence of the craze for Japanese woodblock prints, which were circulated in Europe since the 1850s: magnificent bold patches of color, no use of chiaroscuro effect to achieve a semblance of three-dimensionality (testament to the importance of non-Western art to the history of modernism)
6. The black servant has become a seminal figure for contemporary critical race studies: gazing in subservience at Olympia who gazes in defiance at the viewer, the black servant has been discussed as reduced to the status of luxury commodity like the bunch of flowers or the cashmere shawl (see for example Fred Motens essay Taste Dissonance Flavor Escape, where he juxtaposes Manet with Thomas Eakins photograph of an African-American girl nude)
7. Widely attacked by its contemporaries, Manet was praised by mile Zola for his bold and innovative originality (important concept of modernity): he has produced original works, strong and bitter in flavor, Zola writes. Zolas oeuvre gives the most extensive picture of social life in the Second Empire (compare, for example, his Nana form 1880 about the life of a Parisian cocotte)
Edouard Manet, Djeuner sur lherbe (Luncheon on the Grass), 1863

Realism/Beginning of Modernism
  1. Student of Thomas Couture, he had gained recognition at the salon two years prior with Spanish Singer. This painting was then refused outright by Salon jury in 1863 and so was shown at the Salon des Refuss.
  2. Painting shows two young Parisian men seated with a naked woman who does not conform to the academic mythical nude, and is instead a specific woman who has purposely removed her clothes that sit in a pile beside her. A second woman bathes in a thin chemise in the background. The composition seems to refer directly to Titians Pastoral Concert (c.1508), one of the most widely admired Renaissance paintings in the Louvre, and a particular section of Marcantonio Raimondis engraving of Raphaels The Judgement of Paris.
  3. Here, he invites an alternative interpretation of Titians painting, and Renaissance painting more generally, indicating the nudity can be read in different ways depending on its visual context, either as an aesthetical beautiful atemporal form, or as an object of sexual desire firmly rooted in the present.  
  4. In the painting, Manet tries to represent outdoor light more faithfully, painting directly onto the white canvas so as to capture the vibrant greens of the outdoors, in contrast to the muddiness of Titians colors due to the traditional use of a brown wash ground. He represented shadow as it appears in broad daylight, no more than a dark contour, abandoning the usual subtle gradation of shadow in favor of brutal contrasts.
  5. Manet deliberately flattens the background so that the figures seem to be placed artificially on top of a shallow backdrop, emphasizing Manets desire to decontextualize and remove justification for the nude.
  6. Along with Olympia, this work is credited with ushering in the era of modernism, in his challenging of traditional subjects and style, exploration of new subject matter, painterly values and spatial relationships.
Nadar, Sarah Bernhardt, 1864

Portrait photography
1.    Flix Tournachon (used the pseudonym Nadar) was considered the greatest portrait photographers of the period, when portrait photography was beginning to be regarded as an artform. He started as a portrait caricaturist, and thus had sharp sensitivity to the facial characteristics of his sitters. 
2.    He was known for his portraits of political and artistic celebrities. He brought out the physical and psychological essence of his sitters through posing, lighting, and various darkroom manipulations.
3.    Nadar began his career as a theatre critic and writer. He started his project of creating a lithographic Pantheon of Famous Contemporaries in 1851, but financial problems prevented him from producing more than one issue. He later turned to the emerging field of photography to produce portraits of celebrities for technical reasons: photography was faster and cheaper than lithography.
4.    This image was created at a time when Nadar was preoccupied with ballooning, and left most of the portrait work to his studio assistants, but made an exception to photograph the actress himself. He wrapped her in a great sweep of velvet, baring one shoulder but showing no more of her body, centring all the attention to her face. 
5.    The actress Sarah Bernhardt was about twenty at the time, and had barely begun her long and successful career. She would go on to become an incomparable actress, famous first in France and then internationally for her wide variety of plays. 
6.    There was a great demand for celebrity photographs during the 19th century, and competition in the star market became increasingly stiff (led to the development of cartes-de-visite)
Winslow Homer, Prisoners from the Front, 1866

19C American / Realism?
  1. Homer is regarded by many as the greatest American painter of the 19th C. His work is rooted in American experience and represented a departure point for American art in the 20th C. (in comparison to Whistler, Cassatt, or Sargent)
  2. Homer was an illustrator for the journal Harper's Weekly, and he was sent to the front during the Civil War. The material he collected as artist-correspondent provided the subjects for his first oil paintings.
  3. Homer completed this painting in 1866, one year after the war ended. It represents an actual scene in which a Union officer, General Francis Channing Barlow, captured several Confederate officers on June 21, 1864. General Barlow was one of the most eminent officers to survive the war. The background depicts the battlefield at Petersburg, Virginia.
  4. Homer focused on the emotional drama of the encounter rather than the high drama of battle, showing instead the ravaged landscape of the battlefields in Petersburg, Virginia. We feel the tension between Barlow and the Confederate soldiers, as Homer expertly characterized the range of personalities involved in the war, from the young and old men humbly submitting to their fate, to the proud challenging stance of the man in Confederate uniform.
  5. Perceived as vigorous and truthful, the painting achieves the impact of history painting in that the characterization of the varying ages and types of soldiers alludes to the tremendous difficulties to be faced during the Reconstruction, reflecting a profound understanding of the wars impact and meaning.

Dante Gabriel Rossetti, Monna Vanna, 1866
Tate Gallery, London

Aesthetic movement
  1. Rossetti (1828-1882) was a poet and painter who began in the Pre-Raphaelite tradition. His early works were inspired by biblical and medieval sources. He illustrated books of poems in addition to his oil paintings. 
  2. Rossetti befriended poet Swinburne who adhered to Gautiers ideas of art for arts sake that had no moral or instructive content but was meant to appeal to the senses. The Aesthetic Movement was guided by complex ideas, but most boiled down to 2 ideas set forth by Walter Horatio Pater (1839-1894): 1) Art is superior to nature. 2) Content is not as important as form. 
  3. Like the Pre-Raphaelites, the Aesthetic Movement was directed against reigning Bourgeois tastes like the anecdotal and descriptive genre paintings of Victorian taste. 
  4. Inspired by the new Aesthetic movement, Rossetti begins painting again, specifically paintings like Monna Vanna, that are iconic instead of narrative. Not a portrait of a woman, an idealized vision of a woman cloaked in sensual fabrics. The subject is just a vehicle for a beautiful painting. 
  5. Beauty compared with sexual arousal, beauty carried in the guise of a beautiful woman without an identity. The idea of beauty carried within her. Idealized, not individualized features. 
  6. Female figure offset on a dark background with an oil painted sheen, focus on the beautiful sensual experience of the color, shine, texture, surface.

Julia Margaret Cameron, Portrait of Sir John Herschel, 1867
Museum of Modern Art, New York

Early Victorian Photography
  1. Sir John Frederick William Herschel was a famous Victorian astronomer (he popularized the wave theory of light) who invented the cyanotype ("blue-print"), often used to make contact prints of botany. 
  2. A few years after they met in South Africa in 1835, Herschel wrote to Julia Margaret Cameron (1815 - 1879) in Calcutta about Henry Fox Talbots invention of photography and sent her the first photographs she had ever seenscientific discoveries that were water to the parched lips of the starved, she recalled. According to Cameron, Herschel was as a Teacher and High Priest, and an illustrious and revered as well as beloved friend.
  3. Cameron favored an atmospheric effect rather than the sharp, descriptive images sought by many of her contemporaries and was the subject of their ridicule as a result. At a time when flat lighting and long depth of field were standard, Cameron sought expressive effects: contrast of light and shadow, varying qualities of light, shallow focus.
  4. Cameron defended the distinction between art photography and "professional" photography (she proudly practiced the former). 
  5. Cameron, stylistically influenced by portraits by Rembrandt and Vlazquez, used the collodion-albumen process: more difficult than the calotypes made by Talbot and others, but allowed her to achieve deeper chiaroscuro effects. 
  6. Cameron sought to make portraits that depicted subjects inner life rather than merely outward appearance. For this portrait, she had Herschel wash and tousle his hair to catch the light, draped him in black, brought her camera close to his face, and photographed him emerging from the darkness. Herschel liked this photograph best of the four exposures that Cameron made at this time: he thought it made him look like an old Paterfamilias.
  7. Cameron was aware of the commercial viability of her Herschel portraits: he was a famous figure, and her photography helped to  support herself and her family. She registered them for copyright, and in June 1867 they were displayed at Colnaghis, a commercial art gallery and print publisher in London. The reviewer for the Athenaeum described them as severely and grandly effective pictures of a noble head. Cameron sent this work and several others to the 1867 Universal Exhibition in Paris, where she was awarded an honorable mention for artistic photographs.

Marcello, Pythian Sibyl, 186770
Opra, Paris

2nd Empire Academic sculpture
1. Marcello (pseudonym for Adle dAffry, Duchess of Castiglione Colonna) was a Swiss artist and one of the first female sculptors to make a name for herself in France
2. This bronze sculpture decorated the interior of the Opra, constructed by architect Garnier in the 1860s and 70s during the Haussmannization of Paris (turning the city from a narrow medieval city into a modern metropolis with broad boulevards and straight avenues)
3. Erected during the Second Empire, reign of Napoleon III: gilded age ruled by optimism and wealth, with a prosperous bourgeoisie that had the time for leisure and cultural activities
4. The sculpture shows an ancient Greek prophetess at Apollos sanctuary, bent over to receive a divine message (religious rapture was seen as analogous to artistic inspiration)
5. It is an idealized figure, conforming to the Classicist formulas of academic sculpture rather than a Realism that was beginning to gain ground at the time (compare the scandalous realism of Carpeauxs sculpture The Dance on the faade of the Opra, showing plump real-life bodies with drunken smiles); in the case of the Sybil, the function of public art is still to edify and instruct
6. Marcello made a cast of her own shoulders and left hand to model the figure
7. The sculpture was installed at the Opra in 1875
William H. Barlow, with Midland Grand Hotel, Sir George G. Scott, St. Pancras Station, London 1868-74

Victorian architecture
  1. The station was designed by Barlow, a utilitarian iron and glass shed, a feat of engineering, and the adjoining Gothic style hotel of brick and masonry designed by Scott. Instead of integrating the two contrasting structures, Scott maintained a duality that has been criticized by architectural historians
  2. At St. Pancras we see two things: In the shed, the highest flight in Victorian engineering . . . in the hotel, the most emphatic and uncompromising application of Gothic Revivalism to a secular purpose (Summerson 1970, 38).
  3. The project was commissioned by the Midland Railway to expand its regional system. Scott won the design competition in 1866 in his design for a Gothic architecture relevantly adapted to the modern 19th century city, establishing the hotel as effectively a new city gate.  
  4. Scotts design for the Midland Grand Hotel at St. Pancras embodies the contradiction between up-to-date engineering and an architecture predicated on revivalism. The design looks to medieval German and Flemish precedents for a hotel that sat on a railroad hub, epitomizing the astounding expansion of mechanized transportation and commercial culture in the Victorian era. It was also equipped with the most advanced ventilation and heating system.
  5. Scott was a disciple of Augustus Pugin, who moralistically advocated for the application of Gothic architecture to the 19th century city to denounce social ills concomitant with industrialism. As such, Scott kept at a distance such an emblem of modern technology as the arched shed, built of iron and glass. The exuberant Gothic forms of his hotel seem to respond with a commensurate level of historical virtuosity to the technological mastery embodied in the engineering of the shed.

Frdric Bazille, Summer Scene, 1869
Fogg Art Museum, Cambridge, Massachusetts

Impressionist
1.     Considered as Bazilles final masterpiece; was exhibited at the Salon of 1870. In some ways, the work conformed to the standards of the academy: the degree to which it is finished and the way in which it is evocative of the traditional formula for classical symmetrical landscapes; follows the long-standing tradition of studying the male nude. 
2.     However, it subverts the tradition in that scenes of outdoor bathers typically featured female nudes. A large-scale painting of nude of mostly nude male bather was unprecedented. The square shape of the canvas also differs from the standard format for landscapes that were horizontal and figurative works that were vertical: hybrid of two genres, therefore radical in its departure from convention.
3.     The ideological construction of women as embedded in nature encouraged the creation of images of females nudes in nature, which crowded the Salon of the early Third Republic. By contrast, image of the contemporary men here stripped of the uniform masculinity which inscribed them in the realm of culture made them seem vulnerable and unheroic. Whilst the nakedness of modern women could appear natural, subsuming them into the mythic category of femininity for which they became a sign, that of men seemed odd, embarrassing, strangely anachronistic. (Garb 1996) 
4.     The painting reveals in a contradictory way the legal reality of the period: an 1835 law forbade nude bathing in public; men could do so in bathing suits but women were forbidden that allowance and required to bath in a single-sex, indoor facility.
5.     Follows in the tradition of Caillebotte and Courbets trends of painting the male nude set in a modern context. Sources for the male figures include figure groups by the Renaissance artists, Sebastiano del Piombo and Andrea Mantegna. Depicts a group of young men clad in bathing suits either swimming, reclining in the sun or wrestling.

Claude Monet, La Grenouillre, (The Frog Pond), 1869
Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

Impressionism
  1. During summer of 1869, Monet and Renoir went to La Grenouillre, a popular bathing place on the Seine not far from Paris, to paint side by side. This composition closely resembles Renoir's in the Nationalmuseum, Stockholm (see next slide).
  2. Monet did three loosely painted sketches that summer, quickly capturing the essence of each figures appearance with plans to make a larger painting intended for 1870 Salon, which never materialized. Personal and political events stopped him, as he fled to London during the Franco-Prussian war to escape being drafted.  In London, Turner's bold brushwork may have led him to question the Academy's boundary between a sketch and a finished painting. Monet chose to exhibit this work as a painting in the first Impressionist exhibition in 1874, when he decided to eliminate the distinction.
  3. For Monet it was an opportunity to explore his interest in atmospheric water effects, in reflections of sunlight on water and is a close study of human interactions.
  4. The figures on round island in center, known as "Le Camembert, are dressed in long black bathing suits, top-hatted men in white pants and women in crinoline long skirts, revealing how all classes mixed.
  5. The work is recognized for its modernity, embodied in its rejection of established styles, and demonstrates the techniques Impressionists adopted: short, broken brushstrokes, pure unblended colors, an emphasis on the effects of light, shadows and highlights rendered in color (not grays). This seemingly casual style became the new language to depict modern life.
  6. Impressionism focused on nature and the leisure life of the bourgeoisie and maintained landscapes must be painted outdoors. Boating and bathing establishments were favorite motifs.

PierreAuguste Renoir, La Grenouillre, 1869
Nationalmuseum, Stockholm

Impressionism
  1. Auguste Renoir (1841-1919) was one of the leading painters of the Impressionist style along with Claude Monet. He made his breakthrough at the Impressionists first exhibition in Paris in 1874. 
  2. In 1869 he and Monet painted together at La Grenouillre, a bathing spot on the Seine, and in Argenteuil. The two painted en plein air and recorded the busy outdoor retreat and people wearing the clothing of modern life. 
  3. The impressionists rapid, sketchy way of painting their desire to portray their impressions directly on the canvas was something new. They were breaking with tradition. The subject chosen was also new. They portrayed modernity, la vie moderne, with its commercial and public life. They were flneurs, men who wandered randomly about the city observing it. La Grenouillere was a popular bathing place on the Seine. These are not aristocrats, they are the people of Paris. 
  4. Plein-Air painting was usually used as a sketch for the painting of a landscape, but both Monet and Renoir painted these as sketches but later displayed them as finished works. Tried to capture the light and color in its fleeting impression in order to paint a finished work later. Impressionists would later use this technique to paint finished works. 
  5. Using paints directly from the tube. Industrialization makes this possible.
John Augustus Roebling, Brooklyn Bridge, New York, 18691883

American Industrial Architecture
  1. Roebling (born Rbling, German, 1806-69) studied architecture, dyke and bridge construction, hydraulics, and engineering at the Bauakademie in Berlin. Also studied with Hegel, and developed an interest in philosophy. 
  2. Emigrated to US at 25, and began constructing suspension bridges in 1844. He developed a method for stranding and weaving wire cables, more durable than the hemp usually used for suspension bridges at the time. (He ultimately founded his own factory in Trenton to keep up with rising demand for the new cables.)
  3. Completed 12 structures 1844-69, including suspension bridges in Pittsburgh and at Niagara Falls.
  4. Roeblings design for a bridge connecting Brooklyn and Manhattan was accepted in 1867, and he was appointed chief engineer of the project. It would be the first steel suspension bridge, with the longest span in the world: 1,1595 feet from tower to tower. Tallest structure in the world for several years after completion. 
  5. The two-tier design included cable car transportation as well as roadways for vehicles and an elevated pedestrian promenade. 
  6. Brooklyn Bridge is supported by deep foundations (44 on Brooklyn side, 78 on manhattan side) dug using caissons: massive wooden boxes, which provided dry underwater space for workers to use shovels and dynamite to clear away the mud and boulders at the bottom of the river. When they had dug deep enough, they backfilled the caissons with poured concrete and brick piers. Workers would often suffer from the bends on their way back to the surface. 
  7. In 1869, just before construction began, Roeblings foot was crushed in a ferry accident, and he died from tetanus two weeks later. His son and later his daughter-in-law Emily took over the construction management; she was the first to cross the bridge in 1883.

Ilya Repin, Barge Haulers on the Volga, 187073
Russian Museum, St. Petersburg

Russian Realism / The Wanderers
1. Repin was a leading figure in the Wanderers (Peredvizhniki), an anti-academic movement and anti-Romantic movement (like Realists or Pre-Raphaelites), bypassing the official exhibitions by sending traveling shows around the country for the society at large (insisted on the importance of art as a source of social reform)
2. Repin submitted this painting, a strikingly non-academic work, to make his debut at the Academy before joining the group of the Wanderers
3. Its subject matter is squarely realist: showing ten men towing a barge on the shore of the Volga, it is an image both of suffering of the underclass and one of their strength and dignity (painted ten years after serfdom had been abolished in Russia)
4. Unlike the French Realists (Courbet or Millet), Repin does not de-individualize his subjects to show the de-humanizing effects of labor; instead he paints ten individual portraits, showing the psychological effects of labor on the haulers (rebellion, indifference, fatigue)
5. The painting was admired by Dostoyevsky at the St Petersburg Academy Exhibition in 1873, who shared Repins personal sense of responsibility for the poor
6. Repin was one of the artists exhibited in the International Exposition of 1889 in Paris, where the work of the Russians was not particularly well-received (dominated by the more conservative artists)
7. The Wanderers would become an important artistic predecessor for the Socialist Realists of the early 20th century (representing a distinctly Russian realist lineage as opposed to the foreign Western styles of the French Realists or Impressionists)

Gustave Dor, Holland House, A Garden Party
Illustration in Blanchard Jerrold, London: A Pilgrimage, 1872

Victorian
  1. In 1869 British journalist Blanchard Jerrold (18261884) joined forces with the famous French artist Gustave Dor (18321883) to produce an illustrated record of the shadows and sunlight of London in London: A Pilgrimage.
  2. The book and illustrations commented on the vast economic divide that plagued Victorian Britain. While the middle and upper class experienced significant luxury, the peasant class existed on the brink of starvation. During the 1830s and 40s, a small group of journalists, politicians and intellectuals spoke up against this massive class divide.
  3. In this image, Dor illustrates an upper-class gathering in a garden in London. In the accompanying image, Orange Court, Drury Lane, Dor depicts a London slum with people dressed in rags huddled together along a narrow alleyway, with no trees nor sky in sight. The disparity between these two groups is emphasized not only in the figures themselves, but in the way that Dor represents their environments, While the figures at Holland House are crowded together, they gather comfortably, surrounded by greenery. Dors use of the vanishing point in both images also alludes to the divergent futures of each group a magnificent illuminated estate versus the unseen end of a dark, shadowed alleyway
  4. Around the time the article and images were published, change was finally enacted in a series of legislations the Factory Act of 1878 restricted the work week to 56 hours, while other acts worked to improve housing, public hygiene and education.  
  5. Contemporary critics had severe reservations about the book. Dor disliked sketching in public so there were many errors of detail; it showed only the extremes of society, and Jerrolds text was superficial. Both were transfixed by the deprivation, squalor and wretchedness of the lives of the poor, even though they realised that London was changing and some of the worst social evils were beginning to be addressed. Despite these criticisms, Dors work has become celebrated for its dramatic use of light and shade, and the power of his images to capture the atmosphere of mid-Victorian London.
Claude Monet, Impression: Sunrise, 1872

Impressionism
1.    During the 1870s and 1880s, there were artists initiatives that aimed at organizing private and group shows in rented spaces. Impression was exhibited in one such exhibition, in the photographer Nadars studio. The title of this painting led to the title a review of the show class The Exhibition of Impressionists by Louis Leroy in Le Charivari, making this painting the target of all the resentment Leroy felt towards the exhibition. 
2.    His use of the term impressionists was used to criticise artists whose work he felt was an attack on proper artistic custom, on the culture of form, and the respect for the masters. These paintings were considered unfinished for their sketch like quality. 
3.    In 1872, Monet visited Le Havre during which he completed a series of six paintings featuring the Port of Le Havre at various times of the day. This image representing sunrise is seen through a mist that provides a hazy background to the French harbour (aim was not to create an accurate landscape, but to record impressions formed while looking at the view)
4.    Despite its notoriety, the painting is in some ways atypical of Monets work of this period and of the impressionism movement. The colors are restrained and the paint is applied not in discrete brushstrokes but in very thin washes. The painting is strongly atmospheric rather than analytical and has a spirit closer to Turners work. 
5.    Nevertheless, this painting propelled a surge in the Impressionist movement with Monet at the forefront. The artist continued to capture impressions of his surroundings for the remainder of his life.

Berthe Morisot, The Cradle, 1872
Muse dOrsay, Paris

Impressionism
  1. A leading Impressionist, Morisot remains less well-known than her friends Monet, Degas, and Renoir, yet she was immediately recognized as one of the groups most innovative artists.
  2. This is her most famous painting. It shows one of the artist's sisters, Edma (also a painter), watching over her sleeping daughter. It is her first image of motherhood, later one of her favorite subjects. Prior to Morisot, bourgeois mothers were rarely depicted in art.
  3. The mother's gaze, her bent left arm, a mirror image of the child's arm, and the baby's closed eyes form a diagonal line accentuated by the curtain in the background. This diagonal links mother and child. Edma's gesture, drawing the net curtain of the cradle between spectator and baby, reinforces the feeling of intimacy and protective love.
  4. Morisot exhibited regularly in the Salon between 1864-73. The Cradle was exhibited at the first Impressionist exhibition (1874), she was the only woman among thirty artists. Morisot participated in all but one of the eight Impressionist exhibitions (1874-1886). She missed the fourth exhibition in 1879 due to the birth of her daughter Julie Manet (1878-1966). Julie became an artist too.
  5. The Cradle stayed in Edma's family until it entered the Louvre in 1930.
  6. Morisot favored painting her entourage and womens domestic work, her daughter, sister, maids, and wet nurses, were her favorite models. For her, these portraits captured the scenes of modern life. Linda Nochlin characterized her paintings as stimulating ambiguities, expressed in her models, choice of spaces, and her bold and energetic technique, which is allusive rather than descriptive, constantly blurring the borders between interior and exterior, private and public, finished and unfinished.
  7. She believed painting should capture something that passes. Her modern subjects, loose touch, and rapid execution show how she tirelessly tackled the ephemeral.

Jean-Lon Grome, Prayer in the Mosque, c. 1872
Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

Second-Empire Orientalism
  1. Jean-Leon Gerome (1824-1904) was an academic painter who worked in both the Neo-Grec style and on Orientalist subjects. 
  2. Gerome traveled to Turkey, the Near East, and North Africa and painted scenes of life in the places he visited. Prayer in the Mosque was painted after drawings he made in Cairo in 1868 at the mosque of Amr.
  3. Painted in meticulous academic detail, with everything depicted in near-photographic accuracy. Relied on photographs, drawings, travelogues, and reports of colonial administrators to create his scenes. 
  4. Style derived from the harem scenes of Ingres but more focused on the verisimilitude of the scene. 
  5. Paintings were immensely popular and many tried to capitalize on his success.

Adolph Menzel, Iron Rolling Mill, or Modern Cyclops I, 187275
Nationalgalerie, Berlin

German Realism
  1. Began career as a lithographer (inherited fathers business), and studied briefly at Berlin Academy of Art; was otherwise self-taught. In addition to being a painter, was a popular illustrator, largely responsible for the popularization of wood engraving in mid-19th century Germany: reproduced 400 drawings illustrating the life of Frederick the Great. 
  2. Menzel often created historical genre paintings, but later in career was was more interested in scenes from contemporary life. 
  3. Iron Rolling Mill depicts furnace in a factory in Kningschtte, upper Silesia (now Poland), where train rails were produced. Menzel travelled there in 1872 to familiarize himself with work conditions and make hundreds of onsite preparatory sketches. 
  4. Depicts process for creating train rails beginning with puddle ball at left, group of workers rolling iron at center, through workers shaping rail at right. Workers become part of machine through Menzels echoing of forms: diagonal line from their bodies/shoulders continued through the molten iron. 
  5. Rolled metal: process for making thickness uniform. Had been around for centuries - particularly in Middle East and South Asia - but industrial advances in early 1800s allowed for faster production and larger pieces of metal. At The Great Exhibition in 1851, where a plate 20 feet long, 3 feet wide, and 7/16 of an inch thick, and weighing 1,125 pounds, was exhibited by the Consett Iron Company.
  6. Unlike Courbet, does not seem to emphasize the negative aspects of workers conditions. Instead, Menzel seems to be treating this as contemporary heroic history painting - thats certainly the scale at 8 wide and over 5 tall. 
  7. Impressionists looked to Menzel for inspiration. Edgar Degas called him the "the greatest living master," and studied/copied his work.

Camille Pissarro, White Frost, 1873
Muse dOrsay, Paris

Impressionism
1. Camille Pissarro was amongst those who founded the Private Company of Artists together with Monet in 1873. Having had their works rejected or ignored at the state-sponsored Salons, this cooperative hosted a series of eight independent group shows to bypass the conservatism of the Salons in the Third Republic. The first of these was called by a disparaging critic The Exhibition of the Impressionists, taking the name from the title of Monets Impression, Sunrise 1872.
2. Yet Pissarro differs in crucial ways from Monet, both in subject matter and in style: whereas Monet was drawn to water, in White Frost Pissarro depicts a rural scene, a frozen field outside his residence in the village Pontoise.
3. This also explains the different brushwork used by the artists: Monet paints in broad, horizontal strokes to convey the glimmering surface of water while Pissarro uses short, fuzzy dabs to suggest the rough texture of the field
4. Compare to a contemporary academic artist like Bouguereau to understand the radical novelty of the technique: the former negates and dissimulates his own brushwork while the latter purposely calls attention to it (depending on proximity of viewer to painting)
5. Impressionists painted their canvases in plein-air (facilitated by invention of paint in tubes); from the 1850s the painters of the Barbizon school had sketched in plein-air, but only as a preparation for the final painting in the study; the Impressionists eliminated the distinction between sketch and finished painting (to capture the immediacy and fleetingness of their visual sensation)
6. This allowed Pissarro to masterfully convey the effects of light and atmosphere: blue shadows cast by an invisible row of poplars suggest the clear light of a cold winter morning
Timothy OSullivan, Ancient Ruins in the Canyon de Chelle, 1873

Early photography / Romanticism
  1. OSullivan is well known for his photographs of death and carnage on Civil War battlefields, particularly in the aftermath of Gettysburg. In 1867, he later accompanied several expeditions across the US and Central America, documenting the landscapes he encountered.  
  2. Following the end of the civil war, many Americans sought an escape from the horrible memories of war and took refuge in the natural beauty of the West, and found riches in its mines. As settlers explored further west, Native Americans became a subject of particular fascination to scientists and photographers who sought to record and understand them anthropologically and ethnographically. Thirty years later, Edward Curtis would describe Native Americans as The Vanishing Race, exemplifying the way that native peoples and their homes were represented by these photographers disintegrating, abandoned, disappearing.
  3. As part of the Wheeler Expedition of 1873-5, OSullivan explored and photographed the landscape of Arizona and New Mexico, during which this image was taken. The expedition sought to document the native population, select sites for future military bases and railways, and assess the natural resources. He was among the first non-Native American to explore this area of northern Arizona which had been inhabited by Anasazi and Navajo populations for 5,000 years.
  4. With an eye for vivid contrasts, enormous scale and extraordinary features of the west, he captures the canyons the dynamic geological violence that dwarfs the abandoned Pueblo dwellings.
  5. The scientific objective of the expedition is evident in the methodical, front-on and vertical framing of the image. Upon close inspection, one can see two figures standing on one of the structures, demonstrating the vast scale of the cavern as well as creating a sense of vulnerability and humility in the viewer. While the image was originally intended as merely one of a collection of topographical records, the image was quickly adopted into the realm of fine art, admired for its abstraction of textures.
Thomas Eakins, The Gross Clinic, 1875

American- Scientific Realism
1.     Admired for its uncompromising realism, this work has an important place in documenting the history of medicine as it honors the emergence of surgery as a healing profession: surgery was associated primarily with amputation often resulting in infection or death.
2.     Depicts famous surgeon and teacher Samuel Gross leading a clinic of five doctors operating on the left thigh of a patient. Gross is show demonstrating a relatively new surgical procedure he had developed to treat bone infections. 
3.     Eakins deep connection to his birthplace of Philadelphia remained a theme throughout his career. This work was completed for the Centennial Exhibition in Philadelphia but was rejected by the Committee of Selection, and criticised for its gruesome subject matter, seemingly vulgar treatment and inherent melodrama (swooning, hysterical woman on the left)
4.     Evokes Rembrandts art historical precedent, The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Tulp (1632), but unlike Rembrandts painting, the focus of this work are the living figures. Known for his portraiture, Eakins calculated the work as a visual record of all the individuals present in the medical amphitheatre. Not solely a portrait of Dr. Gross and his students, Eakins inserts himself as a witness in the audience. The lighting and composition however still place all focus on the portrait of Dr. Gross.
5.     Through his master of rendering volume, individualistic features and psychological intensity, Eakins showcases his academic training in a style described as scientific realism; was obsessed with accuracy and known to project photographs onto canvases in order to laboriously trace figures and shift objects for a more harmoniously composed scene.

Gustave Caillebotte, Floor Scrapers, 1875
Muse dOrsay, Paris

Realism/Impressionism
