  5. Lithographed posters proliferated starting in the 1870s due to technical advances in scale and color printing and the relaxation of laws restricting the placement of posters. It is estimated that 1,000 to 3,000 prints of this image were displayed around Paris.
  6. It was shown at The Armory Show, which marked the first public exhibition of Toulouse-Lautrecs paintings in the United States, although some prints had been exhibited at Alfred Stieglitzs 291 gallery in 1909 and 1910.

Victor Horta, Staircase in the Tassel Residence, 189293,
Brussels

Belgian Art Nouveau
  1. If any architect might claim to be the founder of Art Nouveau architecture, it is the Belgian Victor Horta (18611947). Trained as an academician, he was inspired by Baroque and Rococo concepts of linear movement in space, by his study of plant growth and of Viollet-le-Ducs structural theories, and by the engineer Gustave Eiffel, designer of the Eiffel tower, which used metal construction. 
  2. Horta fuses the twin themes of nature and industry almost seamlessly. Undulating organic curves made possible by industry. Art nouveau is a style without historical precedent, making it an early modern style. 
  3. The heart of the building is this central stair hall, almost a foregone conclusion given the narrow urban lots that Horta was dealt for these commissions. Here, the emphasis is on structure, which Horta makes frankly clear in the green iron columns that anchor the space.
  4. The stair hall is plainly visible on the exterior, with a riveted green iron I-beam serving as its foundation above the recessed main entrance before blossoming into a luminous set of stained glass windows containing the blues of water and pinks of flowering plants. Brings the outside in with the natural motifs and makes the inside visible to the outside world. 
  5. Art historian Deborah L. Sliverman (Silverman, 2011) connected the vine style of Belgian art nouveau with images of conquest in the Belgian Congo. She now considers art nouveau the Congo Style inspired by the rubber tree plant and whips. She re-classifies art nouveau as imperial modernism.

Richard Morris Hunt; McKim, Mead & White; Burnham and Root, et al.
Worlds Columbian Exposition, Chicago, 1893

American Neoclassical
  1. The 1893 Columbian Exposition in Chicago - also called the Worlds Fair - was a celebration of the centennial of Columbus voyage to the Americas. Like the 1889 Exposition in France, it provided a showcase for the countrys power and values. Also served to mark citys recovery from the Great Chicago Fire of 1871, when many of the citys buildings burned. 
  2. Famed landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted was invited to create the plan for the fair. He chose Jackson Park on the shore of Lake Michigan, and designed a spectacular seascape rather than a landscape. The site was 4x larger than the 1893 fair in Paris.
  3. Architect Daniel Burnham of Burnham and Root, the chief of construction for the fair, suggested that the greatest American architects of the time contribute designs for the buildings. The contributors included Richard Morris Hunt (faade of the Metropolitan Museum, New York, and base for the Statue of Liberty), Charles McKim (New York Public Library), and Louis Sullivan (Auditorium Building and Wainwright Building), among others. 
  4. Neoclassical buildings following Beaux-Arts principles of design (symmetry, balance, splendour) stood around the Grand Basin, seen here. Designed Hunt and McKim, Mead & White, among others (not Sullivan), this portion of the exposition was called the Court of Honor. The buildings in the Court of Honor were covered in white stucco (hence the nickname The White City) and had a uniform cornice height of 60 feet and the consistent use of bays 25 feet wide. (A number of the architects hated the Neoclassical style of these buildings, but it would influence American architecture for decades.) 
  5. Like the Eiffel Tower, the buildings were intended to be temporary. 
  6. The Court of Honor's gleaming buildings were exhibition halls, housing many inventions and appliances powered by electricity (including an electric sidewalk, an early fax machine that sent pictures via phone lines, and electric irons).
  7. Augustus Saint-Gaudens oversaw the decorative program of the fair as its artistic director. Included works by Impressionist Mary Cassatt and Daniel Chester French, who created the gilded-bronze statue The Republic seen at the center of the Grand Basin here. (French later created the statue of Lincoln for that president's memorial). Saint-Gaudens compared the group of artists and architects to the Italian Renaissance geniuses who built Florence. "Look here, old fellow," he said to Burnham, "do you realize that this is the greatest meeting of artists since the fifteenth century!"
Henry Ossawa Tanner, The Banjo Lesson, 1893

American Naturalism / Symbolism
1. Tanner is the first African-American artist to achieve international renown, son of a former slave and minister, trained at Philadelphia Academy under Thomas Eakins, went to Paris to study at Acadmie Julian (with Grme). Exposed to both the tradition of American Realism and to French Academic painting; frequently associated with the mysterious imagery of contemporary Symbolists (moved in circles of Paul Gaugin)
2. Exhibited widely at Paris Salons and received the prestigious Lgion dhonneur
3. Became well-known for his biblical paintings, but Banjo Lesson is most famous work: renowned for its nuanced orchestration of light and shadow, emotional delicacy, symbolism, spiritual stillness
4. Painting made after illustrations in Harpers Young People magazine accompanied by short story of an old man giving his banjo to his grandson on Christmas morning
5. Painted after visiting Blue Ridge Mountains in North Carolina while recovering from typhoid in the United States, where he witnessed the poverty of African-Americans in Appalachia
6. Slavery was abolished 24 years before (1865) and had left deep scars in community; Tanner was from bourgeoning African-American intelligentsia but haunted by the legacy of slavery
7. Influence of Courbet depictions of the rural poor and Millets theme of spiritual solace (see Angelus 1857): highlighting the dignity and grace of poverty-stricken African-Americans, departs from popular images of overly servile and jolly Uncle Tom figures
8. Vision of resilience, spiritual grace and creative and intellectual promise of post-Civil War African-Americans
9. Set a log cabin with hearth fire illuminating the two figures; counterpoint between age and experience versus youth and promise of achievement (glimmer of light on boys forehead): the success of future generations is built on the legacy of previous ones; from oppression, racism, poverty to education, advancement, new beginnings
10.  Banjo is integral to slave music and music of American South; banjo here is not entertainment for a white audience but stands for the passing on of tradition
Aubrey Beardsley, Salome with the Head of John the Baptist, 1893

Decadent/Aesthetic Movement
  1. Beardsley (British 1872-1898) was an illustrator who created this series of drawings in response to Oscar Wildes Salom published in 1893. First published in 1894, The Climax consists of strong, precise lines, decorative motifs characteristic of the developing Art Nouveau style, and the use of only black ink.
  2. Wilde seems to have been ambivalent about Beardsleys stunning designs, which not only foregrounded the erotic almost to the point of obscenity, but also incorporated visual references to Wilde himself, seeming to attribute dubious voyeuristic motivations to the plays creator.
  3. Beardsley's style was influenced by Japanese woodcuts also known as Ukiyo-e, which comes through in the flatness of imagery, compositional arrangement, and the stylistic motifs.
  4. Beardsley satirized Victorian values regarding sex, that at the time highly valued respectability, and men's fear of female superiority, as the women's movement made gains in economic rights and occupational and educational opportunities by the 1880s. Salome's power over men can be seen in the way that Beardsley presents her as a monster-like figure, reminiscent of Medusa.
  5. As Wilde must have been aware, even before Beardsleys illustrations, Salom would inevitably attract the label decadent. He may have even welcomed the appellation because he was able to view decadence not simply as a pleasurable, if risky, way of life, but as a necessary precondition for a cultural renaissance. In this respect, decadence was a natural follow-on from the more obviously high-minded Aestheticism that Wilde (and Beardsley) had advocated in the early 1880s.
Jules Chret, Loie Fuller at the Folies Bergre, 1893

Art Nouveau Posters

1.     The sudden development of picture posters in the 1870s was the result of a number of factors: the constantly increasing manufacture of consumer products made advertising necessary. Producers became dissatisfied with small texts posters used as advertisements and sought a more attractive, pictorial mode of advertising, enabled by the lithographed color poster. 
2.     By the late 1870s, the lithographic process had been refined to print images in multiple colors. In addition, large presses had been developed that made it possible to print on sizeable paper. Initially, posters were covered walls of urban buildings, but were eventually considered a uniquely modern phenomenon that poster exhibitions were held across France and posters became a collectors item. Posters made to advertise theatrical or musical performances, such as those by Jules Chret were made specifically for galleries or collectors. 
3.     This poster for a performance at Folies Bergre is about the image and contains minimal text. It shows the famous American Dancer Loe Fuller in one of her popular serpentine dances, dressed in billowing folds of silk that she whirled around in. Chrets posters are marked by large blocks of color (reduction of number of shades was inherent to the print medium) which was effective for poster art, meant to be seen from a distance.
4.     His subject matter focused on modestly free-spirited women, giving him the title of father of the womens liberation. Women had previously been depicted in art as prostitutes or puritans. The women of Chrets posters were neither depicted as joyous, elegant and lively Cherettes as they were popularly called. It was freeing for the women of Paris, and heralded a more open atmosphere in Paris were women were able to engage in formerly taboo activities such as wearing low-cut bodices and smoking in public.
5.     Chrets works were influenced by scenes of frivolity depicted in the works of Rococo artists like Fragonard. His success inspired the emergence of a new generation of poster designers and painters such as Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec.
Paul Czanne, Still Life with Basket of Apples, c.1893

Post-Impressionism
  1. Czanne was a Post-Impressionist painter hailed as the "father of modern painting." His work formed the bridge between late 19C Impressionism and early 20C Cubism, even though recognition came late as he worked primarily in his native Provence; had little public success and was repeatedly rejected by the Salon.
  2. Optics fascinated Czanne. He explored the non-mimetic possibilities of what painting could be, never aiming for mere illusionism. Painting from nature is not copying the object, he wrote, it is realizing ones sensations. This painting, one of Czannes rare signed works, reflects this as well as his fascination with color, light, pictorial space, and how we see. It shows how he concentrated on the visual and physical qualities of the paint and worked to capture the full complexity of how our eyes take in the sights before us.
  3. Czanne realized that unlike the Renaissance's simple single-point perspective and static vision of space, people see in a fashion that is more complex, through both time and space, so he broke away from many of the illusionistic techniques he had inherited from the Old Masters. This was partly due to photography's impact and its transformation of modern representation.
  4. His deep study of geometry in painting led to his rendering of multiple perspectives simultaneously of the same object to provide viewers with an aesthetic experience that conveyed the subjectivity of time, space, and seeing, which brought about the end of copying nature.
  5. Here, his perspective seems jumbled with no sense of gravity, as seen in his signature tilted table where the fruit seems about to roll off; a basket of apples that pitches forward; some of the apple's edges, which look undefined, almost shifting; the tipsy bottle; the eclairs that are seen from the side and top simultaneously, and in the non-aligned sides of the table. Czanne left some areas of canvas bare, others, like the bunched tablecloth, appear unfinished. The heavy modeling and solid brushstrokes give the composition a density, depth, and dynamism that a more realistic still life could not possess.
  6. He applied the paint in small modulated units of color, used layers of color to build up surfaces, and outlined his forms for emphasis.
  7. Still life was so neglected then, seen as decorative and trivial, that it was freed of virtually all conventions, which appealed to Cezanne, offering him a blank slate and the opportunity to invent meaning unfettered by tradition.
  8. He almost single-handedly revived still life, making it an important subject for Picasso, Matisse, and others, while his concern with representing the true experience of sight had enormous implications for 20th century visual culture.
Fun fact: In one of Meyer Schapiros most exhilarating essays (1968), he turned to psychoanalysis to explore the erotic roots of Cezanne's obsessively reiterated choice of apples - rounded, luscious - linked in popular speech and classical mythology to physical love.
Alphonse Mucha, Sarah Bernhardt (published in La Plume), 1896

Art Nouveau
  1. Alphonse Mucha (18601939), a Czech artist who encountered Art Nouveau style during his study in Paris in the late 1880s, adopted the new style for his early graphic works. Attracted to ephemeral media such as product packaging and posters as much for the opportunity to produce works rapidly for a guaranteed audience as for commercial advantage. 
  2. Mucha employed the sinewy, flowing lines and broad areas of saturated color typical of the art nouveau movement.
  3. At the end of 1894 his career took a dramatic and unexpected turn when he began to work for French stage actress Sarah Bernhardt, who he worked with throughout her career. Mucha designed posters for each successive Bernhardt play, beginning with a reprise of one of her early great successes, La Dame aux Camelias (September 1896), followed by Lorenzaccio (1896); Medea (1898); La Tosca (1898) and Hamlet (1899). He sometimes worked from photographs of Bernhardt. In addition to posters, he designed theatrical programs, sets, costumes, and jewelry for Bernhardt. She set aside some from each run to sell to collectors because they were so sought after, 
  4. The posters were a huge success in Paris and earned Mucha a reputation, he later designed for JOB cigarette papers and other posters.
  5. His art nouveau style often featured women with long hair curling in arabesque shapes and the organic, undulating shapes and lines associated with the popular style. He also incorporated it into the lettering of the posters.

Fernand Khnopff, Caresses, 1896
Muses Royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique, Brussels

Neo-Romantic
  1. Rose + Croix Salon (1892-7) organizer Josphin Phladan was a self-styled prophet in the Rosicrucian tradition: abhorred materialism and saw art as an initiatory rite to religious revelation. 
  2. Khnopff (Belgian, 1858-1921) was among Phladans favorite artists. He painted society portraits as well as more mythological and occult scenes. He was influenced by the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, and co-founded the group Les XX in 1883 in Brussels and exhibited with them regularly.
  3. Like other Neo-Romantic artists, Khnopff made works that were conservative stylistically: in contrast with painters like Delacroix, Khnopffs style was was more like Academic painting. Influenced by Ingres in particular. 
  4. Khnopff and others of this Neo-Romantic circle were also conservative socially, particularly in their views of women (white women in particular were gaining increasing rights at the time).  Women were often depicted as new women or femme fatales, like the sphynx here. Womens seduction as a force for mans downfall. 
  5. This oil-on-canvas painting follows in the tradition of Romantic artists in depicting scenes from mythology, like Oedipus answering of riddles by the sphynx. Far from appearing like a paragon of intellect, as he does in myth and in paintings by artists like Ingres, Khnopffs Oedipus appears to be seduced by the sphynx. 
  6. In 1898, he exhibited 20 works at the first Vienna Secession exhibition. He would influence Gustav Klimt in particular (he was sometimes called the painter of closed eyelids.

Joaquin Sorolla y Bastida, Sewing the Sail, 1896
Galleria Internazionale dArte Moderna Di CaPesaro, Venice

Spanish Naturalism
1. This is an example of the type of plein-air Naturalism that was the dominant trend at the International Exposition in Paris in 1900: a flamboyant and light-filled Naturalism that was touched by Impressionism, yet that clung to the accurate representation of reality, countering the avant-garde trend towards abstraction (compare to the style of his contemporary John Singer Sargent)
2. None of the modernist trends were included in the 1900 International Exposition: barely any Impressionists and none of the Post-Impressionists (speaks to the extreme distance between the fashionable and the avant-garde in 1900)
3. Sewing the Sail exemplifies the extent to which the Naturalists had learned from the innovations of the Impressionists: sails folds reflect the play of light and shadow, transforming a lumpy canvas into a shimmering mass (the sail could be read as an allegory for the picture canvas) (see Renoirs Ball at the Moulin de la Galette 1876 for Impressionisms rendering of the play of light and shadow)
4. Sorolla y Bastida won the first-class medal at the International Exposition
5. Sorolla y Bastida was a Spanish artist born in Valencia, became internationally established in his 20s, solo exhibition in NYC in 1909, commission for panels about different regions of Spain for Hispanic Society in NYC in 1911; known for his beach scenes, sunlit water, representation of people and landscapes under the Spanish sun
Paul Gauguin, Where Do We Come From? Where Are We? Where Are We Going?, 1897

Symbolism
  1. Sought to experience pre-colonial Tahiti, and gradually rid his representations of the colonial presence throughout the island, depicting instead an idealized, primitive vision in his paintings, a sort of earthly Eden.
  2. This painting depicts the cycle of life from birth (represented on the far right) to the daily existence of adulthood (in center) to a reconciliation with death (woman on far left). The painting was intended to be read from right to left as in a sacred scroll. He compared this work, which he considered to be his magnum opus, to the Gospels.
  3. He juxtaposed the physical and spiritual worlds in the same canvas, imagining the spiritual either in the form of the buddha, or as abstract color patterns that played a musical role, characteristic of Symbolism. This work in particular served as a visual articulation of the artists philosophy of human life and civilization.
  4. He compared the work to the allegorical murals of Puvis de Chavannes but stressed the unpolished nature of his own work as a sign of superiority. His work spoke of energy, passion and suffering in contrast to Puviss the carefully staged compositions. He makes further reference to Puviss murals in the top two golden corners which are meant to evoke a fresco where the corners are spoiled with age.
  5. Furthermore, while Puvis had used standard, trite allegorical imagery, Gauguin advocated for the development of a personal symbolism less easily understood but more imaginative and poetic. Observation of reality was no longer a point of departure for Gauguin.
Auguste Rodin, Monument to Balzac, 1898

French Fin-de-sicle sculpture
1.     Rodin has been considered a symbolist for his later works, in their attempt to express the spiritual. This sculpture was similarly designed as a visual metaphor for Balzacs energy and genius. His ultimate aim was less Balzacs physical likeness than an idea or spirit of the man and a sense of his creative vitality.
2.     Commissioned by a French literary society to honour Honor de Balzac, one of Frances greatest novelists, known for his novels grouped as La Comdie Humaine (human comedy) in which he tried to record all the tragic and comedic aspects of human life in his own time.
3.     Rodin spent seven years preparing for the sculpture, studying the writers life and work, posing models that resembled him and ordering clothes to his measurement. He became infatuated with the personality of Balzac, and travelled numerous times to the authors hometown of Touraine. 
4.     Several studies that were created are nudes, but Rodin finally decided to represent the writer in a monks robe, inspired by the dressing gown Balzac was known to have worn while writing. The shrouded figure is understood to be symbolic of the authors imposing genius; the goal was to create a monolithic, upward thrusting form that would be both majestic and realistic. Rodin once said that his aim was to show a Balzac in his study, breathless, hair in disorder, eyes lost in a dream.
5.     The work provoked harsh criticism upon its debut for its amorphous form. The literary society that commissioned it dismissed it as a crude sketch, and refused to accept a work that broke with all the traditional conventions for a commemorative monument and the requirement for a realistic portrait. Rodin retired the plaster model to his home in the Paris suburbs, returned the money and refused all offers to buy it. It was not cast in bronze until many years after his death.
Pierre Bonnard, Promenade of the Nursemaids, Frieze of Fiacres, 1897

Post-Impressionism
  1. Bonnard was a Post-Impressionist painter, illustrator, and printmaker, known for the stylized decorative qualities of his paintings and his bold use of color. He was a founding member of the Nabis, and was strongly influenced by Gauguin, Hokusai, and other Japanese artists. His backgrounds, colors, and painting style usually took precedence over his subjects.
  2. There was a growing demand for decorative screens in Paris in the 1890s, partly because of the popularity of Japanese art and traditional objects. This folding screen is made up of four lithographs, based on a previously painted screen (private collection). Three years later, Bonnard decided to transcribe it into five-color lithographs, published and sold as separate sheets, or mounted on a screen. The work thus became an object of everyday use, going back to one of the major preoccupations of the Nabis: to bring art into domestic life.
  3. Bonnards enthusiasm for Japanese woodblock prints is evident in the tilted perspective, silhouetted forms, simplified use of color (brown, black, blue, yellow and red), the empty space, the deployment of incidents from top to bottom down each panel, and the flattening of the three nannies billowing cloaks. As in Japanese screens, the action is read from right to left.
  4. The stylized forms and innovative composition show Bonnard at his most Japoniste and decorative, but he made it his own by including a fashionably dressed Parisienne, the woman closest to the viewer, tending three children playing with two hoops, two dogs and a ball, situated below a frieze of horse carriages near Place de la Concorde. The stillness of the three nannies, who stand lined up beside a stone balustrade echoing the linearity of the carriages, enhances the sense of movement conveyed by the boys' legs.
  5. Lithographs of this size were something of a technical marvel at the time.  In a letter to his mother, Bonnard referred to this screen as the eighth wonder of the world.
Edouard Vuillard, Woman in Blue with Child, 1899

Nabis
  1. Les Nabis were a group of post-impressionist French painters active from 18881900 whose work is characterised by flat patches of colour, bold contours and simplified drawing. Nabis comes from the Hebrew word for prophet. The term Les Nabis was coined by the poet Henri Cazalis who drew a parallel between the way the group of painters aimed to revitalize painting (as prophets of modern art) and the way the ancient prophets had rejuvenated Israel.
  2. Nabis believed that painting was foremost a harmonious assembly of lines and color. It was precisely in the way that these were arranged that the personality of the painter could come through. 
  3. Woman in Blue focuses all the attention on pattern. Everything in the picture has its own bold pattern from the couch to the dress she wears underneath her blue dressing gown. 
  4. The overlapping patterns creates an almost collage-like cacophony. It takes a while to decipher the scene because depth of the scene is sacrificed in favor of emphasis on sensuous pattern. 
  5. The duality of the life of a woman at the turn of the century. Surrounded by a tasteful interior that becomes claustrophobic in this scene. (Think of Gilmans 1892 The Yellow Wallpaper, an eerie American short story about confinement and postpartum depression that focuses on the bourgeois interior and wallpaper as a site of trauma)
  6. Vuillard and Bonnard are called intimistes, artists interested in the private scenes of daily life.

Henri Van de Velde, Poster for a food concentrate
manufactured by Tropon, 1899

Art Nouveau
  1. In France, Belgium, and Spain, Art Nouveau = irregular curves, often derived from organic forms. Linked art + design with painting and sculpture (many artists of the period were designers as well as painters, for example). In painting and sculpture, Art Nouveau is often linked with Symbolism. 
  2. In this lithograph, Henri Van de Velde (then the director of advertising and graphic design for Tropon) used the fashionable, highly stylized language of Art Nouveau to advertise the firms egg white-based protein extract. (The late nineteenth century witnessed a revolution in industrial-food processing, ultimately transforming the way that people cooked and shopped.) The composition depicts egg whites being separated from yolks.
  3. Van de Velde studied painting in Paris and in Antwerp, where he joined the artists group Les XX (co-founded by Knopff) in 1886. 
  4. He was increasingly influenced by English Arts and Crafts pioneers John Ruskin and William Morris and abandoned painting to pursue design. Like Morris, Van de Velde advocated the idea that all branches of art share a common language of form and are equally important to human existence. He saw ornament not as decoration but as a logical element of the total work and as the result of formal, structural considerations. 
  5. Van de Velde's graphics and packaging for Tropon received the respect and admiration of the graphic design community. This iconic poster was printed in various publications and multiple languages, including German (seen here) and French.
  6. Like Owen Jones, Van de Velde believed that modern design should speak to the needs of the day. In an unpublished manuscript on ornament from 1916-18, Van de Velde argued that line, rather than geometry, was the basic component of all art because it was an instinctive manner of visual description and the creative carrier of human energy. He referred to line as the creative force. 
  7. Van de Velde was a founder of the Deutsche Werkbund (1902-1914)
Edvard Munch, The Dance of Life, 18991900

Symbolism / Berlin Secession
1. This is a scene from a series of 22 paintings called The Frieze of Life, unified by a common landscape and theme (love, sexual anxiety and death), exhibited at the Berlin Secession in 1902
2. The Berlin Secession formed in response to the Society of Berlin Artists closing a retrospective by Munch after only a week; it was led by Max Liebermann
3. Munchs 1902 show was one of the boldest organized by the Berlin Secession; compared to the Vienna Secession, the Berlin Secession was rather conservative: focus on German Naturalism and Impressionism, only few international avant-garde shows
4. Munch is Norwegian, trained in Oslo in a naturalist mode, went to Paris for two years (encountered Post-Impressionists), then worked in Berlin
5. Deeply impacted by the death of his father: specters of sickness and death haunt his entire oeuvre, as well as his personal history of love and rejection
6. Working at the moment when Sigmund Freud was developing his theories about sex, death and woman-as-lack: Munch transforms the red reflection of the moon into a phallic symbol
7. Dance of Life represents the libidinous energy that keeps death at bay; sexuality as a defense against mortality; three women signify the three stages of life: youth and innocence (white), maturity and passion (red), old age and experience (black)
8. Use of simplified forms and flat patches of bold primary color with thick outline similar to the Synthetism of Gaugin or the Cloisonnism of Bernard
9. The use of a sinuous, constantly moving and curving line as well as bold color to express inner emotional states is even more pronounced in Munchs The Scream 1893, which also formed part of the Frieze of Life (has become a symbol of modern anxiety and alienation)
10.  Important precursor of German Expressionism
Louis Comfort Tiffany, Wisteria Table Lamp, c. 1900

American Art Nouveau
  1. Tiffany, son of Charles Tiffany the founder of Tiffany&Co., started as a painter but became interested in glassmaking in 1875 and then switched primarily to design. He opened his own glass factory in Corona, New York determined to provide designs that improved the quality of glass.
  2. Tiffany used opalescent glass in a variety of colors and textures to create a unique style of stained glass. He acquired Stanford Bray's patent for the "copper foil" technique, which, by edging each piece of cut glass in copper foil and soldering the whole together to create his windows and lamps, made possible a level of detail previously unknown. This can be contrasted with the method of painting in enamels or glass paint on colorless glass, and then setting the glass pieces in lead channels, that had been the dominant method of creating stained glass for hundreds of years in Europe.
  3. Each lamp was handmade by skilled craftsmen, not mass- or machine-produced. Its designer was not, as had been thought for over 100 years, Louis Comfort Tiffany, but a previously unrecognized artist named Clara Driscoll who was identified in 2007 by Rutgers professor Martin Eidelberg as being the master designer behind the most creative and valuable leaded glass lamps produced by Tiffany Studios
  4. This work borders the aesthetic and art nouveau movements. Also can be considered in relation to Arts and Crafts movement.
Hector Guimard, Entrance to the Porte Dauphine Metropolitan Station, Paris, 1900

Art Nouveau
1.    The turn of the century was for many an ominous time that spelled the beginning of the end of western civilization. Many felt that the excessive luxury of the period was a sign of moral decay. New philosophies of life that offered alternative modes of thinking and living such as naturism, meditation etc. arose. 
2.    Guimards design for the Paris metro entrances is representative of the style of art nouveau or new art, an innovative approach to design marked by the rejection of revivalism and eclecticism, and the search for new forms inspired by plants, marine life and other natural forms. The metro entrances are one of the major architectural projects that reflected the contradictory atmosphere of the period. A large-scale construction project took place in Paris: a network of tunnels, hallways and stations for an underground railway system.
3.    The approaching Paris Exposition of 1900 accelerated the need for an efficient and attractive means of mass transportation. A competition was held for the design of the systems entrances, and although Guimard never formally entered the competition, the young architect was offered the commission for his avant-garde designs, which employed mass produced cast-iron components to facilitate efficient manufacture, transportation and assembly. Additionally, the modular design of the stations enabled many dozens to be assembled in a period of only a few years.
4.    The entrance to the Porte Dauphine is one of eight entrances labelled the dicule B type: simpler but still elaborate structures that consisted of three-sided glass roofed structures enclosing the stairway, with a projecting canopy. These type of entrances have come to be called libellules,because they resemble dragonflies. 
5.    Guimards entrances embody the contradictory attitudes of the fin-de-sicle period, that rekindled ancient practices and beliefs of alchemy and spiritualism and witnessed the introduction of modernist devices such as electrical light and the automobile. Salvador Dali described them as divine entrances of the Metro, by grace of which one can descend into the region of the subconscious of the living and monarchical aesthetic of tomorrow.

Auguste Perret, apartments at 25 bis rue Franklin,
Paris, France, 1902

Early Modern/Art Nouveau
  1. Perret was a French architect (though he never graduated) and pioneer of the architectural use of reinforced concrete. His major works include the Thtre des Champs-lyses, the first Art Deco building in Paris and the Church of Notre-Dame du Raincy.
  2. This residential building was his first self-designed home.  Situated in a coveted location opposite the Eiffel Tower on the Rue Franklin in Paris' 16th arrondissement, it is a seminal construction of modern architecture, because of its explicit and brilliant use of the reinforced concrete frame, the Hennebique system, and the way its internal organization anticipated Le Corbusier's later development of the free plan. Perret deliberately made the partition walls nonstructural throughout and their removal yielded an open space, punctuated only by free-standing columns. This allowed inhabitants to arrange the partitions of rooms according to their needs.
  3. It was built in 1903 when Perret was only 29, and although it owes much to his upbringing and familial wealth, it also reveals his genius as he chose something radical and previously unseen. The Perret family, mother, father, and five children, were very close, choosing to live and work together throughout their lives. Their company flourished and became known as 'Entreprise Perret-Architectes-Constructeurs-Bton Arm', capable of conception and execution of architectural projects, design, materials, and construction.
  4. Unsure about how the reinforced concrete frame would age, Perret covered the building in tiles, not so much for decoration, but because he believed it would protect it from decay. The graceful restraint of the signature Art Nouveau ceramics by Alexandre Bigot, nearly monochrome, in a pattern that repeats over the facade, is one of its most remarkable features.   
  5. Perret took advantage of the 1902 decree concerning bow-windows, setting them within 3 centimeters of the maximum area allowed. Another ingenious interpretation of building regulations was the semi-octagonal recess between these, which allowed every room splendid views and avoided the need for the customary interior courtyard.
  6. The top floor with a series of terraces served as Perret's private residence. His architectural studio was on the ground floor. Le Corbusier's first experience in an architectural firm was working for Perret from 1908 to 1910.
Fun fact: Thirty years later, the Perret offices and family home moved 500 meters down the road to a new building, where I lived in the "cave" in 2000-01!

Gertrude Ksebier, Portrait of Alfred Stieglitz, 1902
The Museum of Modern Art, New York City

Pictorialism
  1. Gertrude Kasebier (1852-1934) was an American photographer in the circle of Alfred Stieglitz in New York at the turn of the century. 
  2. With the rise of amateur photography, a small but persistent group of photographers staked their mediums claim to membership among the fine arts. They rejected the point-and-shoot approach to photography and embraced labor-intensive processes such as gum bichromate printing, which involved hand-coating artist papers with homemade emulsions and pigments, or they made platinum prints, which yielded rich, tonally subtle images. 
  3. Photographs emphasized the role of the photographer as craftsman and countered the argument that photography was an entirely mechanical medium.
  4.  Alfred Stieglitz was the most prominent spokesperson for these photographers in America, and in 1902 he and several like-minded associates in the New York Camera Clubincluding Gertrude Ksebier, Alvin Langdon Coburn, and Frank Eugenebroke away from the club to form what they dubbed the Photo-Secession.
  5. The group held exhibitions of their work in a space donated by Edward J. Steichen called the Little Galleries of the Photo-Secession (known familiarly as 291 for its address on Fifth Avenue) and published a quarterly magazine edited by Stieglitz entitled Camera Work.
  6. Photographys expressive potential and demonstrating that its value lay beyond reproducing the outlines of the world around us. 
  7. Pictorialist works were as beautifully rendered as any painters canvas and as skillfully constructed as any graphic artists composition. In manipulating the presentation of information in a photographic negative, the Pictorialists injected their own sensibility into our perception of the image.
Edvard Munch, Vampire, 1902

Symbolism
  1. Munch studied in Paris, and in 1902 (the year this work was made) exhibited at the Berlin Secession. Berlin Secession rejected academic conventions of realism and naturalism in favor of works that explored more personal and spiritual themes. (More conservative than the Vienna Secession. Berlin Secession formed in response to the controversial closing of one of Munchs exhibitions in 1892).
  2. Although Munch is primarily known as a painter, he was also a prolific printmaker. This work is a lithograph and woodcut from an edition of 150-200, for which Munch experimented with several color variations. 
  3. Munch was obsessed with images of the embrace; this print seems to show the darker side of a couple in one anothers arms. Early in his career, Munch described the embrace as sacred, as one before which people take off their hats, as if in church. He continued, the man and woman [are] not themselves, they [constitute] a link in the interminable chain linking one generation and the next.
  4. This subject is that Munch returned to repeatedly. He first depicted it in oil and titled it Love and Pain. The Polish critic Stanislaw Przybyszewski, who saw an earlier version of the work at an exhibition in 1893, suggested the title The Vampire. The title stuck, and Munch used it on the later iterations of the theme. Munch ultimately created 10 different paintings of the subject and 2 versions in print. (The 1895 print version was in black and white, while in the second - seen here - he experimented with colour lithograph, atop the original woodcut.)
  5. Munch originally imagined the work as part of the Frieze of Life : a series of 22 paintings begun in the 1890s. The series explored angst, love, sex and death; other works intended for the cycle included The Dance of Life, The Scream, and Madonna.
  6. Munch liked the visible grain of the wood from the wood block, which he combined with two lithographic stones (one for grey and red, and another for green and blue.) Wood blocks were fashionable at the time, due to the influence of Japanese woodblock printing.  
  7. Munch used a new kind of woodblock, which separated the block into pieces like a puzzle, and then combined it with lithography for rich color + tone.

Gustav Klimt, Choir of Heavenly Angels from the Beethoven frieze, 1902
The Secession, Vienna

Jugendstil / Vienna Secession

1. In 1897, 19 artists broke away (seceded) from the dominant association of artists in Vienna to form their own exhibiting society; built their own exhibition building (the Sezession, white cube with a golden dome); founded journal Ver Sacrum (sacred spring); held 23 exhibitions around the turn of the century to bring foreign art to Vienna and awaken Austrian art from its sleepy provincialism (organized a retrospective of the Impressionists and various themed exhibitions)
2. Vienna Secession was the Austrian version of Art Nouveau movements around Europe at the turn of the century (compare Les XX in Belgium, Munich Secession, Berlin Secession, etc.)
3. One of the most famous themed exhibitions was the Beethoven show of 1902, to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the composers death; show was a Gesamtkunstwerk around a statue by Max Klinger
4. Klimt was a founding member of the Secession and its first president; had caused a scandal a year prior with his allegory paintings for the University of Vienna (because of pubic hair and a pregnant nude)
5. This frieze is a narrow horizontal wall painting extending over two walls, plaster panel painted in carein colors, worked with charcoal, pencil and pastel, decorated with inlaid stucco, gold, semiprecious stones
6. Is a visual paraphrase of the final section of Ode to Joy (last movement of Beethovens 9th Symphony); last line: Let me embrace you, O millions! This kiss is for the whole world!
7. Kiss became a leitmotif of Klimts work (see The Kiss 1908)
8. Shows a chorus of women behind a couple in embrace, watched over by sun and moon in a bubble-shaped halo; epitomizing ecstasy, the momentary removal for the soul from the body
9. Formally innovative: interest in expressionist possibilities and decorative aspects of line, color and pattern; simplified, stylized figures lacking any chiaroscuro; flatness of garments versus sparsely modelled hands and heads; few sparing lines suggest the musculature on the back; sense of weightlessness and ethereality
10.  The bodily contortion and expressive use of line will later be pushed to its extreme by Klimts student Egon Schiele
Aristide Maillol, The Mediterranean, 19021905

Symbolism?
Bronze
  1. Maillol studied under Cabanel and Grme but became quickly disillusioned with their strict academicism. He met Gauguin and was convinced to join the Nabis, who he showed with from 1896-7. Upon meeting Gaugin he started to produced stylized paintings of women. When his eyesight began to fail, he translated his painterly form to sculpture, and began to produce his characteristic female, thick-limbed, symmetrical and archetypal figures in 1901.
  2. In comparison to Rodins fragmented figures, Maillol and others sought to represent the figure as an indivisible whole. In his plump nudes, Maillol leans on the Greco-Roman tradition, opting for smooth surfaces in which bronze imitates marble. His figures like those of Classical sculpture, are emotionally restrained, placid and stable, also in contrast to the emotional intensity of Rodins sculpture.
  3. He attempts to imbue the female form with a symbolic significance, removing literary and psychological references to produce a generalized figure that emphasizes form itself.
  4. La Mditerrane is carefully balanced, right arm and leg extended straight while left arm and leg bend to meet one another. Her body occupies a neat square; the volumes so perfectly balanced that she could be described as an abstract construction of an idealized woman absorbed in thought. (Bertrand Lorquin) He minimizes the empty space surrounding the sculpture in order to achieve this stable balance of volumes.
  5. This serene classicism set a standard for European and American figurative sculpture until the end of WWII. The simplification and rounding of the human form would be furthered to the point of abstraction by Henry Moore and Constantin Brancusi.
Paul Czanne, Mont SaintVictoire Seen from Les Lauves, 1902-06

Post-Impressionist
1.    Whereas the Impressionists painted with thick, short brushstrokes, shimmering colours and no outlines, Cezanne used blocks of strong color and prominently outlined forms. His simplification of the landscape could be interpreted as a return to an era of balanced, harmonious form rather than complex ornamentation, as a leap towards Modernism.
2.    After 1980, Czannes brushstrokes became larger and more expressively abstract, the contours more broken and dissolved, with color floating across the canvas, sustaining its own identity independent of the objects it defined. This painting represents the contradictions of a structured and lyrical painting, characteristic of the artists style, in which each stroke exists on its own, but is nevertheless subordinated to the harmony of the whole.
3.    One of a series of more than 30 oil paintings of Mont Saint-Victoire from various vantage points. The Mont Saint-Victoire is a mountain in Southern France. Towards the end of his life, he often painted the view of the mountain from sites near his studio, built on a hillside road across the valley from the mountain. This painting is one of the last paintings of the series.
4.    The image depicts a typical aerial perspective or fading perspective or fading away of a mountain, seen here from a distance. Although Czanne has eliminated details of the image, he gives the mountain an intensity equal to that of the foreground forms. He plays with depth in the image: flatness coexists with depth and the viewer is caught between two poles, the mountainous landscape is both within reach and far away. 
5.    This painting belongs to the tradition of classical landscape, exemplified by the works of French Academic painter Nicolas Poussin, seen as an accumulation of individual perceptions, analysed by Czanne into their abstract components and then reconstructed into the new reality of painting.
Edward Steichen, The Flatiron, 1904

Pictorialism
  1. Steichen was a key figure of 20C photography, directing its development as a prominent photographer and influential curator.
  2. The Flatiron was a popular subject for photographers after its construction on Madison Square in 1902, as a symbol of the new America in the making. Stieglitz photographed it repeatedly in 1903, providing a model for this print made by Steichen, in his newly adopted city, a year later. Steichen paid subtle homage to Stieglitz in his composition, but the differences in mood and light cancel out the similarities. Stieglitz held Steichen's composition in high esteem, for he collected all four variants in different hues.
  3. With a background in painting, Steichen experimented early with coloring techniques developed by the Lumire Brothers. Steichen added color to the platinum print that forms the foundation of this photograph by using layers of pigment suspended in a light-sensitive solution of gum arabic and potassium bichromate. This is the quintessential chromatic study of twilight.
  4. Indebted in its composition to Japanese woodcuts and in its coloristic effect to Whistler's "Nocturnes," this picture is a prime example of the conscious effort of photographers in the circle of Alfred Stieglitz to assert the artistic potential of their medium. Although indebted to these influences, Steichens iconic photograph is decidedly modern and American in its subject, with the soaring structure rising so high above the street that it cannot be contained within the frame.
  5. Steichen designed the logo and first cover of Stieglitz's journal Camera Work with Stieglitz and was its most frequently shown photographer. In 1905, Stieglitz and Steichen created the Little Galleries of the Photo-Secession, which became known as 291 after its address, and in 1910 he participated in the International Exhibition of Pictorial Photography at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo. The Flatiron was exhibited among the six hundred photographs shown, in what represented the capstone of Stieglitz's efforts to promote Pictorialist photography.
  6. During World War I, he directed aerial photography for the Army Expeditionary Forces, and in World War II became director of the U.S. Naval Photographic Institute. During his tenure as director of photography at The Museum of Modern Art (1947-62), he mounted over fifty shows, including The Family of Man in 1955, the most popular exhibition in the history of photography, with over 500 photos from 68 countries.

Henri Matisse, Portrait of Mme Matisse/The Green Line, 1905
Statens Museum for Kunst, Copenhagen, Denmark

Fauvism
  1. Henri Matisse (1869-1954) was a French artist, known for both his use of colour and his fluid and original draughtsmanship. He was a draughtsman, printmaker, and sculptor, but is known primarily as a painter. 
  2. The Green Line is an early Fauvist style painting by Henri Matisse from 1905. 
  3. Demonstrates how a painting can become hugely, powerfully expressive with very few, simple devices. The strong contrasts in colour, a typical feature of Matisses paintings from the beginning of the twentieth century, are instrumental in giving this small painting (40.5 x 32.5 cm) its great visual strength.
  4. His breakthrough as an artist came during the summers of 1904 and 1905, when the bright sunlight of the South of France inspired himalong with artists like Andr Derain and Maurice de Vlaminckto create optically dynamic works of bright, clashing colors that led to these artists being derided with the epithet fauves (wild beasts). Known as Fauvism, the work from this period set him on a career-long path that he described as construction by colored surfaces.
  5. The green line dividing the face into two halves, a cold and a warm one, contributes to a plane-like effect that makes the portrait mask-like and abstract.
Charles Rennie Mackintosh, Library, Glasgow School of Art, 190509

Glasgow Style: The Four / Scottish Art Nouveau
  1. In Scotland, Glasgow Style was inspired by Japanese design, more restrained than the sinuous lines of French, Belgian, and Spanish Art Nouveau. In both cases, the style linked art + design with painting and sculpture.
  2. The Four, a group of 4 students from the Glasgow School of Art, were led by Mackintosh (1868-1928), an architect, interior designer, and painter. In Mackintoshs designs, the curvilinear lines of French and Belgian Art Nouveau were replaced with a series of straight horizontals and verticals. 
  3. In 1896, an architectural competition took place for the building of a new Glasgow School of Art on a site offered to the School's directors by the Bellahouston trustees. Working to a budget of just 14,000, the Glasgow firm of Honeyman and Keppie submitted a design by Mackintosh, then one of their junior draughtsmen. 
  4. The library was at the heart of his designs for the building. The division of the interior space by beams recalled the architecture of Japanese homes. The timbres were likewise jointed rather than a post and lintel system. Mackintosh drew heavily on Japanese design throughout his career. 
  5. The librarys tall windows referenced Scottish Baronial tower houses, which Mackintosh considered incredibly modern in their original use of iron and glass. (Mackintosh was sensitive to surrounding architecture and existing national traditions, which he combined with his own aesthetic sensibilities.)
  6. Mackintosh became known for a series of four tearooms he designed in Glasgow in the early 1900s, which - like the library - revolved around an integrated scheme of art and design, from tables and chairs, to light-fixtures, to structural supports. 
  7. The Glasgow School of Art is referred to by the Charles Rennie Mackintosh Society as the architect's "masterwork", as it seamlessly merges numerous eclectic references that would appear throughout the architect's career.
Josef Hoffmann, Palais Stoclet, Brussels, 190511

Art Nouveau / Viennese Jugendstil
1. Together with Gustav Klimt, Josef Hoffmann was the founder of the Vienna Secession; aside from his achievements in architecture, his most significant role was in the establishment of the Wiener Werksttte, a leading crafts workshop in the field of design and industrial objects for the next three decades (which did not reject the machine as a basic tool of the designer)
2. Built for the banker and art lover Adolphe Stoclet, it is one of the most luxurious private mansions of the 20th century
3. Hoffmann aimed to create a Gesamtkunstwerk (a total aesthetic environment): even designed a dress for Madame Stoclet so that she would not clash with her living room decor
4. Exterior is a flat-walled, rectangular structure or broad, clear white areas framed in dark, linear strips (influenced by Mackintosh); with its relatively unadorned cubic forms, it anticipated the functionalism of Gropius, van der Rohe and Le Corbusier
5. Interior: typical Art Nouveau synthesis of decorative elements into a total decorative environment: includes dining-room murals designed by Klimt, made of glass, enamel, metal and semiprecious stones; figures are conceived as flat patterns (except for modelled heads and hands) within an overall pattern of abstract spirals; although essentially decorative in their total effect, the Stoclet murals mark the moment when modern painting was on the edge of nonrepresentation
6. Although located in Brussels, the building is more typical of the elegant geometry of Viennese Jugendstil (compare Viennas subway stations by Wagner or the Secession building by Olbrich) than the decorative flourishes of Belgian or French Art Nouveau (i.e. Hortas Tassel House or Guimards metro stations)
7. This building exemplifies the fact that an Art Nouveau decorativeness (interior) and modern geometric functionalism (exterior) are far from mutually exclusive
8. Still occupied by the Stoclet family and not open to visitors, but declared a UNESCO world heritage site
Paul Czanne, The Large Bathers, 1906

Postimpressionism
Oil on canvas
  1. Maintained the divisionism (discrete strokes of single non-mixed color) established by the Impressionists. In his later works especially, each stoke exists in its own right, but is nevertheless subordinated to the harmony of the whole, something he felt lacking from the impressionist paintings.
  2. Cezanne had a desire to remake Poussin after nature, struggling with the problem of how to pose classically or heroically nude figures in an open landscape. In The Large Bathers he sees this through, painting from his imagination. It was painted the year of his death and is thus unfinished.
  3. He was interested in his still lives, as well as in his later landscapes in setting up spatial tensions among objects and unifying them as color areas, while preserving the nature of the individual object. He did this by distorting the shapes of the objects or figures, modulating circular forms with flat brushstrokes, and loosening or breaking the contours.
  4. In this work the human body become so formalized that it is subservient to overall composition, just like the apples do in his earlier still life paintings. You can see this in the posture of far-left figure which mirrors the bend of the tree as well as in the use of rosy flesh tones and earthy ochers to unify the canvas, making up the bodies as well as the tries, and hazy sky. In this way, the formal relationships become the subject of the painting itself.
Andr Derain, Turning Road, LEstaque, 1906

Fauvism
1.    Typical of the vibrantly colourful style of Fauves (French for wild beasts). The Fauve painters (Matisse and Derain) were the first to break from the traditions of Impressionism. The Fauve movement was driven by the need to create a new artistic style that the directness of traditional impressionism, but also used intense color juxtapositions. 
2.    Depicts the Southern French village LEstaque, a popular location painted by several other artists including Czanne and Braque, indicating how Derain was influenced by his artistic forebears and ways in which his style diverges from that of others. 
3.    Early Fauve works like this one were influenced by Gauguin. The same kind of decorative treatment of the landscape is evident in Gauguins early work in Pont Aven in 1889. 
4.    The differing depths in the composition is created by juxtaposing extreme colors besides each other. He uses flat areas of color, abstaining from any traditional manner of denoting shadow: Fauves considered juxtaposition of complementary colors an adequate method by which to capture the difference between light and shade. He no longer uses the style of Division noted in his earlier landscapes, instead allowing 
5.    LEstaque serves as a milestone in the brief, yet crucial movement of Fauvism, which explored the central tenet of Modernist painting: that the strength of a picture had more to do with colors of the canvas than with serving as a realist representation of the world.
Paula ModersohnBecker, SelfPortrait with Camellia Branch, 190607

Expressionism
  1. Modersohn-Becker produced an enormous body of work in her brief life (1876-1907). In 1898, she joined the Worpswede artist colony, near Bremen, where she met and married painter Otto Modersohn. She soon grew impatient with the sentimental naturalism of the Worpswede painters and in 1900 made the first of several long trips to Paris, where she found inspiration in the works of Czanne, Gauguin, and van Gogh. She was the first German painter to assimilate the Post-Impressionist currents she discovered for herself in Paris.
  2. Her style blended post-impressionism's focus on simplification and abstraction, with her commitment to humanistic ideals. Frequently criticized for her paw-like hands, Becker was interested in suggesting a sense of presence/physicality and expressing her inner-feelings, leading her to be recognized as a pioneer of German Expressionism.  
  3. This serene self-portrait shows how she also drew from Fayum mummy portraits seen at the Louvre. The high, narrow format of the support, directly frontal depiction, focus on head and upper body, and the enlarged eyes, mirror their antique predecessors.
  4. A camellia branch held in her hand, pictorially only hinted at, refers to an older pictorial tradition where the camellia branch symbolized an eternal cycle of blooming and withering, becoming and passing, life and death.
  5. Contemplating the transience of her own existence was not unusual. Modersohn-Becker began to express concerns about her mortality early. "I know I will not live very long," she wrote in July 1900. But, "if love blooms for me before I go and if I paint three good pictures, then I can leave willingly with flowers in my hands and hair."
  6. This, likely her last self-portrait, can be linked to her last stay in Paris between August 1906 and March 1907, when she returned to Worpswede. On November 20th, 1907, three weeks after the birth of her first child, she died of a post-partum embolism at age 31.
  7. Her contributions to early 20th century art paved the way for future female artists to explore themes of femininity in their work. Modersohn-Becker painted herself and other women in a way that upended traditional standards, avoiding idealization, eroticization, and conventional beauty. As she sought to reinvent the representation of women in Western art history, her most radical step was in taking herself as a subject, likely becoming the first modern woman artist to have painted nude and pregnant self-portraits.
  8. Her diaries and letters were published in 1917.
McKim, Mead and White, Pennsylvania Station, New York, 1906-10

Beaux-Arts Architecture
  1. New York Penn Station was inspired by the Gare d'Orsay, a Beaux-Arts style station in Paris, but twice as large. He commissioned Charles McKim of the New York architectural firm McKim, Mead & White to design the terminal.
  2. McKim envisioned a space that would celebrate "the entrance to one of the great metropolitan cities of the world." He studied the role of public buildings in Ancient Rome, including the Baths of Diocletian. (coffered ceiling, corinthian columns, white stone)
  3. McKim, Mead & White was an American architectural firm that came to define architectural practice, urbanism, and the ideals of the American Renaissance in fin de sicle New York.
  4. The firm's founding partners Charles Follen McKim (18471909), William Rutherford Mead (18461928) and Stanford White (18531906) were giants in the architecture of their time, and remain important as innovators and leaders in the development of modern architecture worldwide. They formed a school of classically trained and technologically skilled designers who could build on the grand scale of Penn Station. The firm's New York City buildings include Manhattan's former Pennsylvania Station, the Brooklyn Museum, and the main campus of Columbia University. They also worked in Boston, Rhode Island, and Washington, D. C. 
  5. After a period of decline in railroad usage after World War II, the station was eventually sold and demolished in 1963-6 to make way for Madison Square Garden and new Penn Station (so lovely and wonderful, right?) the demolition was met with huge opposition and the  controversy over the original head house's demolition is cited as a catalyst for the architectural preservation movement in the United States, particularly in New York City.  In 1965, two years after Penn Station's demolition commenced, the city passed a landmarks preservation act, thereby creating the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.
Pablo Picasso, Les Demoiselles dAvignon, JuneJuly 1907

Proto-Cubism
  1. The title of this massive (96x92) oil painting references Carrer d'Aviny (Calle de Avin [es]), a street in the red-light district of Barcelona. 
  2. Between 1906 and 1907, Picasso was introduced to Iberian stone sculpture in Spain, as well as to African and Oceanic art at the Muse dEthnographie du Trocadro in Paristhe citys first anthropological museum. The two figures at the center are sometimes connected to the style of the former, the two figures at the right are often connected to the latter. Some art historians have described the left-most figure as a reference to Egyptian sculpture. 
  3. Iberian sculpture had influenced a number of Picassos works painted the previous year, including his portrait of Gertrude Stein. 
  4. Picassos interest in so-called primitive art influenced his development of Cubism with Braques. The pared-down, geometric quality that he perceived in the forms of Iberian, African, and Oceanic sculpture could be used to pose a challenge to contemporary European conventions of realism, fragmenting forms and space by rendering them viewpoint-by-viewpoint. 
  5. Picasso admired Degas monotypes of sex workers (he would later collect them). Art historians (including Krauss et al in Art since 1900, in a typically Freudian analysis) have drawn a parallel between the voyeurism of spectators in a bordello and in art exhibitions. 
  6. Picasso filled 16 sketchbooks in preparation for this work, and made numerous studies. The composition initially included two (clothed) men: Leo Steinberg notes that the actual viewer has replaced these men.
  7. Les Demoiselles DAvignon stayed in Picassos studio for nearly the entirety of the time between its painting and the artists sale of the work to collector Jacques Doucet in 1924: it was not exhibited widely at its inception, as its scale might encourage one to assume. In the years since, however, it has been written about widely, including by famed MoMA curator Alfred H. Barr and perhaps most notably by Leo Steinberg, in his landmark essay The Philosophical Brothel.

John Sloan, Hairdressers Window, 1907
Wadsworth Atheneum, Hartford Connecticut

American Social Realism / Ashcan School or The Eight
1. The Ashcan School/The Eight were a group of young realist artists who opposed the conservatism of the American art academies; held a historic 1908 show at Macbeth gallery, milestone in modern American painting (the first modern revolution in American painting was one towards realism)
2. Sloan was trained as an illustrator of newspaper sketches, a profession that became obsolete with the development of photography printing in newspapers; came to painting as a draughtsman interested in the everyday realities of American life
3. This painting shows a sidewalk scene in New York in which people crowd underneath the window of a hairdressers shop; includes a commercial sign with the pun Madame Malcomb; private act of grooming is performed for a public audience, which nevertheless remain strangers to each other; fierce social criticism inherent in these scenes of urban grime
4. Early example of the Ashcan Schools mundane but gritty realism: worked from his window and spent hours walking the city sketching scenes he found, documented an urban community, sense of isolation, loneliness and lack of connection (recalling the flneurs of mid-19th century Paris)
5. Theme of the window frame and the very act of looking become the explicit theme of the work
6. Searched for the artistic potential within the most commonplace subjects, including commercial advertisements: Ashcan School can be seen as an early forerunner of Pop Art (Warhol admired Sloan)
Alfred Stieglitz, The Steerage, 1907

Straight Photography
Gelatin-silver print
  1. Stieglitz was an early advocate of Pictorialism, a photographic movement that deplored the utilitarian banality of sharp-focus, documentary photography as well as academic pretension. Instead, they insisted upon the artistic possibilities of camera-made imagery, but held that these could be realized only when art and science had been combined to serve both truth and beauty.
  2. Because Stieglitz maintained a strict truth to materials position, creating highly expressive images without the aid of darkroom enhancement, he was an important forerunner of so-called straight photography. The straight photographer exploits the intrinsic properties of the camera to make photographs that look like photographs instead of imitations of paintings or fine-art prints. This image marks his transition away from more painterly Pictorialist prints of Symbolist subjects to a more straightforward depiction of quotidian life.
  3. He established the Photo-Secession group in 1902 to promote the serious recognition of photography as an additional medium of pictorial expression.
  4. In this image, taken during a voyage to Europe, Stieglitz selected as his subject the steerage where the cheapest accommodations were. He avoids the slightest Pictorialist sentiment or anecdote, providing instead a straight document of the scene that was not merely a crowd of immigrants but a study of line, shape and light. By using photography to elevate formal qualities, engaging the same dialogues around abstraction that preoccupied European avant-garde painters, he elevated photography from a mimic of painting to a wholly formed and unique art form in itself.
  5. Four years later he published the photo on the cover of his magazine Camera Work at which point it was highly celebrated.
Georges Braque, Houses at LEstaque, August 1908

Proto-Cubist 
1.    Houses at LEstaque exemplifies the transformation that took place in Braques style in the Fall of 1907, from his earlier brief exploration of Fauvism, indicated by Viaduct at LEstaque (1907) which featured bright colorations. In comparison, this work moves towards a Cubist style with simplified, geometric forms and a more subdued palette. 
2.    Considered the first Cubist landscape. Braque was critiqued by art critic Louis Vauxcelles as being a daring man who despises form, reducing everything, places and figures and houses, to geometric schemas, to cubes which led to the name of the Cubist movement.
3.    In 1907, the Grand Palais organised a retrospective of Czannes work, the artist having passed away the year before. Braques visit to the exhibition played a crucial role in his shift from fauvism. Inspired by Czannes visual language, Braque creates a series of landscapes atLEstaque, which was a popular subject among Impressionists, and Czanne in particular. Here, he emulates Czannes systematization of the motif, gradually lightened his Fauvist palette, and reduced details in his composition these tendencies in his work are often referred to as Czannism.
4.    Braques illusion of limited depth is not dependent upon the traditional single point linear perspective. Instead, he achieves illusion by the apparent volume of the buildings and trees their overlapping and shifting shapes create the effect of a scene observed from a distance. 
5.    Despite many inconsistencies (conflicting orthogonals and vantage points) Braque creates a syncretic and highly conceptualized space, one that exemplifies modernist concerns in being true to sense perceptions rather than pictorial conventions.

Lewis Hine, Child in Carolina Cotton Mill, 1908
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

Documentary Photography
  1. Hine, a sociologist and photographer, spent 1908-1916 as the staff photographer for the National Child Labor Committee, visiting factories to photograph child labor abuses in perilous work environments. Declaring that he "wanted to show things that had to be corrected," he was the most important photographer to use the medium as a documentary tool for social advocacy in the first half of the twentieth century.
  2. Hine conned his way into mills and factories from Massachusetts to South Carolina by posing as a Bible seller, insurance agent, or industrial photographer, to find children in exploitative situations and tell the plight of nearly 2 million children. Carting around a large-format camera and jotting down information in a hidden notebook, he recorded children laboring in mills, meatpacking houses, coal mines, and canneries.
  3. Hine often directed his subjects and skillfully composed his images to better make his case. In 1908 he came upon a 48-inch-tall wisp of a girl, Sadie Pfeifer (10-11 years old), who embodied the world he exposed. She was one of many children at work manning a gargantuan cotton-spinning machine in Lancaster, S.C. For this image, he chose a vantage point that emphasizes the enormity of the child's environment. A series of tall windows on the right illuminate the large loom that recedes into the distance and dominates the room, dwarfing the child.
  4. He made double-sure that [his] photo data was 100% pureno retouching or fakery of any kind. His images of children set the horrors of child labor before the public, leading to regulatory legislation against industrial exploitation of child labor over a period of roughly 35 years, which cut the number of child laborers nearly in half from 1910 to 1920 and ended in the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 which brought child labor to an end in the US.

Arthur Dove, The Lobster, 1908
Amon Carter Museum, FortWorth, Texas

American Fauvist-style
  1. An early American modernist, he is often considered the first American abstract painter. Dove used a wide range of media, sometimes in unconventional combinations, to produce his abstractions and his abstract landscapes. Member of Stieglitz group. 
  2. Image exhibited at the Salon d'Autonme. 
  3. Dove's study of Cezanne's work is apparent particularly from Cezanne's spatial arrangements, along with the influence of Matisse in the decorative use of brilliant color. Influenced by the style of les Fauves (French for "the wild beasts"), a group of early twentieth-century modern artists whose works emphasized painterly qualities and strong color over the representational or realistic values retained by Impressionism.
  4. Dove reinterprets the traditional still life genre in a modern style.
  5. This was the last representational painting by Dove before he turned to abstraction. This was a stepping point on the way to his ideals of abstraction: pictures as independent of natural subject matter, making him one of the innovators of nonobjective art (Nature Symbolized No, 2 (1911). By late 1920s, proclaimed the boldest American pioneer, based on the exploration of color and form. 
  6. American critics denounced the painting's "radical" French traits such as its high key colors, thick impasto, and the tilt of the table, which flattens the picture plane.
Peter Behrens, AEG Turbine Factory, 190809, Berlin

Industrial Classicism
  1. Peter Behrens was a painter turned graphic designer. Earlier in his career, Behrens was artist-in-residence at the Darmstadt Artists Colony; headed the Kunstgewerbeschule ("School of arts and crafts") in Dsseldorf; and with Josef Hoffmann, and Joseph Maria Olbrich, Henri Van de Velde,  and others, was a founding member of the Deutscher Werkbund (German Association of Craftsmen).
  2. Behrens first assignment with AEG was to redesign their arc lamp. He streamlined the design and shifted its proportions: the redesign was so successful that they invited him to design kettles, fans, and clocks among other objects, and even factory buildings. AEG was among the first firms to invest in industrial design: AEG wanted to sell not only the best-functioning kettles, but also the most streamlined, aesthetically pleasing kettles. 
  3. At the time, people would have had little knowledge of whether they were purchasing an appliance made by a reputable company or buying a cheaper-quality object. AEG was one of the first major manufacturers to develop a label as a means to distinguish their products from those of their competitors: Behrens designed their trademark. The emergence of brand-recognition ushered in a new age of capitalism, and a new place for artists within the industrial capitalist system.
  4. According to Behrens, the artist-designers role was to respond to the contemporary moment and give it form (For like minds, see Owen Jones and Behrens contemporary and comrade at the Werkbund, Henri Van de Velde.) Behrens saw the Turbine Factory - his first building design - as a symbol of modernism: speed, noise, and power. He wanted to make the design as simple as possible, and worked with engineers to create a temple to production: largely open in the interior, with fewer, larger girders than was usual. 
  5. The design was a new classicism, rendered in the industrial materials (glass, concrete, steel) that were shaping modern life.
  6. Design, Behrens wrote, is not about decorating functional formsit is about creating forms that accord with the character of the object and that show new technologies to advantage." (See also/later: Bauhaus) His faade for the building - emblazoned with the hexagonal logo that he designed for AEG - had no structural significance, but became iconic for the company. 
  7. Walter Gropius later apprenticed with Behrens. 
  8. The Neo-Beidermeyer style that Behrens espoused by Behrens was praised for its self-restraint but condemned for its allegiance to the age-old precept of symmetry in Jan Tschicholds New Typography (1928)
Frank Lloyd Wright, Robie House, Chicago, 1908-10

Prairie Style
1. Wright studied engineering at the University of Wisconsin, reading the works of John Ruskin and Viollet-le-Duc, worked in the firm of Adler and Sullivan, saw the buildings of Olbrich and Wagner in Vienna during a trip to Europe
2. Robie House is the masterpiece of Wrights early-career Prairie Style = named after the horizontal accent of rooflines with deep overhanging eaves, which echo the flat prairie landscape of the Midwest; first architectural style to be considered uniquely American and a new form of domestic design and residential architecture
3. Centered around the fireplace as the spiritual and psychological home of the house, Wrights houses were the habitat of the American middle-class nuclear families living in harmony with nature; the fast-growing, sprawling suburbs of Chicago allowed for such a horizontal extension, as opposed to the verticality demanded by the urban context
4. Arranged in two sliding horizontal sections on one dominant axis (two rectangles that seem to slide past each other), with a horizontal cantilevering roof hanging out on steel beams, long symmetrical row of windows deeply embedded into the brick structure, horizontal lines are extended in the terraces and walls which fuse interior and exterior space in an outward-flowing design
5. Interior is characterized by a light-filled open plan, low ceilings that create a sense of intimacy, constantly changing vistas of one space flowing into another (reflecting the informality of the American lifestyle)
6. Created for 28-year old Frederick Robie, who was forced to sell the house due to financial problems and (ironically) a crumbling marriage after only 14 months
7. Wrights pre-war architecture antedates much of the abstract and industrial design experiments of interwar European architecture (Bauhaus)
Emil Nolde, The Last Supper, 1909

German Expressionism / Die Brcke
Oil on canvas
  1. Nolde (German 1867-1956) advocated for a regeneration of the German spirit and its art characterized by the popular volkisch or nationalist tradition, with strong emotional ties to the landscape. His early paintings drew on themes of traditional Germanic fantasy.
  2. He joined the German Expressionist group Die Brcke in 1906, but quickly left, preferring to work in solitude and began to devote himself to a personal form of Expressionist religious painting, the first of which was The Last Supper.
  3. Here, his figures are crammed tightly into the frame, which, along with the vivid colors of their robes and glowing skin, and the excitable expressions on their faces, contributes to a dramatic sense of impending crisis. He provides no spatial context to the figures, focusing intensely on their individual expressions, capturing the emotion and experience of the event. This exists in stark contrast to Old Master or Renaissance depictions of this scene that represents the event and all the figures with calm restraint.
  4. This painting in its colors, composition and loose brushstrokes retain the hallmarks of Die Brcke.
  5. Emil Nolde believed in the ethnic superiority of the Nordic people and became a member of the Nazi party in 1920; his art was at first tolerated by Goebbels and then condemned in 1934, and included in the Entartete Kunst exhibition in 1937

George Bellows, Both Members of This Club, 1909
National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.

Ashcan School 
1.    In the early 20th century, Bellows aspired to represent the rough and dark edges of New York City. He moved to New York in his early twenties and studied with Robert Henri at the New York School of Art, and became part of an informal group of American artists led by Henri who came to be called the Ashcan School due to their gritty brand of realism and apparent muddiness of their color palettes. Typical subjects for the group included youths, working class people, immigrant communities and the urban streets. 
2.    This painting is the third and largest of Bellows early prizefighting subjects. Boxing was a controversial subject at the time (public boxing matches were banned in New York State in 1900), but the interracial theme in which the black boxer appears to be winning made the painting even more so.
