  5. Corner Counter-relief evokes the dynamism of modernity, with the various intersecting lines overlapping and moving in different directions to create rhythm and tension, representing opposed yet inseparable notions flexibility and rigidness, freedom and tension, movement and calmness.
  6. The structural relationships are laid bare. It was this literal incorporation of structure that came to be seen as an early stage in the development of Constructivism the dominant modern art movement in Soviet Russia after 1920.
Kazimir Malevich, view of the 0-10 exhibition in Petrograd, 1915

Suprematism
1.     Zero-Ten: The Last Futurist Exhibition of Paintings was held in Petrograd from Dec 1915 to Jan 1916, and was important in inaugurating a form of non-objective art called Suprematism, and in signifying the  end of Russias previous leading art movement, Cubo-Futurism. Up until then, Russian innovators had essentially been assimilating and developing the inventions of European artists. 0-10 marked the point when Russian artist had caught up with their European counterparts and now occupied a position at the forefront of avant-garde experimentation.
2.     Malevich worked in a Cubo-Futurist manner until 1914, with paintings featuring a matrix of colored planes. His transition to Suprematism in 1915 was marked by abstract paintings in which these places came to function as entirely independent forms suspended on a white ground. He worked intensively to develop his ideas through painting and writing in the second half of 1915, finally unveiling 39 non-representational paintings in the exhibition to launch Suprematism.
3.     In his volume of essays titled The Non-Objective World, he defined Suprematism as the supremacy of pure feeling in creative art, rather than a visual depiction of objects. He created a suprematist grammar based on fundamental geometric forms, in particular the square and circle.
4.     0-10 includedBlack Square, hung high across the corner of the room, the position traditionally occupied by an icon in Orthodox Russian homes. The gesture seemed to emphasise the spiritual qualities of Malevichs painting, although some viewers interpreted it as provocative blasphemy. It was considered the emblem of Suprematism, the most reductive, the most uncompromisingly abstract paintings of its time.
5.     Some of the paintings in 0-10 are based on elemental geometric forms such as the square or the cross, while others depict more complex arrangements of form and color. Occasionally their titles play on the tension between abstraction and figuration, such as Red Square (Painterly Realism of a Peasant Woman in Two Dimensions)
6.     This is one of only two existing installation photographs of 0-10. Even the printed catalogue does not provide a definitive list of exhibits. To compound such difficulties, many of the paintings were lost or damaged in the Revolution of 1917 and the imposition of Stalinism.

Morgan Russell, Synchromie Cosmique, 1915
MunsonWilliamsProctor Institute, Museum of Art, Utica, New York

Synchromism
  1. Morgan Russell was a modernist painter and one of the first Americans to paint in a purely abstract manner.
  2. While in Paris, he and fellow expat, Stanton MacDonald-Wright, were deeply influenced by color theory, as well as by the works of Delacroix, the Impressionists, Czanne, and Matisse that placed a great emphasis on juxtapositions and reverberations of color. Together they co-founded the avant-garde movement Synchromism, the first American avant-garde art movement to receive international attention.
  3. They chose the term for its analogy with the word symphony to suggest their interest in color rhythms. Russell wrote this for the catalog of the Synchromist exhibition at the Bernheim-Jeune Gallery in Paris, in October 1913: These color rhythms infuse a painting with the notion of time: they create the illusion that the picture develops, like a piece of music, within a span of time, while the old painting existed strictly in space, its every expression grasped by the spectator simultaneously and at a glance.
  4. Cosmic Synchromy contains repeated variations of the same spiral shape that he included in an earlier monumental painting Synchromy in Deep Blue Violet (1913). In that painting the spiral derived from the contrapposto of Michelangelos Dying Slave (Louvre). In this painting, however, no obvious pictorial source is evident. The principal idea in this canvas, according to Russell, was "a spiraling plunge into space, excited and quickened by appropriate color contrasts."
  5. Russell held Cosmic Synchromy in high esteem. This is evident by its inclusion in the Forum Exhibition of Modern American Painters in New York (1916), and his choice to discuss the work in the exhibitions catalog and to use it to illustrate his essay.
  6. Cosmic Synchromy was also reproduced in "Modern Painting," a book by the critic Willard Huntington Wright, Macdonald-Wrights brother and one of the Forum Exhibitions organizers.
Marcel Duchamp, The Bride Stripped Bare by Her Bachelors, Even (The Large Glass), 191523

Anti-Art/American Dada
  1. In Duchamp are joined the essential elements of the dada revolt: a total absence of principles or prejudices, things moveover being equal and permitted. "There is no solution," says Duchamp, "because there isn't any problem." My irony," says Duchamp, "is that of indifference: meta-irony." Before Marcel Duchamp, a work of art was an artefact, a physical object. After Duchamp it was an idea, a concept.
  2. A well-known example of Dada and neither painting nor sculpture (Medium: Oil, varnish, glue, lead foil, lead wire, and dust on two glass panels), this work by Duchamp is distinguished by its exceptional visual and conceptual complexity; Duchamp began working on The Large Glass shortly upon his arrival to New York and it took him eight years to complete, although he first conceived of it three years earlier while in Munich; the process of making the work was accompanied by a multitude of sketches, studies, etc; the voluminous notes on the work were published in 1934
  3. In 1923, Duchamp declared the work definitively unfinished and he only considered it finished after the glass cracked during transport to Philadelphia Museum and the artist laboriously put it back together, satisfied with the result of the asymmetrical cracks
  4. The Large Glass is radical in that it is intended to be looked both at and through; it is different from other ready-mades and the assisted ready-mades due to its complex manufacturing and convoluted narrative; the narrative of the work is contained in Duchamp's notes and was only partially published in 1934 in The Green Box (includes jokes that are not included in the sculpture itself)
  5. According to these notes, "Duchamp's "delay in glass" chronicles the state of perpetual desire involving the bride, depicted in the upper panel, and the circle of nine uniformed bachelors arrayed in the lower. Duchamp devised an elaborate iconography to demonstrate the erotic proceedings and characterize the unfortunate actors." (Philadelphia Museum of Art); could be understood as a mechanistic and cynical interpretation of love; importantly, Duchamp's published notes place significant emphasis on the erotic facet of the work
  6. It occupies the same space in the museum that Duchamp chose decades ago; enigmatic and polysemic, the work has offered a continued source of art historical research and speculation

Confused? Me too, and I spent 3 weeks of a seminar listening to a Duchamp scholar trying to explain it. This guide is super helpful if you want to attempt to understand what the hell is going on here or look at close-up images of the bride/bachelor halves: https://smarthistory.org/duchamp-largeglass/
Hugo Ball in his Magical Bishop Costume, at the Cabaret Voltaire, Zurich, June 1916

Zurich Dada
  1. Cabaret Voltaire is often referred to as the birthplace of Dada, of which Ball was a co-founder (or perhaps co-midwife). Ball was a German theatre director and philosopher. Ball and his partner, cabaret singer Emmy Hennings, opened the cabaret together in February 1916 - two years after the start of WWI. 
  2. Ball wrote in his diary in 1916, Everyone has been seized by an indefinable intoxication. The small cabaret is about to come apart at the seams and is going to be a playground for crazy emotions. Dada was founded on the rejection of all norms, including its own (Dada is Andi-Dada was a frequent refrain). Cabaret Voltaires vaudevillian mockeries set their sights on ideals of culture and of art. That is our Candide against the times, wrote Ball: the cabarets name was an homage to Candides author. 
  3. Tristan Tzara (poet and impressario), Marcel Janco (visual artist) and Richard Huelsenbeck (poet and percussionist) were at Cabaret Voltaires opening, and went on to be important figures in Dada. 
  4. Performances at the cabaret often appropriated African and African diasporic art and music: Huselnbeck decided that the cabaret would be improved by the addition of Negro rhythm and brought an African drum; Janco designed masks and costumes influenced by Romanian as well as African art. 
  5. This photograph is linked to the first performance of Balls sound poems at Cabaret Voltaire. These poems were verses without words that rejected the rigid system of conventional language. Ball described this first performance in a diary entry (dated June 23, 1916, published in Flight Out of Time (1927): I gave a reading of the first one of these poems this evening. I had made myself a special costume for it. My legs were in a cylinder of shiny blue cardboard, which came up to my hips so that I looked like an obelisk. Over it I wore a huge collar cut out of cardboard, scarlet inside and gold outside. It was fastened at the neck in a way that I could give the impression of winglike movement by raising and lowering my elbows. I also wore a high, blue-and-white-striped witch doctors hat. Eventually, bathed in sweat, he was carried down from the stage like, as he put it, a magical bishop. 
  6. Contrary to most academic discussions, this photograph was most likely restaged, not taken live, due to the darkness of theatres and the available photographic technology at the time. The supposition of present-ness of the photographs making to the original performance indicates historians desire for and supposition of access to the original performance.
Fun fact: Ball often played piano at the cabaret.

Paul Strand, Blind, 1916
Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

American Straight Photography
1. Paul Strand was an American photographer and filmmaker who, along with fellow modernist photographers like Alfred Stieglitz and Edward Weston, helped establish photography as an art form in the 20th century.
2. Strand was introduced to Stieglitz and other members of the Photo-Secession group by his teacher Lewis Hine. In 1916 Stieglitz arranged Strands debut with a one-person exhibition at 291. In 1917 last two issues of Stieglitz magazine Camera Work were dedicated to Strands photography.
3. This image of a street peddler was published in Camera Work in 1917. It immediately became an icon of the new American photography, which integrated the humanism of social documentation with the boldly simplified forms of modernism.
4. By the time he entered the Stieglitz circle, Strand had abandoned his early Pictorialism for photographs inspired by Cubist painting and straight photography. Strand published an essay in Camera Work in 1917 in which he called for photography as an objective art without tricks of process of manipulation.
5. Strand was documenting immigrants in NYCs Lower East Side when the nation was being reshaped by a surge of immigrants. Wanted to capture people as they were, and not as they posed. The result is a radical departure from the eras stilted poses for formal portraits (here, the womans face turned away from the camera as she is seemingly gazing elsewhere).
6. Blind is from a series of candid street portraits from 1916 made with a handheld camera fitted with a false lens attached to its side, allowing Strand to point the camera in one direction while actually taking the photograph in another. Even if she could see, the blind woman thus wouldnt have known she was being photographed (she is doubly unaware).
7. By depicting subjects without their knowledge or consent and using their images to promote social awareness, Strand helped pave the way for an entirely new form of documentary art: street photography.
8. In 1945 MoMA organized its first one-person exhibition of photography for Strands work.
Jean (Hans) Arp, Fleur Marteau (Hammer Flower), 1916

Zurich Dada
Oil on wood
  1. This work, one of his constructed paintings represents a medium somewhere between painting and sculpture. They evidence the influence of Cubist collage and constructions.
  2. To make the reliefs, Arp prepared drawings and gave them to a carpenter who cut them in wood. They were formed from his willingness to let his pencil be guided unconsciously without a set goal in mind.
  3. The biomorphism of the resulting organic forms has universal significance for Arp which he described as Formes terrestres or earthly forms. After initially intuitively creating the shape (from a doodle), he would identify in its a specific object, thus titling the work as in Hammer Flower.
  4. Dada was the soil for shaping up personal artists style, based on biomorphic forms and principle of spontaneity, chance. 
  5. Arp was a co-founder of Dada, developing an art form based on biomorphic forms and principle of spontaneity, chance. In this work, Arp demonstrated his sustained interest in depersonalization, being explored simultaneously by Duchamp, relinquishing a certain amount of control to distance oneself from the creative process
Jean (Hans) Arp, Collage Of Squares Arranged According To the Laws of Chance, 191617

Zurich Dada
1.     Profoundly affected by the trauma of modern warfare and the expansion of print media, Arp and his fellow Dadaists sought to radically rethink the very nature of art. They held reason and rationality responsible for WWI and in response, employed new, antirational aesthetic strategies, including abstraction, collage and the use of chance procedures.
2.     In 1916-17 Arp produced collages of torn, rectangular pieces of colored paper scattered in a  vaguely rectangular arrangement on a paper ground. This work is one of the earliest of Arps chance collages and fully embodied Dadas demands of new art.
3.     Also emerging at the time was his conviction of  the metaphysical reality of objects and of life itself. It may have been his passion to express his reality in the most concrete terms possible, as an organic abstraction (or as he termed it, organic concretion) that led him from painting to collage.
4.     The work, like his other collages, was created by tearing paper into pieces, letting them fall to the floor and pasting each scrap where it happened to land. Rather than ordering the page according to his own design, he ceded control to the random hand of gravity, thus also giving him a solution to his problems of composition with which he had been struggling.
5.     Liberated from rational thought processes, the laws of chance, Arp felt, were more in tune with the working of nature. By relinquishing a certain amount of control, he was distancing himself from the creative processes. This kind of depersonalization was also being explored by Duchamp and other Dadaists. 
6.     However, the grid like composition of the collage may be evidence that Arp did not fully relinquish control. He used heavyweight, possibly fine-art paper, and that edges were torn on a slant to reveal inner fibers. It suggests a counterintuitive interpretation: that the work may be as much a visual representation of chance as a product of it.
Wilhelm Lehmbruck, Seated Youth, 1917

1. Lehmbruck was a German sculptor, painter, draftsman, and printmaker. He is best known for his sculptures of slender, elongated figures whose solemn gestures convey introspection and a hushed, brooding emotion.
  2. He was influenced by the calm Classicism of Aristide Maillol and the monumental works of Auguste Rodin, as well as the ideas of Friedrich Nietzsche.
  3. He served as a medic in Berlin during World War I, though he was discharged in 1916 for a hearing impairment. His experiences with wounded and dying soldiers led him to create this, and other poignant works like Fallen Man (191516).
  4. Seated Youth portrays both survivor and mourner. In place of dramatic gestures there is inward contemplation in a self-contained, reflective, and melancholic pose. All nonessential elements eliminated, we focus our attention on the bowed head, elongated limbs, and the pockets of negative space that unite the form. This use of space reflects Lehmbruck's awareness of contemporary Parisian trends in sculpture, though it represents a departure from Maillol and the 19th c. tradition that emphasized volume and mass.  The formal language both underlies and reinforces the sculpture's expressive content. With its mood of dejection and loss, it expresses the trauma and sadness he experienced during WWI.
  5. Lehmbruck's poem "Is There Anybody Left?" (1918), attests to his despair: "Who has survived this bloodbath? Friends lie silent around me; My brothers are no longer here. Faith, love, everything has disappeared, but death is everywhere, on every flower and every path. Oh limitless curses on it! You who have made so much death, have you none for me?"
  6. Seated Youth represents the fullest synthesis of Lehmbruck's sculptural style. The originality of its formal language, his use of the new technique of stone casting in lieu of bronze, and its deeply expressive content would influence sculptors as diverse as Alberto Giacometti and Henry Moore. 
  7. In January 1919, Lehmbruck was selected as a member of the Prussian Academy of Arts in Berlin. Unable to recover from the trauma of the war and suffering from depression, he committed suicide in March that year. Ten years later, a bronze cast of Seated Youth was erected as a war memorial at Duisburgs Cemetery of Honor (his birth city).
  8. Although Lehmbruck was not involved in the German Expressionist movement, his sculptures' emotiveness and elongated features have led historians to associate him with Expressionism.
  9. In the 1930s Nazis condemned his work as degenerate and removed it from public collections.
Amedeo Modigliani, Nude, 1917

School of Paris/ Les Maudits
  1. Amedeo Modigliani (1884-1920) as an Italian Jewish painter and sculptor who worked mainly in France. He is known for portraits and nudes in a modern style characterized by elongation of faces, necks, and figures that were not received well during his lifetime but later found acceptance.
  2. Example of the School of Paris, which is defined as a diverse group of similarly minded artists working in Paris during the interwar period, who shared an interest in redefining the figurative imagery and its role in modern painting
  3. Modigliani belonged to the group known as Les Maudits or the Cursed Ones which alluded to both the poverty of the artist and other members and the bohemian lifestyle
  4. The style of the nude becomes typical for Modigliani, with elongated shape of the female body curved slightly and exposing the subject's eroticism; the influence of Titian, especially of his Venus of Urbino, is important in this regard, as Modigliani reworks a motif of the nude, a perennial subject in Western art, during the modern period, considered pornographic because of their body hair (confiscated by police)
  5. The reworking of this subject becomes particularly important when considering the question of the gaze, especially in terms of the male spectator, who looks at the figure from above; such perspective implies the subject's availability for the viewer; there is no allusion to mythology or literary sources, but rather the nude is presented as is with her sexuality emphasized
  6. Due to the erotic content of this work, it was, along with other paintings of nudes by Modigliani, considered offensive and shocked the contemporary audience. 
  7. His career was so short that it is difficult to speak of a stylistic development, although a gradual transition can be seen from work inspired by the Symbolist painters, in which the figure is securely integrated in the space of an interior, toward a pattern of linear or sculptural detachment 
  8. All of his portraits and nudes resemble one another through their elegantly elongated features or their reference to forms deriving from Archaic art

Max Beckmann, The Descent from the Cross, 1917 
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

German Expressionism
  1. German Expressionism emerged in response to widespread anxiety about humanity's increasingly discordant relationship with the world and accompanying lost feelings of authenticity and spirituality. 
  2. The Expressionists looked in particular towards Post-Impressionists like Van Gogh, Munch, and Ensor: they used strong colors to convey psychic turmoil.
  3. Beckmann (Leipzig, 1884 - New York, 1950) served as a medical corpsman (working in field hospitals) for Germany in World War I, over the course of which he encountered many dead and grievously wounded soldiers. Beckmann described the war as doing "great injury to his soul." (He had a nervious breakdown in 1915). His practice shifted substantially, and his compositions were subsequently filled with often-chaotic and horrifying imagery. 
  4. At the time when Beckmann created The Descent he had previously made only prints for a few years, and only recently returned to painting. 
  5. In The Descent from the Cross, a darkened sun glows behind Christs removal from the cross. The figures are rendered from multiple perspectives, perhaps reflecting the influence of Cubism. Christs corpse - covered in bruises and wounds, and apparently in the midst of rigor mortis - stretches across the full canvas. The relative scale of the figures recalls the Northern Early Renaissance masters whose work - in which figures of greater importance were depicted at a greater size -  influenced Beckmann at this time. 
  6. The Christian concept of guilt and atonement became Beckmanns leitmotiv for several years following his return from the war. The Descent... and The Woman Taken in Adultery (painted around the same time) are companion pieces of almost identical size, forming pendants perhaps referencing the format of the diptych. From 1916 to 1918, Beckmann attempted a gigantic Resurrection, which he left unfinished, and in 1917 he also painted an Adam and Eve. 
  7. In November of 1917, an exhibition of Beckmann's new graphics opened at J. B. Neumann's gallery in Berlin. On this occasion the artist formulated his program in a few laconic sentences: "The editor of this catalogue has asked me to write something about my work. I don't have much to prescribe: Be a child of your times-Naturalism toward your own ego-Objectivity toward inner visions. My love belongs to the four great painters of manly mysticism: Malesskircher, Grunewald, Bruegel, and Van Gogh.
  8. Beckmann possibly made this painting to answer a challenge posed by curator Gustav Hartmann to create a modern work as powerful as medieval German art, which they had viewed together in Frankfurt (along with works by Italian, Flemish, and German Old Masters that significantly influenced Beckmann's style).
Kazimir Malevich, Suprematist Composition: White on White, 1918

Suprematism
1. In 1915, Malevich exhibited 39 entirely nonobjective paintings in a gallery in present-day St. Petersburg (see Zero-Ten: The Last Futurist Exhibition 1915): a series of black-on-white squares, circles and crosses; the most reductive, uncompromisingly abstract works of their time. He termed his new style Suprematism, which denotes the supremacy of pure feeling in creative art. Malevich: the significant thing is feeling as such, quite apart from the environment in which it is called forth
2. With his interest in the expressive qualities of geometric shapes, Malevich carried abstraction to an ultimate geometric simplification.
3. This constituted a new beginning for painting that corresponded to the social transformation in the years leading up to the Russian Revolution (1917).
4. Malevich thus formed one branch of the two dominant forms of early 20th century abstraction: on the one hand, the painterly expressionism of Kandinsky; on the other, the hard-edged geometric purity of Malevich; both were rooted in spiritual visions and ancient Russian traditions
5. White on White is from the final of his three stages of Suprematism (black; red or colored; white): the last stage stands for the complete renunciation of materiality, for white symbolizes the real concept of infinity, leading into a utopian world of pure form
6. Shows a white square floating weightlessly in a white field; Malevich studied aerial photography and wanted White on White to create a sense of floating and transcendence
7. But the picture is not impersonal: the artists hand can be discerned in the texture of the paint, the slight asymmetry of the square, the imprecisely ruled lines which have a breathing quality
8. In the 20s, during a tide of conservatism, Malevich was dismissed from his official post as director of a major Soviet arts organization and even briefly imprisoned and interrogated about his artistic philosophy; in his later work he returned to a more figurative style
Marcel Janco, Mask, 1919

Zurich Dada
Paper, cardboard, string, gouache, and pastel
  1. Janco created masks from torn and crumple scraps of paper, cardboard, cloth, and patchy paint for Dada performances at Cabaret Voltaire. The simple and disposable materials he used suggests that these masks were meant to be ephemeral, like the shows for which they were made.
  2. The masks would compel the wearer to act unpredictably, to lose inhibition. The wearer was meant to feel possessed by the spirit of the mask and transformed into a sort of shaman. The masks reflect Jancos faith in a direct art, magical, organic, creative like that of primitives. The influence of African masks is very clear in both the formal qualities and their performative, almost ritual use.
  3. The details of the face, with flattened planes and angular eyes and nose indicate the influence of Expressionism, Cubist collage assemblage, as well as Japanese and Greek theater design
  4. He does not control the accidental creases or tears in the materials, but uses them to increase the expressive force of the work. Demonstrates the importance of chance and spontaneity in the Dada project.

Georgia OKeeffe, MusicPink and Blue, II, 1919
Whitney Museum of American Art, New York

American abstraction
1.     For many artists in the early 20thcentury, music offered a model for expressing nonverbal emotional states and sensations. OKeeffe was fascinated with what she called the idea that music could be translated into something for the eye. 
2.     Her reference to music in the titles of her paintings derived equally from her belief that visual art, like music, could convey powerful  emotions independent  of representational subject matter. 
3.     In MusicPink and Blue II, the swelling, undulating forms imply a connection between the visual and the aural, while also suggesting the rhythms and harmonies that OKeeffe perceived in nature.
4.     OKeeffes first abstract works were inspired by the ideas of Arthur Wesley Dow, under whom she  studied from 1914-1916. Dow called on artists to reject  imitative representation in favour of expressing their feelings and thoughts through harmonious arrangements of line, color and tonal contrast. He saw music as the key to other fine arts and had his students draw their responses to music as an exercise of free expression.
5.     She favoured abstract forms in the beginning of her career, which critics misread as psychological expressions of her sexuality. Instead, she claimed that she intended  her abstract works to be the very personal expressions of the intangible, her feelings about the natural world.

Hannah Hch, Cut with the Kitchen Knife through the Beer Belly of the Weimar Republic, c. 1919
Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Preussischer Kulturbesitz, Nationalgalerie

Dada/Photomontage
  1. Hannah Hch was a member of the Berlin Dada movement and developed the art of photomontage. Hoch's photomontages advanced the absurd illogic of Dada by presenting chaotic, contradictory and satiric compositions about the failings of the Weimar government. This technique of taking words and images from the press to make new and subversive statements was highly innovative.
  2. Dada's equivalent of the Cubist collage, photomontage consisted almost entirely of "found" details in magazine photographs, usually combined in deliberately antilogical compositions.  This work was made from images culled from the Berliner Illustrirte Zeitung and other periodicals.
  3. Bursting with Dada energy, it is populated with well-known faces of the day. In the top right corner Hch pasted together images of "anti-Dada" figures of the Weimar government and representatives of the old empire, like the recently abdicated Wilhelm II, Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg, and President Friedrich Ebert. Elsewhere, fellow proponents of Dada including Raoul Hausmann, as well as Marx and Lenin, circus performers, athletes, actresses are ranged in opposition to these establishment figures. Most notably, Hoch juxtaposed herself with a map of Europes women suffrage to show the progress of women. Everyone is shown floating among the gears and ball-bearings of industrial production. The effect is one of visual confusion, yet a nonsense-narrative develops with sustained attention. Hoch's juxtapostions of German military leaders with exotic dancers provided a humorous critique that was central to Dada.
  4. The title's inclusion of kitchen knife and beer-belly, reveal the social commentary regarding gender issues in post-war Germany.  Hoch also promoted Dada in prominently placed cutout lettering - "Die Grosse Welt Dada" (The great Dada world). 
  5. Though one of Hch's earliest works, this large-scale, ambitious collage, is one of Dadas most recognized works. It symbolizes the piecing together of German society after WWI, and the social, political, and artistic hypocrisies of the era. The work encapsulates the eclecticism of Dadaism, but also makes a pointed political statement against the staid establishment; it is a carefully-crafted homage to anarchistic opposition, the redefinition of women's social roles, and the explosive growth of mass print media.
  6. It was exhibited in the First International Dada Fair, which took place in Berlin in 1920, and it was one of the most popular pieces in the show

Raoul Hausmann, Mechanical Head (Spirit of the Age), c.1920
Muse National dArt Moderne, Centre Pompidou, Paris

Berlin Dada
  1. Raoul Hausmann (1886-1971) was the leader of the Berlin Dada artists, arguably the most politically engaged group; he was nicknamed the Dadasoph because he was the groups chief theoretician and writer.  "The highest art," declared the First German Dada Manifesto in 1918, "will be the art which has been visibly shattered by the explosions of last week, which is forever trying to collect itself after yesterday's crash."
  2. The work is a commentary on what Hausmann saw the culturally and socially fragmented fabric of the modern society and his fellow Berliners in the aftermath of World War I, representing individuals not as unique and sophisticated individuals, but rather as mindless and mechanized beings; Hausmann said that the average German "has no more capabilities than those which chance has glued on the outside of his skull; his brain remains empty"
  3. Head of a mannequin with extraneous mechanical elements affixed to it appears exceptionally crude and anti-human and provides a stark contrast to the expressive and emotional faces carved by the Renaissance masters like Michelangelo or even the modernist sculptor Rodin; this use of additional, add-on element that make the head appear mechanical should also be understood in connection with the development of the discipline of facial reconstruction stemming from World War I injuries and the development of prosthetic elements to replace facial elements 
  4. Iconoclastic spirit of Duchamps readymades
  5. References the sense that people were pawns in the war
  6. engaging with the notion that modern media can be placed directly into your mind (i.e. dummy automaton without processing information), the tape measurer subverts man's control of nature, nature is defining us rather than us defining nature. Dada hates capitalism as a driving force of society so that wallet is representative of this
  7. The work can also be seen to evoke Hegel (German Idealist), for whom mind was the foundation of living (Phnomenologie des Geistes); by replacing the thoughts generated by mind with material and artificially affixed elements, the work provides a Marxist reversal of Hegel
  8. The groups in Germany were not as strongly anti-art as other groups. Their activity and art were more political and social, with corrosive manifestos and propaganda, satire, public demonstrations and overt political activities. The intensely political and war-torn environment of Berlin had a dramatic impact on the ideas of Berlin Dadaists. The art of the movement spanned visual, literary, and sound media, including collage, sound poetry, cut-up writing, and sculpture.
Sophie Taeuber, Dada Head, 1920

Zurich Dada
  1. Sophie Taeuber was one of the only female participants in Zurich Dada. 
  2. Taeuber's artistic practice was interdisciplinary, as was the case for other Zurich Dadaists (see for example Max Beckmann, who was a poet and piano player, as well as a philosopher, or Emmy Hennings, who was a singer and also made dolls and other objects). Tauber was a painter, sculptor, dancer, teacher, writer, and designer of textiles, fashion accessories, stage sets, marionettes, and interiors. Her background was in decorative painting and drawing and she taught textile design at the school of Applied Arts for 14 years. She was one of the first among the Zurich Dadaists to demonstrate the way that the applied arts could contribute to the development of abstract art.
  3. Taeuber and her future husband Hans Arp (m. 1922) were part of the second wave of Dada, for whom Dada was not without intention, but rather could perhaps mean anything at all. 
  4. Taeuber and Arp were suspicious of easel painting: We regarded [it] as characteristic of a pretentious and conceited world. Instead, they sought less individualistic forms, and often collaborated on interiors and collages. This head is likewise a painted surface which refuses the ego-centric history of easel painting, as well as that of portrait busts: the head is both anti-monumental and anti-mimetic. 
  5. The head is paint on turned wood, and is rendered at approximately life-size. In a self-portrait photograph with this head, Taeuber poses with it half-obscuring her face, like a mask. 
  6. Like many of the Zurich Dadaists, Tauber was interested in ritual. She studied under Rudolf von Laban, a great innovator in modern dance. She participated as both a choreographer and dancer at the Cabaret Voltaire, and created a series of marionettes in 1918, which this head recalls. 
  7. Taeuber is often said to have been inspired by the stylized features of Oceanic and Northwest Indian masks in creating her turned-wood Dada Heads, of which this object is one.
Fun fact: Art Since 1900 suggests that this series of works - two of which are subtitled Portrait of Hans Arp - could instead be signed the woman who mistook her husband for a hat stand. Theyve got jokes.

Aleksandr Rodchenko,
Oval Hanging Construction No. 12, c. 1920

Russian Constructivism
1. Having come in contact with the Constructivist works of Malevich and Tatlin, Rodchenko began to experiment with constructions in the mid-1910s. Constructivism was a utopian movement of Russian artists after the 1917 Revolution that attempted to achieve the full integration of art and life to foster the ideological aims of the new society. This was at a time when the Soviet regime was still encouraging experimentalism in the arts (until mid-1920s).
2. Rodchenko and other Constructivists believed that the artist could serve the revolution through a practical application of art to engineering, architecture, theater, graphic design (an idea which later was expressed through the name production art): the goal was to create a radically rational art for a new society, an art that takes place not on the wall, but in space; an art of physical and social involvement
3. This is an example from the experimental phase post-revolution, a three-dimensional object with planar elements which reveals the scientific bent of Constructivist and their interest in mathematics and geometry.
4. It is a nest of concentric oval circles, cut from a single piece of plywood. Can be collapsed after exhibiting and easily stored. Rodchenko also made versions based on triangle, square, hexagon, ellipse (all of which are now lost).
5. Has no base, no top or bottom, is weightless: suspension and movement replace modeling or carving of a central mass (continues the revolutions in sculpture begun by Braque, Picasso, Lissitzky, Tatlin)
6. Moves slowly in currents of air: bespeaks Constructivists interest in movement and fascination with space travel (looks like a chart of planetary orbits)
7. Rodchenko shone light onto the construction so that it would reflect off the sliver paint and underscore the dematerialization of the work.
8. After 1921 Rodchenko devoted himself to graphic, textile, theater design and photography. His work later became important for the American Minimalists in the 1960s.
Vladimir Tatlin, first model for the Monument to the Third International in the former Academy of Arts, Petrograd, 1920

Russian constructivism
Wood, Iron and glass
  1. The Tower, which was never fully realized, was intended to act as a fully functional conference space and propaganda center for the Communist Third International. It was part of Lenins plan for Monumental Propaganda that would replace the monuments of the tsarist period in favor of new ones that reflected the new soviet regime. When Tatlin took over the program, he shifted the focus form figurative sculptures of revolutionary heroes to abstraction, determining that an entirely new art be created to reflect the utopian radicality of the new Bolshevik movement.
  2. Its steel spiral frame was to stand at 1,300 feet, which would have made it taller than the Eiffel Tower which had inspired its design, and the tallest structure in the world at the time.
  3. The rising spirals, diagonal girder, and rotating internal volumes give symbolic form to the aspirations and dynamic forces of the world communist revolution. The planned materials of metal and glass were associated with modern engineering and construction technology, and signified the advanced, even futuristic, goals of communist society. This was further emphasized in the plan to have the interior volumes revolve mechanically, which symbolized the alignment of communist world revolution with the astronomical movement of the sun, earth, and moon, and also likened the new government to an efficient modern machine.
  4. The Monument stressed the Cominterns transparency to the people in its fully visible support structure and the glass interior volumes housing its various functions. The importance given to disseminating information and propaganda to the masses is also integral to the design and acknowledges the crucial role played by mass communication technologies in modern society and their power to promote world revolution.
  5. The tower was never built and is best known through photographs of a wooden model that he built with a group of students
  6. Tatlins combination of modern materials, rational structure, and utilitarian forms was an important example of how artists could synthesize the historically disparate roles and forms of art, craft, and engineering to contribute to the formation of a new world.
Otto Dix, Pragerstrasse, 1920

The New Objectivity Movement
1.     The New Objectivity movement in German art arose during the 1920s as a reaction against expressionism (rejected the self-involvement and romantic longings of the expressionists). It called for a return to unsentimental reality and a focus on the objective world. Their naturalistic depictions frequently portrayed Weimar society in a caustically satirical manner. 
2.     Otto Dix was a painter and printmaker, part  of the New Objectivity group, known for his ruthless and harshly realistic depictions of Weimar society and the brutality of war. Born of working-class parents, he was a proletarian by upbringing as well as by political conviction. Dixs combat experience made him fiercely anti-militaristic. His war paintings, gruesome depictions of unaccountable horrors, are rooted in the expressive realism of German late medieval and Renaissance art. 
3.     The figures dominating this painting are crippled war veterans. They are distorted and shock the viewer forcing us to confront the results of war- both physical and mental scars.
4.     The bright lurid colors he uses lend an intensity evocative of the bright pigments of commercial imagery. His paintings  attract the viewer with the colors before shocking them with its harrowing realism.
5.     Dix was exposed to diverse influences from Cubism to Dada, but from the beginning was concerned with uncompromising realism. This was a symptom of the postwar reaction against abstract, a reaction most marked in Germany.

George Grosz, Republican Automatons, 1920
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

New Objectivity
  1. Grosz was a painter as well as a printmaker known for pointed political satire and social criticism. His work from 1914 to 1917 shows the influence of Expressionism and Futurism, as well as of caricature.
  2. After observing the horrors of war as a soldier in World War I, Grosz focused his art on social critique. He became deeply involved in left-wing pacifist activity, publishing drawings in many satirical and critical periodicals and participating in protests and social upheavals. His drawings and paintings from the Weimar era sharply criticized what he viewed as the decay of German society.
  3. The traumatic experiences that drove George Grosz to rally against war, corruption, and what he saw as an immoral society created a particularly affecting and indelible artistic legacy. As a symbol of the revolution in Germany, his art was instrumental in awakening the general public to the reality of government oppression.
  4. This small sized painting (23 5/8 x 18 5/8," 60 x 47.3 cm) applies the style and motifs of De Chirico and the Metaphysical School to political satire. Empty-headed, blank-faced, and mutilated automatons parade loyally through the streets of a mechanistic metropolis on their way to vote as they are told.
  5. In works such as this, George Grosz comes closest to the spirit of the Dadaists and Surrealists.
  6. Grosz was also part of the Berlin Dada group. As a member of Berlin Dada from 1918 to 1920, he created mordantly satirical collages. In the 1920s his style became more naturalistic in depicting corrupt officers, war profiteers, exploitative industrialists, and sex workers.
  7. He was declared an ''enemy of the state' by the Nazi party and his works in German museums were confiscated or destroyed. He emigrated to New York in 1933, and one month before his death in 1959, returned to Berlin.

Amde Ozenfant, Guitar and Bottles, 1920
Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York

Purism
  1. Purism was developed by Ozenfant and architect and painter Le Corbusier in 1918. Drawing on pre-1914 Cubism (Analytic, rather than Synthetic, Cubism), particularly the coolly rational interpretation of Juan Gris, they dismissed its subsequent evolution as too decorative and unordered. 
  2. Ozenfant and Le Corbusier believed that it was a moral imperative that the chaos of the natural world should be dispelled by the organizing mechanisms of the human mind. (Contrast with the interruptions to order sought by Dada.) They articulated the doctrines of Purism in their book Aprs le cubisme (1917) and the first Purist exhibition the same year. 
  3. Ozenfant used the following metaphor to describe the function of rational thought: A lens concentrates the diffuse rays of the sun and creates fire by converging those rays. To converge is to refine something in nature, so as to render it more concentrated, compact, penetrative, intense: it helps to facilitate the manifestations of that phenomenon and to render it effective and useful for humanity.
  4. Like the return to neoclassicism among other artists of the same period, the Purists desire for simplicity and rationality was likely a manifestation of the desire for a return to order after the chaos of WWI. 
  5. To achieve a sense of fundamental order, Purism systematized expression of visual phenomena into a precise arrangement of modern, impersonal, universal forms, especially images of simple machine-made objects from everyday life. They rendered these as volumetric, geometric forms with simplified contours.
  6. Ozenfant painted a number of works with bottles and a guitar as their subjects 1920-21. These seem to allude to the compositional elements of early Cubist works: see, for example, Picassos Guitar (1912)

Le Corbusier, Still Life, 1920
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

Purism
1. Purism was an interwar variant on Cubism developed by Le Corbusier and Amde Ozenfant around 1918: sought a simple architectural structure and the elimination of all decorative ornateness and fantastic subjects; advocated instead a return to clear, precise, ordered forms that were expressive of the modern machine age
2. Amongst several painters who were attracted to a machine-like aesthetic (see also Lger Three Women 1921) during an interwar return to order and revival of a classical tradition in favor of more scandalous pre-war avant-garde experimentations  
3. Unlike Picasso and Braque, these later Cubists were prone to theorizing and published their ideas in journals and manifestos, where they attacked Cubism for having degenerated into an elaborate decoration (in their manifesto After Cubism from 1918 and in their review LEsprit nouveau from 1920-5).
4. The machine became the perfect symbol for the pure, functional painting they hoped to achieve (in his early architecture, Corbusier thought of the house as a machine for living)
5. Ozenfant and Le Corbusier defined painting as an association of purified, related, and architectured elements.
6. Still Life is a typical Purist painting: purified color scheme including only the neutrals (gray, black, and white) and monochromes of green. Le Corbusier applied the paint smoothly to enhance the sense of impersonal objectivity. He also repeated the rhythmic, curving contours of a guitar (a favorite Cubist motif, which the Purists eventually rejected for being too picturesque), in the shoulders of a bottle and in other objects on the table; by tilting the tops of the objects toward the spectator, he gave an added emphasis to their flatness.
7. Le Corbusier continued to paint throughout his career.

Kurt Schwitters, Merzbild 25A (Das Sternbild) [Stars Picture], 1920
Kunstsammlung NordrheinWestfalen, Dsseldorf

German Dada (Merz)
Assemblage
  1. While making reference to political conditions, Schwitters work was never explicitly political or satirical like the other German Dadaists. He established his own Dada variant in Hanover called Merz based on the idea that all values only in exist in relationship to one another, and one must not restrict themselves to a single material for risk of being small minded. The name was extracted from the work Kommerz (commerce).
  2. His collages which he called Merzbilder (Merz-pictures) made of rubbish gathered from the street, transformed the detritus of German culture into a fragile and strange beauty. To demonstrate the elegance found in the discarded every day material, he used a cubist-derived grid
  3. In Merzbild 25A he moves into the three-dimensional realm, and places a particular interest in the physically of the surface, more so than his other photomontaging contemporaries. This interest in building beyond the two dimensional space of the canvas evolved into a Gesamtkunstwerk in which he sought to incorporate every kind of material until it filled a room in his house in Hanover (Merzbau)
  4. The extracted text from German newspapers in this image refers to recent political events (one of the snippets contains the word corrupt)
Joseph Stella, New York Interpreted: The Voice of the City,19202

cubo-futurism
1.     Joseph Stella was an Italian-born American Futurist painter, best known for his depictions of industrial America, especially through his images of the Brooklyn Bridge. 
2.     Stella has been associated with the Precisionist movement, which emerged after WWI in America in the 1920s and celebrated the new American landscape of skyscrapers, bridges and factories; however, his work is stylistically closer to Cubo-Futurism.
3.     A painting of five panels, each over seven feet high; evokes the city through massive scale, night-time luster and linear force. Here, Stella conceives New York as a circuit of movement, with each panel devoted to a site of transportation. 
4.     The image is a pictorial version the poetic trope of personification. As the Expressionist Franz Marc does with nature, Stella uses a Cubo-Futurist line to vitalize the city, to give it a voice to  render it more than human.
5.     Stella saw New York as an apotheosis of the new civilization with the bridge as its shrine; his painting is a kind of modern alter-piece in which the city appears as a cathedral, with its skyscrapers, bridges, avenues as columns, vaults and naves.
Man Ray, Gift, 1921

Dada/Proto-Surrealist

  1. Man Ray was an American artist who spent most of his career in Paris. He was a pioneering figure of interwar art, a significant contributor to Dada and Surrealism, although his ties to both were informal. He produced works in a variety of media but considered himself a painter above all, although he is best known for his fashion and portrait photography, and his photograms, "rayographs."
  2. In 1921, disappointed that Dada had failed to ignite an artistic revolution in NY, he moved to Paris. Within a year he had his first solo show, including paintings, aerographs, and collages, mostly brought from New York. Among the works exhibited was this unlisted sculpture, Gift, a flatiron with fourteen brass tacks glued in a column down its center. According to his autobiography Self-Portrait, the object was made quickly the day of the opening as a gift for the gallery owner, poet Philippe Soupault, after having drinks with composer Erik Satie. With its menacing blend of domesticity and sadomasochism, the object apparently attracted unusual attention but by the end of the day had vanished.
  3. Although made in the spirit of Dada and Duchamp's "assisted" readymades, The Gift prefigured by several years the Surrealist object, three-dimensional works that included found objects, modified objects, and sculpted objects.  It is considered a Surrealist icon that anticipated the exposure of hidden desires found in subsequent surrealist objects.
  4. Gift exemplifies two important features of Surrealist objects.  First, an everyday object has been changed so that its original function is denied. Ray's simple addition of tacks subverted the iron's utilitarian function, transforming a useful device into something alien, potentially destructive, and threatening. Second, his alteration gives a common object a symbolic function. The flatiron, associated with social expectations of propriety and middle-class values, becomes a subversive attack on social expectations. Even if Rays iconoclastic object is no longer used for pressing clothes, it resonates with violent possibilities. It also exemplifies Ray's emphasis on the juxtaposition of two unrelated elements in his future assemblages, the iron representing domesticity/femininity; the tacks, carpentry/masculinity.
  5. The nails and burning metal suggest a violent eroticism at odds with the works title, the French word for gift. The original version was lost but became well-known through his photograph of it. When there was a greater commercial interest in Ray's objects, Gift was recreated in an edition of eleven by Galleria Il Fauno, Turin, in 1972.
Fun fact: All 11 versions were made using different irons from the interwar period, as it proved difficult to find identical irons dating from the 1920s and 1930s.
Max Ernst, Celebes, 1921

German Dada/Proto-Surrealist
  1. Max Ernst (1891-1976) was a German painter, sculptor, graphic artist, and poet. He was a primary pioneer of the Dada movement and Surrealism.
  2. Ernst often re-used found images, and either added or removed elements in order to create new realities, all the more disturbing for being drawn from the known world. Ernst used collage from 1919 onwards to produce bizarre combinations of images, though no preliminary collages or sketches were made from it.
  3. At the end of the war, he discovered Zurich Dada and the paintings of De Chirico and Klee, which influenced his painting style, which is evident in Celebes. 
  4. Ernst, following the example of De Chirico and fortified by his own gothic imagination, became a principal founder of the wing of Surrealism that utilized Magic Realismthat is, precisely delineated, recognizable objects, distorted and transformed, but nevertheless presented with a ruthless realism that throws their newly acquired fantasy into shocking relief.
  5. The piece was painted in Cologne in 1921 and was Max Ernst's first large picture. The images are irrational and threatening or unexplainable.
  6. The painting's inexplicable juxtapositions, such as the enigmatic headless female figure and the elephant-like creature, suggest the imagery of a dream and the Freudian technique of free association (also employed by De Chirico).
  7. The monster presented a horned head with sightless eyes. Its horns (projecting on the left) suggested a second head (or perhaps the real head?). The top is surmounted by a brightly-colored construction containing a mysterious eye. Three upright objects stand around it, while in the bottom corner a headless mannequin figure with a raised arm appears to be beckoning the monster towards it. The mannequin wears a surgical glove, a common Surrealist symbol.
  8. The central round shape in this painting derives from a photograph of a Sudanese corn-bin from the Konkombwa people (found in an English anthropological journal), which Ernst transformed into a sinister mechanical monster.
  9. The work's title comes from a childish German rhyme that goes: "The elephant from Celebes / has sticky, yellow bottom grease / The elephant from Sumatra/ always f*cks his grandmamma / The elephant from India / can never find the hole ha-ha."
  10. Influenced by the German Romanticism of Bocklin and the Gothic quality of Duhrer remained consistent throughout all of his series
Fernand Lger, Three Women (Le Grand Djeuner), 1921

Synthetic Cubism 
  1. In Synthetic Cubism after the war, Picasso generally either divided the canvas into thirds, or superimposed elements into a an interlacing of figure and ground. Lger took the former approach in his oil painting Three Women, although the space has a shallow depth, and the back wall dissolves into near abstraction, pushing forward and making the two figures at left seem to float in space.
  2. Lger combines Cubism with the return to neoclassical themes that grew out of the post-WWI return to order: the depiction of three nude women as the three graces (daughters of Zeus) has been used by artists since at least the Renaissance, showing the unclothed female form from all angles. Three cheers for voyeurism! As in Renaissance depictions of the three graces, the female form in Three Women is not specific, but rather is a generalized excuse for image-making.
  3. The edges of the three figures seem at first glance to be defined by a sharp contrast between the contours and colors of their bodies and the yellow-and-patterned couch. The bodies of the two figures at left dissolve into a series of black-and-white, starkly shadowed volumes, however, making differentiation between figure and ground difficult. Is the figure at right sitting on the central figures legs? 
  4. Lger was a combat engineer in WWI, and was particularly enamored of the smooth geometric forms of machine aesthetics. Here, the womens nude bodies and hair and the frame of the couch are rendered like gleaming, interchangeable machine-made products.
  5. Reclining nude in background: reference to the chalky skin and stark contours of Manets Olympia? Theres what looks like a black cat behind the figure at the right, as there is in Manets painting. 
  6. This painting was one of a series of paintings and drawings of groups of three women in domestic settings that Lger created 1920-21. During this time, his practice was influenced by both Synthetic Cubism and Purism, which rejected Synthetic Cubism as too decorative. A graphite-on-paper drawing that Lger made in 1920 - also titled Three Women and currently in the Mets collection - was reproduced in the January 1921 issue of the periodical LEsprit Nouveau, the mouthpiece of Purism. Despite the clearly figurative imagery, it was simply titled Composition.

Oskar Schlemmer, Study for Triadic Ballet, c. 192123
Museum of Modern Art, New York

Bauhaus
1. Schlemmer taught design, sculpture and mural painting at the Bauhaus from 1920-9; although mainly a visual artist, he was made head of the experimental Theater Workshop at the Bauhaus in Dessau, which inaugurated a period of theatrical experimentation
2. Schlemmer's ideas on art were complex and challenging even for the progressive Bauhaus movement. His work was a rejection of pure abstraction, instead retaining a sense of the human figure: he represented bodies as architectural forms, reducing the figure to a rhythmic play between convex, concave and flat surfaces.
3. The Triadic Ballet was created before WWI but not performed until 1922 in Stuttgart. The ballet became the most widely performed avant-garde artistic dance, helping to spread the ethos of the Bauhaus.
4. The idea of the ballet was based on the principle of the trinity: it has 3 acts, 3 participants (2 male, 1 female), 12 dances and 18 costumes (triad = set of three). Building on multiples of three, the artist explained, transcended the egotism of the individual and dualism of the couple, emphasizing the collective.
5. Following the devastations of WWI (in which he served), Schlemmer took an interest in the body in relation to the machine: he encased his performers in colored, geometric shapes of wood, metal and cardboard; costumes designed to limit the dancers range of motion (compare Hugo Balls Magical Bishop costume 1916); transformed the human body of the dancers into geometric, abstracted, kinetic sculptures; the performers become living sculptures, as if part of the scenery
6. Mounted his spatial-plastic costumes as sculptures for exhibition purposes (i.e. at MoMA and the V&A)
7. The ballet was performed against a backdrop of yellow, white and black; envisioned the stage as an abstract, gridded space through which the performers moved according to a mathematically precise choreography (different from the anarchy, noise and spontaneity of Dadas Cabaret Voltaire performances)
8. Use of deep perspectival space and uncanny, looming figures is reminiscent of De Chirico and foreshadows Surrealism
9. Schlemmer resigned from the Bauhaus at a time when the curriculum was becoming increasingly politicized and prioritized practical, industrial training over artistic production and experimentation; Nazis destroyed his murals at Weimar in 1929; despite Nazi assaults on his degenerate art Schlemmer remained in Germany until his death in 1943
Lyubov Popova, Stage design for Vsevolod Meyerholds The Magnanimous Cuckold, 1922

Russian Constructivism (Cubo-Futurism)
  1. Following the 1917 October Revolution, Popova and many other constructivists abandoned tradition media in favor of production art intending to merge art with technology in products that ranged from utilitarian household objects to textile design, propaganda posters, and stage sets for political rallies.
  2. Popova renounced easel painting in 1921 and made theater designs including this one for Vsevolod Meyerhold, one of the leading figures of avant-garde theater.
  3. The set was organized according to the principles that informed Popovas paintings, like a large constructivist environment it consisted of arrangements of geometrical shapes within a structure of horizonal and vertical elements.
  4. The set design responded to a set of demands Meyerhold had for a new theater: mobile and stage that could be easily dismantled and transported, active and responsive to his stylized biomechanic acting exercises, and colorful to demonstrate a utopian future. Her design included multi-level platforms, staircases, revolving doors, three weeks and spinning props, one of the first sets to incorporate moving parts.
  5. The actors were a key part of the design and invited to use the set as a living prop throughout the performance. They feature as walking sculptures and bring to life the dynamic movement at the center of Popovas work

John Marin, Lower Manhattan (Composition Derived from Top of Woolworth Building), 1922
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

1.     John Marin was an American painter and printmaker especially known for his expressionistic watercolor views of Manhattan. 
2.     The late watercolors of Cezanne were an important source of inspiration and Cubist structure remained a controlling force in the cityscapes and landscapes he painted throughout his life.
3.     In this watercolor, an explosion of buildings erupts from a black circular form containing a sunburst center, a cut-out form that Marin attached to the paper with thread. He reinforced the transparent, angular strokes of the watercolor of graphic force that vibrates with the clamor and speed of the city.
4.     His introduction to Alfred Stieglitz in 1909 marked the beginning of a long relationship (he was one of the artists Stieglitz promoted). While Marin remained largely unaware of new movements in European art until 1910, through Stieglitzs 291 gallery, he became familiar with Cubism and the various schools of German expressionism. Influenced by those movements, his own style matured into a very personal form of expressionism. 
5.     While watercolor was used to produce delicate transparent effects, Marins command over the medium enabled him to render the monumental power of New York. His concern with force and motion led him to produce such views of Manhattan, in which the objective reality is hardly discernible amidst the activity of the composition.
Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, model for a glass skyscraper, 1922

Expressionist/International Style
  1. Mies van der Rohe is regarded as one of the most influential architects and architectural theorists of the 20th century. He served as the third and last director of the Bauhaus in Dessau from 1930 to 1933.
  2. His work is unmistakable in its clarity and the rigor with which it embodies the principles of rationalism and functionalism, as well as in its spatial qualities, material expression and detailing. Mies had four guiding principles: the search for clarity of construction; reduction to a few formal elements and simple architectural design; a constructional logic derived from the materials; and the principle of simplicity and continuity between indoors and outdoors. Space for Mies was something that continues beyond its physical limits and creates connections between inside and outside.
  3. For Mies, technological advances were a driving force of architecture, a spirit of the times that architecture should embrace and express.  Between 1921 and 1925 he developed five visionary studies, including this amoeba-like design for a Glass Skyscraper (1922) consisting of a core and three wings with rounded forms, which followed his radical proposal for the Friedrichstrasse Skyscraper Project (1921), the first example of his skin-and-bones architecture that was to dominate his later designs. Although none of the five projects were realized because they were highly idealized, they were presented in international exhibitions on modern architecture. To this day, they are regarded as remarkably innovative designs and the degree zero of his career and of a certain strain of modern architecture.
  4. The importance of glass as a material for Mies is evident in this design, where the window as a link to the surroundings and indicator of human scale was replaced by a facade of continuous glass planes that responds universally to its surroundings and became generalized as an expression of the International Style. It also reflected the more fantastic visions of Expressionist architects and artists, who were drawn to glass as a symbol of purity and renewal. Mies interpreted transparency in two respects: literally, as a property of light- and air-permeable materials and figuratively, as a means of spatial arrangement in which different spaces can be seen at once. 
  5. The unprecedented design is distinguished by its crystalline plan, the daring use of glass, and an expressive silhouette that seemed to owe nothing to history. Conceived only a few years after the end of WWI, this seminal project presented a bold vision of the skyscraper as a new architectural typology for the modern metropolis, anticipating the proliferation of the tall steel-and-glass buildings that have since become ubiquitous in cities worldwide.
  6. A decade later Mies took part, together with Le Corbusier, Walter Gropius and J.J.P. Oud, in the Modern Architecture (1932) exhibition curated by Philip Johnson and Henry-Russel Hitchcock at the MoMA in New York, catapulting him into the limelight in the USA.

Man Ray, Untitled, 1922
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

1. Man Ray (1890-1976) was a contemporary of Picabia and Duchamp. In 1921 Man Ray moved from New York to Paris, where he developed his 'Rayographs.' -These photos were made by placing objects (such as the thumbtacks, coil of wire, and other circular forms) on a sheet of photosensitized paper and exposing it to light (like Anna Atkin's cyanotypes of the previous century).
  2. Ray had taken up photography in 1915 through his association with Stieglitz in New York. Man Ray had photographed everyday objects before, (defamiliarized) but these unique, cameraless,  visionary images immediately put the photographer on par with the avant-garde painters of the day that used collage. In proper Dada manner, the technique was supposedly discovered 'accidentally' in the darkroom.
  3. Hovering between the abstract and the representational, the rayographs revealed a new way of seeing that delighted the Dadaist poets who championed his work, and that pointed the way to the dreamlike visions of the Surrealist writers and painters who followed.
  4. Made using similar technique to the photogram. Some of the earliest photograms were by Talbot. A photogram is a photographic image made without a camera: objects are placed directly onto the surface of a light sensitive material (i.e. photographic paper) and exposed to light. A negative shadow image results, in tones of white, gray and black, depending on the transparency of the objects used.
  5. Early scientific uses of the photogram reflected and fuelled interests in chemistry and botany. In modernism, there was a large push for abstract representation after the horrors of World War I, and the photogram became regarded as an art object. The photogram, with its propensity for random, abstract composition as well as the element of the unknown it could achieve during exposure, was the ideal Dada medium.

Fun Fact: My Duchamp professor always used to unironically say things about Duchamp and Man Ray mucking around in the darkroom.
El Lissitzky, Proun Room, 1923 (1965 reconstruction)

Proun / Russian Constructivism
  1. Between 1919 and 1927 El Lissitzky produced a large body of paintings, prints, and drawings that he referredto as Proun (pronounced pro-oon), an acronym for "project for the affirmation of the new" in Russian. He believed that after the Russian Revolution, art would be remade as a system that blurred distinctions between real and abstract--an interchange between art and architecture, or art and utility. 
  2. Lissitzky was influenced by Kazimir Malevichs Suprematism. Lissitzky studied under Malevich and eventually taught alongside him at the Vitebsk art school.
  3. Lissitzky was trained as an architect before WWI, and at this time was increasingly interested in phenomenological experience of works of art--as was his friend Kurt Schwitters (see for reference Schwitters Merzbau). 
  4. The Proun Room was created for the Great Berlin Art Exhibition of 1923. For it, Lissitzky transformed his ideas into what we would now call an immersive installation for the first time, designing the walls and ceilings in geometric shapes and reliefs. 
  5. The museum director Alexander Dorner called for the museum to become a place for collaboration between author, object, and spectator, mediated through increased tactility. For Lissitzky, that meant a transformation of artwork from cultic, transhistorical object to an experience that was exhibition- and temporally-specific. 
  6. This transformation of the museum experience dovetailed with Lissitzkys own politics: he saw the museum as being transformed into an institution of historicization and archival order. 
Fun fact: Schwitters and Lissitzky met in 1922, and in 1923 Schwitters invited Lissitzky to design and co-edit an issue of Merz, Lissitzkys magazine. The issue - called Nasci (born or becoming) and published in 1924 - was dedicated to the convergence of Constructivist and Dadaist ideals.

Gerrit Rietveld, Living and dining area,
Schrder House, 192324

Dutch De Stijl Architecture
1. Neutral during World War I and thus isolated from experiments with abstraction in both Russia and France, Holland developed its own idiosyncratic form of modernist abstraction called De Stijl (after a journal published by Theo van Doesburg from 1917-1928). The central tenets of de Stijl were: devaluation of tradition, valuation of abstraction, simplification, clarity, order, formal purity, balance, proportion
2. Although with its flat roofs and functional interiors De Stijl architecture is a forerunner of the International Style that would come to dominate monumental building in the US, Dutch architecture was domestic in function and thus smaller in scale.
3. Rietvelds Schrder House (made for a wealthy socialite and mother of three) is one of the most complete statements of de Stijl in domestic architecture. It is made of detached interlocking planes of rectangular slabs, unadorned piping, cantilevered roofs (reminiscent of Constructivist sculptures, which De Stijl artists learned about after the war through Lissitzky)
4. Most remarkable for its open-plan interior with sliding and revolving partitions for maximum flexibility of movement (almost no fixed walls): reflects Mrs. Schrders progressive social ideals and commitment to a new openness about relationships within their own families and to truth in their emotional lives; bourgeois notions of respectability and propriety, with their emphasis on discipline, hierarchy, and containment would be eliminated through architectural design
5. The facades are a collage of planes and lines purposely detached from, and seeming to glide past, one another. Primary colors strengthen the plasticity of the facades and emphasize the geometric, box-like construction. Rectilinear lines and planes flow from outside to inside, blurring distinctions between interior and exterior space.
6. Mrs. Schrder (mother of three) lived in the house for 60 years and renovated it in the 1970s and 80s; today it is open to the public.
El Lissitzky, The Constructor (SelfPortrait), 1924

Russian Constructivism
Gelatin Silver Print
  1. In this double image, the artists face is imposed on an image of his hand holding a compass over grid paper merging Lissitzkys role as a photographer (eye) and constructor of images/architect (hand) in a single image. The image seems to exemplify the social role of the artist as constructor and engineer after 1917
  2. The overlapping images highlight his eye suggesting that insight is passed through the eye and transmitted to the hand and then to paper by tools of production. The image celebrates such tools, both in the compass, as well as in the camera itself, demonstrating its revolutionary capacities. The camera became the Constructivists most effective tool for propagandizing, and Lissitsky himself published many essays championing the medium.
  3. The work puts the act of seeing center stage and contests the reliance of straight photography as a communicator of unmediated truth. By manipulating the photograph in this way, he impels the viewer to reconsider the medium and demonstrates the ability for photography and photomontage to achieve visual poetry.
  4. The work is actually devised from six different exposures.
  5. In the stenciled letters and the underlying grid, Lissitzky makes a clear nod to cubist collage as he began to explore a new form of photomontage as it related to constructivism.
Constantin Brancusi, The Beginning of the World, 1924

Romanian artist Constantin Brancusi was known for his abstract sculptures of ovoid heads, characterised by a restrained, elegant use of pure form and exquisite finishing. 
2.     After moving to Paris, he was invited to work as  one of the fifty assistants for Auguste Rodin. After just one month in Rodins studio, Brancusi left the position to adopt an approach to sculpture that could be said to be opposite of Rodins industrialized methods.
3.     Using wood or stone he was able to salvage (too poor to buy his materials) he began to work without the intermediary of the clay or plaster model, carving directly into the block instead. The direct wood carving were also associated with the rural wood carving traditions of his native land, reinforcing his anti-establishment position.
4.     Yet, he resisted associations to primitivism in his work, in an effort to stand apart from the rest of the Parisian avant-garde, and focus instead on the presumed timelessness and universality of his work. In this search for the historically unmediated, he pursued forms of increasing simplification and purity. 
5.     The reduced compact form of this sculpture refers to not only the beginning of the  world, but also to  the origins and mystery of human life. The high finishes  that Brancusi applied to his works, meticulously and arduously hand polishing the surface to a mirrorlike shine, only reinforce the sense of perfection.

Aleksandr Rodchenko,
Untitled advertising poster, 1924

Constructivism/Photomontage
  1. Rodchenko was a painter, photographer, filmmaker, set designer, teacher, and a pioneer of graphic design in the USSR.  He was a co-founder of Constructivism with Tatlin, reveled in the freedoms thrown up by the Russian Revolution and was fiercely committed to liberating art for the masses. 
  2. Impressed by the photomontage of the German Dadaists, Rodchenko began his own photomontages in 1923 employing found images and later shooting his own photographs. In 1924, he produced this, his most famous advertising poster for the Soviet publisher, Gosizdat, featuring Lilya Brik, who sports a simple kerchief, a sign of the peasant classes, with hand to mouth, joyfully shouting, Books (Please)! In All Branches of Knowledge. A commission from the State Publishing House in Leningrad, the poster bolstered the new governments image as committed to education and literacy.
  3. Brik was an author, actress and socialite, member of Russias cultural avant-garde, and most notably the muse and lover of poet Vladimir Mayakovsky, with whom she had a high-profile and adulterous affair. She was featured in many of Rodchenko's photographs, posters, and publications.  
  4. This poster shows the striking typographical innovations of the Russian avant-garde: unification of text and visual materials, dynamic diagonal compositions, geometric elements and strident colors that trumpet modernity, and the socialist ideals of education for women and peasants.
  5. The poster appeared on the cover of LEF (Left Front of Arts), the most dynamic avant-garde journal of the early Soviet era, which became a model of constructivist design.
  6. Constructivism emerged as a movement in post-revolutionary Russia that sought a new approach to making objects that would be as radical as the political changes. The traditional concern with composition was "abolished" and replaced with "practical construction" and a renewed attention to the technical character of materials, that was meant to replace the "artist's speculative activity."
  7. When he died in 1956, despite his artistic accomplishments and having founded 22 provincial museums along with Vladimir Tatlin as part of the Museum of Artistic Culture, Rodchenko had been largely written out of Soviet history by the Kremlin as Stalin had deemed constructivism to be "dangerously subversive."
Fun fact: The poster has been reworked into other designs, including as cover art for the Scottish indie band Franz Ferdinand (album You Could Have It So Much Better, 2004).
Joan Mir, The Kiss, 1924

Biomorphic surrealism
  1. Joan Miro (1893-1983) Began in the late teens in Barcelona as a Fauve-derived painter, absorbed the lessons of Cubism, arrived in Paris in the early twenties and by 1923 was assimilated to the circle of poets and artists around Andr Breton.
  2. The mid-1920s "dream paintings" such as The Kiss are read by some as erotic recordings of Matisse's work from around 1911.
  3. In The Kiss, fields of intense color are allowed to spread uninterrupted over the surface, so disembodied is the drawing within them. The drawing within is performed as a kind of calligraphy that converts all bodies to the transparency and weightlessness of the written sign.
  4. Typical of his use of biomorphic forms that evoke living forms (cells), or geometric shapes and semi-abstracted objects that call forth poetic associations/metaphors. Compared to his more complex paintings like The Hunter (1924), it employs more elementary forms that are open to plural meanings.
  5. The calligraphic/biomorphic form at the center evokes the number eight, the sign of infinity; with the red bar at the center, it also indicates joining of two cells in erotic contact.
  6. In this way, the picture could serve as an emblem for all Surrealist image-making: the emotional force released by the contact of two sexually charged "distant realities."
  7. Biomorphic Surrealism models artistic design elements on naturally occurring patterns or shapes reminiscent of nature and living organisms.
