  1. While in the early 1930s, Italian governmental style looked back to showy nationalistic monumentalism, a group of young architects called Gruppo 7 got together in 1933 to call for a functional and rational architecture that would value form over surface.
  2. Casa del Fascio is one of few buildings that came out of this movement, and was commissioned by the local fascist party as its headquarters
  3. The structure is a perfect half-cube, adhering to a strict rational geometry. Each of the buildings four facades is different, hinting at the internal layout and rhythmically balancing the open and closed spaces.  On every side except the south-east elevation which articulates the main stair, the windows and the external layers of the building are employed in such a way to express the internal atrium. Inside, cantilevered stairways and offices are arranged around a great covered courtyard illuminated from above by skylights in concrete-frame glass panels.
  4. The glass doors that close off the entrance foyer could be opened electronically to unite the inner courtyard to the exterior pizza, allowing for the uninterrupted flow of mass demonstrations from street to interior, fulfilling its original role as a massive set piece for fascist rallies.
  5. It was frescoed with abstract paintings by artist Mario Radice

Berenice Abbott, New York at Night, 1933
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

Straight Photography
1.     Berenice Abbott was an American photographer best known for her photographs of architecture and urban design in New York City. 
2.     She first became involved with photography in 1923 in Paris, when Man Ray hired  her as a darkroom assistant. It was here that she was introduced to Eugne Atget, who photographed in the early 1900s. Influenced by Atget and her years among the Parisian avant-garde, Abbott inevitably photographed her subjects in modernist, abstract terms.
3.     Upon her return to New York in 1929 (with the goal of finding an American publisher for Atgets photographs), Abbott fell in love with Manhattan, much as Atget had with Paris. First working alone and then for the WPA, she  set herself the task of capturing the inner spirit and driving force of the metropolis, as well as its outward aspect. 
4.     Abbotts ideas about New York were influenced by Lewis Mumfords historical writings from the early 1930s which divided American history into a series of technological eras. Abbott, like Mumford, was hopeful that through urban planning, Americans would be able to wrest control of their cities away from paleotechnic forces and bring about a more humane neotechnic era. Their ideologies are evident in her photographs from this era, composed to make the buildings look downright menacing.
5.     The status and prestige that Abbott enjoyed in Paris did not carry over to the male-dominated field of American photography, rooted firmly in Pictorialism. She critiqued the  works of Steichen and Steiglitz for their tendency to romanticize the American landscape, and as a result was unable to secure spaces at galleries or have her work shown at museums.
Brassa, Nude, 1933

Surrealism

  1. French photographer, draughtsman, sculptor, and writer of Hungarian birth. In 1925 he adopted the name Brassai, derived from that of his native town. He is best known for photographs of Paris at night, in which he documented its streets, architecture, society, and nightlife during the interwar years. These were collected and published as Paris de nuit in 1933.
  2. His photographs caught the attention of Andr Breton and the Surrealists, which led to a ten year association with the group, although Brassa never called himself a Surrealist and maintained that his photographs were objective. He considered the surreal aspect of his images as "the real rendered fantastic by vision."
  3. One of Brassas most abstract nudes, this image was published in the inaugural issue of Minotaure, the Surrealist avant-garde magazine circulated between 1933 and 1939. Nude was accompanied by Maurice Raynal's essay on the "Diversity of the human body."
  4. Here he transforms the female nude into curves and shapes, suggestive of its corporeality. He focused on the woman's torso twisted at an angle to reveal the outline of her hip, waist, breast, and arm. The woman's head and legs are cropped, making her body seem like a floating organic form on a neutral ground (textile) in a reverie of desire. 
  5. The female nude was a subject he dealt with extensively in his drawings and sculptures, but his headless nudes held special appeal for the Surrealists. Brassa contributed about 150 photographs to Minotaure, including his series of photo-conceptual works, Involuntary Sculptures, close-ups of the bizarre shapes formed by mundane objects (i.e. cigarette butts, ticket stubs and other trash), accompanied by captions written by Salvador Dali. 
  6. The breakdown of the female form here has been likened to his transformation of a female body into a phallic shape in his Nude (1934-in second link). Brassas transformation of the female figure into fetish objects is a hallmark of Surrealism that reflects the influence of Freuds psychoanalytic theory on art of the early twentieth century.
Henri CartierBresson, Andalucia, Seville, 1933

Street Photography
Influenced by French Surrealist Photography
  1. Cartier-Bressons early photographs show the influence of both Cubism and Surrealism. He used a small 35mm Leica camera and captured juxtapositions of the everyday, recording 'found images' like Seville, Spain.
  2. He is broadly classified as a photojournalist, but his images have little to do with narrative or reportage of fact. Influenced by Breton's ideas, he sought to 'trap' life in a single photograph and allowed his viewfinder to 'discover' compositions which he would pounce upon.
  3. His images were uncropped and capture 'the decisive moment'
  4. In 1932, traveled in Italy, Spain, and Mexico, seeking out the world of the "dispossessed, the marginal, and the illicit," a world far from his bourgeois Paris upbringing, but a world which he eagerly accepted as his own
  5. Spanish Civil War broke out soon afterwards, affecting many cities Cartier-Bresson passed through Seville was where the first shots were fired, and the photowith its ruined buildings and crippled childrenbecame associated with the horrors of that war, even though it was made three years earlier
  6. Used by Breton in his book to illustrate his chapter on the Spanish Civil War.
  7. Children playing amid ruins. The image is a juxtaposition of art and life, illusion and reality, and youth and old age. It is a complex dialogue within a moment of reality. Not entirely clear where exactly in the city he took this photo, or how the ruins come to be. 
  8. Ambiguous space-broken wall in the foreground, literally acting as frame/window to the actions of the children and ruins in the background. His usual journalistic eye was at work, depicting youthful vigor sprouting out of decayed detritus.
Andr Kertsz, Distortion No. 4, 1933

Surrealish* Photography
  1. Kertsz (1894-1985) moved to Paris from Budapest in 1925. Kertsz was a virtuoso in using the 35mm Leica, both as a pioneer of modern photojournalism and as an experimental photographer. He was friends with Brassa, a fellow Hungarian and photojournalist who he introduced to small-format cameras. 
  2. The market for Kertszs 
  3. Kertsz had long been interested in mirrors, reflections, and the idea of distorting the human figure, but prior to 1933, he had not yet used mirrors in his photography as a distorting device. In 1933, when the risqu French mens magazine Le Sourire (The Smile) commissioned him to make a series of figure studies, Kertsz used three mirrors (possibly from a Parisian amusement park) and a camera designed to expose 9-by-12-centimeter negatives fitted with an early zoom lens. He spent four weeks making about two hundred negatives. Later the same year, Kertsz published another five of the pictures under the headline Kertsz et son miroir in the periodical Arts et Mtiers Graphiques (Graphic Art and Work). He later referred to this body of photographs as Distortions. 
  4. Kertsz recalled, "Sometimes, just by a half-a-step left or right, all the shapes and forms have changed. I viewed the changes and stopped whenever I liked the combination of distorted body shapes," 
  5. * Although this series of photographs is often referred to as Surrealist, Kertsz did not claim allegiance to Surrealism. 
  6. Kertsz moved to the US in 1936, but his work was not well-known here until he had a solo show at MoMA in 1964
Barbara Hepworth, Large and Small Form, 1934

British Abstract Sculpture
1. Hepworth is one of the British sculptors of international stature before WWII (also Henry Moore); she was trained in Leeds and learned marble carving techniques in Italy (inspired by Egyptian, Cycladic, and Archaic Greek art); became a leader of the abstract movement in England; joined group Abstraction-Cration movement in Paris in 1933 (founded by van Doesburg and others to counteract the influence of the Surrealist group led by Breton)
2. Hepworths exposure to the work of Brancusi and Hans Arp (who had previously made his own penetrated sculptures) prompted her to make biomorphic, multipart sculptures in the early 1930s; by 1934 she adopted a more geometric syntax and eliminated, at least for a time, the remaining vestiges of naturalism from her work; she returned to more naturalistic subjects after WWII.
3. Large and Small Form is an example of this multipart, biomorphic abstraction which still vaguely recalls a reclining figure; the small shape that sits atop it might represent a child held in the figures embrace (a very similar sculpture from the same year has the title Mother and Child); the theme of motherhood prominent in the 30s might reflect changes in her own life: in 1934, the same year this work was made, she became the mother of triplets with Ben Nicholson
4. It was made using a technique called direct carving: a process in which no models or sculptural maquettes are used to plan the work, but rather the final form of the sculpture emerges through the act of carving the material. Through this technique, these artists emphasized the inherent properties of the materials, and the marble, stone and wood that they used was rubbed and polished in order to enhance its natural texture, colors and markings (compare Brancusis smooth surfaces).
5. It is similar in structure to her most innovative use of negative space in the 30s, in which the stone is pierced by a hole in the center. This crucial rupture with the notion of carved sculpture as a solid, closed form was one of Hepworths major contributions to modern sculpture.
Albert Speer, Zeppelinfeld (Parade Grounds), National Socialist Headquarters,1934

National Socialist Architecture
  1. Speers atavistic architectural design reflected the anti-modernism of the Nazi regime, a return to neoclassical monumentalism.
  2. Speer was the Nazis primary architect, and along with Hitler devised a ruin theory of architecture whereby Nazi structures would be built to last beyond the millenium of the Thousand-Year Reich to subject all posterity to a sublime awe before its glorious ruins. Using neoclassicism, an already dead aesthetic, it should to dominate time posthumously. The grounds reflected the ideas of perpetuity and monumentality - the architectural principles of the Nazis
  3. Speer and Hitler had planned for an entire demonstration campus to host the yearly Nuremburg Rallies, including a games stadium with a capacity of 400,000 but Zeppelinfield was the only part of the rally site's architecture that was ever completed. 
  4. Built from 1933 to 1937, it was designed by Speer in the style of a fortification. The massive use of banners was part of the overall design. The ancient Pergamon Altar served as the model for the main grandstand. During nighttime events, sophisticated lighting was to endow the structure with a solemn, sacralized atmosphere.
  5. After the war, Nuremberg would become the site of the Nuremberg war tribunals. The trials were most notable for the prosecution of prominent members of the leadership of Nazi Germany, who planned, carried out, or otherwise participated in the Holocaust and other war crimes. Albert Speer, too, was put on trial; he was ultimately responsible for the use of slave laborers from the occupied territories in armaments production. Expressed repentance and received 20 years.
Boris Iofan, project for the Palace of the Soviets, Moscow, 1934

1.     The Palace of the Soviets was a project to construct an administrative center and a congress hall in Moscow near the Kremlin, on the site of the demolished Cathedral of Christ the Savior. The competition was won by Boris Iofans neoclassical concept, revised into a skyscraper. 
2.     If built, it would have become the worlds tallest structure of the time. Construction start in 1937 but was terminated by the German Invasion in 1941 and its steel frame was disassembled for use in fortifications and bridges. 
3.     Topped with a 100m statue of Lenin with a torch in his hand, the project was conceived as the ultimate monument of Soviet power at the time.
4.     Iofan studied architecture in Odessa, St. Petersburg, Paris and Rome, and worked in a neoclassical style. Using his academic training and classical traditions, he created an open plan composition with a square at its center, intended for parades and public events. The different shapes  and silhouettes of the complex was intended to create an asymmetrical  faade. The design was in general, not overloaded with decorative elements and based on a combination of new forms, past experience, dynamics and expressiveness.
5.     In 1958, the foundations of the Palace were converted into the worlds largest open-air swimming pool and the cathedral rebuilt in 1995. The Cathedral was rebuilt to the exact look and specifications of the previous version (as if nothing had changed on the site).
Kthe Kollwitz, Death Seizes a Woman, from the series Death, 1934

Expressionism

  1. Kollwitz was a German artist who worked with painting, printmaking (etching, lithography and woodcuts) and sculpture. She was an eloquent advocate for victims of social injustice, war, and inhumanity.
  2. Initially trained as a painter, Kollwitz began to focus on the graphic arts after she encountered the work and writings of fellow artist Max Klinger, who defended the exacting art of drawing over the free form of painting. The ease of distribution and accessibility of prints appealed to her sense of advocacy. Moving from one technique to another, she increasingly simplified her visual language over time, but never at the expense of legibility.
  3. The loss of her son during World War I, led to a lifelong exploration of death and mourning. Death served as the subject of this, her final print cycle.  Lithography was her preferred technique for creating emotionally powerful images with universal resonance. She felt it communicated her ideas in the most straightforward manner as it allowed for freedom of expression through brushing ink directly onto stone. The eight images in the cycle show Death visiting the most vulnerable members of society, the impoverished women and children whose plight Kollwitz repeatedly chronicled in her long career of socially engaged printmaking.
  4. Set against a blank background free of any markers of time or place, here Death has crept up to a mother and her child from behind without them noticing. The womans eyes and mouth are wide open and reveal the terror that seizes her. Her right hand is put over the mouth of the screaming child as she struggles against Death. 
  5. Kollwitz established herself by developing an aesthetic vision centered on women and the working class. Her representations of women, including her frequent self-portraits, effectively communicated her subjects' predicaments during a period when women were still negotiating ways to represent themselves in the arts. While her naturalistic style appeared out of touch in an era that witnessed the birth of abstraction, her depictions of universal human experiences, given depth and emotional power through her expressive draftsmanship and economy of means, were also reflective of her time.
Henry Moore, FourPiece Composition: Reclining Figure, 1934

Biomorphic Surrealism
  1. Moore (1898-1986) was an English sculptor. He is best known for his semi-abstract monumental bronze sculptures which are located around the world as public works of art.
  2. This sculpture is an expression of the single most important theme of Henry Moore's art, the reclining figure. in which the female form is related to landscape to create images resonant with allusions to procreation, motherhood, mother-child relationships and the relationship of all human life to the earth.
  3. 'Four-Piece Composition' is an extreme manifestation of Moore's interest, at this time and later, in the idea of splitting the human figure into parts. It is a carving in marble comprising four separate elements positioned on a marble base. The individual elements of the sculpture do not accurately resemble human body parts, but when seen together, and in accordance with the work's title, the four pieces may be understood as individual limbs. Although they are positioned in a compact arrangement none of the four pieces of the sculpture touch each other.
  4. Moore commented 'I realised what an advantage a separated two-piece composition could have in relating figures to landscape. Knees and breasts are mountains. Once these two parts become separated you don't expect it to be a naturalistic figure: therefore you can justifiably make it like a landscape or a rock.'
  5. Four-Piece Composition demonstrates how Moore combined such seemingly opposed currents as Constructivism (abstract design) and Surrealism (psychological engagement with the work).
  6. According to a statement released by Unit One, the group Moore associated with, sculpture "had two definite objects: the pursuit of form (as in abstract art) and the attempt to trace the psyche (as in Surrealism)."
  7. The ideological service of his work was to humanize abstraction, and to keep it within the realm of art. He also promotes a type of Surrealism in which natural analogies were favored over psychological provocations. For Moore, it was important to retain nature as the primary reference for sculpture, and he avowed a truth to materials.
  8. In Four-Piece Composition he inscribed partial profiles on the surface, as if to pull the sculpture away from total abstraction towards a semi figurative reading. He looked to preclassical and primitive sources for "a world view" of sculpture, and in the process renewed a commitment to direct carving as an almost ethical value. By opening up the masses and creating dispersed groups he studied various kinds of space relationships in sculpture.

Archibald Motley, Jr., Black Belt, 1934
Hampton University Museum, Hampton, Virginia

Modernism / Harlem Renaissance*
  1. Motley was born in New Orleans and grew up largely in Chicago, where he attended the School of the Art Institute. After graduating, he took a postgraduate course with George Bellows. He had a well-received exhibition in New York in 1928, and in 1929-30 he was awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship to spend a year studying in Paris.
  2. In 1979, Motley recalled, The biggest thing I ever wanted to do in art was to paint like the old masters. There are no modern painters, with exception possibly of George Bellows none of them ever influenced me. Ive gone back far beyond them to men like Rubens, Michelangelo, Rembrandt, a lot of the Dutch masters, Frans Hals, men like that. I gained so much in the faces, especially in the flesh tones. Its remarkable and beautiful if you understand art and you understand the way the light travels on the pigmentation of the skin, how gradually the light changes from warm to cool in various faces. Youve got to study a painting a long time to realize what the artist is really doing. Light is very, very important. 
  3. Motleys interest the role that light plays in perceptions of color - and of the color of skin in particular - was central to his work. He was well-known both for his portraits and for genre scenes of Black life, and was himself Black. His paintings indicate an attention to the ways in which color is not neutral, either optically or socially. 
  4. In Black Belt, the brightly-colored dresses of the some figures in the foreground are balanced by the darker colors of the suits and uniforms worn by the figures alongside them. The saturation of colors is part of Motleys signature style in his more mature work. 
  5. Black Belt refers to the commercial strip of the historically-Black Bronzeville neighborhood in Chicago, also called The Stroll by Black Chicagoans at the time. Many Bronzeville residents had recently arrived in Chicago as part of the Great Migration. 
  6. Many of the figures in the painting appear to be working or engaged in social leisure, with the exception of the balding figure in a vest and tie in the foreground.This figure is of the community but outside of it as well, preoccupied and not appearing to engage with the surrounding milieu. Many critics see this figure as an alter ego of Motley himself, especially as the figure pops up in numerous canvases. 
  7. *As John Yau noted in his review of the 2015 Whitney exhibition of Motleys work for Hyperallergic, Although Motley began making his first mature paintings during the 1920s and 30s portraits and genre scenes of African American street life and nightclubs concurrently with the flourishing of the Harlem Renaissance, he never lived in New York.
Fun fact: Motley corresponded with W.E.B Dubois, and in 1925, contributed a photograph to The Crisis
Frank Lloyd Wright, Fallingwater, Bear Run, Pennsylvania, 19347

American International Style / Prairie Style
1. Although Wright was working on low-cost, prefabricated housing in his social reformist aspirations during the Great Depression of the 30s, most projects he realized during this time were custom homes for wealthy patrons.
2. Fallingwater is a vacation home for the family of a wealthy merchant and art patron Edgar Kaufmann.
3. His use of ferroconcrete, cantilevered terraces, open plan and low ceilings are reminiscent of his early Prairie Style (compare Robie House 1908)
4. Fallingwater has a superficial affinity to the International Style, however Wright was scornful of the machine-inspired architecture of the European modernists (many of whom had been influenced by him). Wright: their modern houses to look as though cut from cardboard with scissors ... in a childish attempt to make buildings resemble steamships, flying machines or locomotives.
5. Though he embraced the machine and modern materials, Wright designed a house to be a natural feature of the environment: made the house an extension of the cliff, using all implications of a site (i.e. the boulders secure the house into hillside and sometimes penetrate the walls and are incorporated into the interior design, the rough local stone contrasts with the smooth beige concrete of the parapets, stairway from living room leading directly to stream below)
6. Achieved an effective integration of the exterior natural world with the interior living world.
7. Built the Guggenheim in New York in the late 50s.

Hans Bellmer, La Poupee (The Doll), 1935
Manoukian Collection, Paris

Surrealism
  1. Bellmers dolls relate to the surrealist use of doubling to depict the uncanny as described by Freud. When live bodies are redoubled by lifeless ones like dollsthey take on the uncanniness of ghosts. That doubled produce this condition is due, Freud explains, to the return of early states of dread.
  2. Bellmer built his early artistic practice around a specifically constructed doll that he would arrange in various situations evocative of sadomasochism and then photograph them. He engaged in redoubling therefore not only in the use of the doll, but in the use of photography that also serves to make a double reality, and was therefore a perfect vehicle for the surrealists.
  3. This was Bellmers second doll sculpture which he photographed in different stages of dismemberment in over a hundred different scenarios, often shown wearing little white socks and the black patent leather shoes of young girls. In this image Bellmer positions the doll face down, with buttocks exposed, seemingly presenting us with the aftermath of torture or abuse.
  4. These works are, on the one hand, ideological and political statements (ominous harbingers of Nazi atrocities), but the photographs also strongly reflect the artists fascination with the fantastic or monstrous aspects of ordinary objects and an awareness of the darker side of human sexuality. 
  5. Bellmer grappled with the base condition of the human body and with the bodily fragment as fetish object. Mannequins and dollssimultaneously familiar and strangesupplied the material for his primal expressions of terror and awe, which often evoked the innocent violence and latent sexuality of childhood games.

Walker Evans, Miners Home, West Virginia, 1935
National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.

Documentary Photography
1.     The stalled economy, as well as the failed banks and crops, catalysed American documentary photographers, many of whom were sponsored by the Federal Farm Security Administration (FSA). Established in 1935, the FSA aimed to educate the population at large about the drastic toll the Great Depression had taken upon the countrys farmers and migrant workers. Photographers including Ben Shah, Dorothea Lange and Walker Evans were hired to travel to the hard pressed areas and document the lives of the residents. 
2.     Employed by the FSA, Evans travelled through the South, starting with West Virgina where  he photographed roadside stores, rural churches, company houses and modest buildings of Americas small towns. This is image is one of two rare interior views that he photographed during his first trip for the FSA.
3.     This photograph of a West Virginia miners reveals volumes about the life of its inhabitants. The cheerful middle-class homemakers and the smiling Santa that cover the walls are incongruent with the stark environment and morose expression of the child on the left.
4.     Though working as a Straight photographer, Evans seemingly simple and direct images are made complex through his use of metaphor, irony and compelling form. He later described his works as against salon photography, against beauty photography, against art photography. 
5.     In the summer of 1936, Evans and the writer James Agee lived in Alabama with sharecropped families. The result, a 1941 book called Let Us Now Praise Famous Men, containing Evans photographs and Agees writing, is one of the most famous books on documentary photography.

Thomas Hart Benton, A Social History of Missouri, section, 1935-37
Missouri State Capitol, Jefferson City, MO

Regionalism
  1. Benton was a leader of Regionalism. He based his art on personal observation, sketching working people from all regions of America, including poor and rural areas he visited in the 1920s and 1930s.  He then used his sketches as the basis for his paintings and murals. Benton built small clay models, or maquettes, which he then painted. His work evolved from a brief abstract phase into a monumental representation of the commonplace in America.
  2. Regionalism was an American movement that included paintings, murals, lithographs, and illustrations depicting realistic scenes of rural and small-town America, primarily in the Midwest. Nationalism was fostered through murals for government buildings that had to depict contemporary or historical American themes. Far removed from the art center, Regionalists evolved very personal styles. Their unique ways of rendering Midwestern subjects proved popular locally, and gradually they gained national recognition.
  3. In 1935, Benton was commissioned to paint murals for the Missouri House of Representatives in the State Capitol in Jefferson City. He completed his most famous murals, A Social History of Missouri, in 1937.
  4. Executed in a fully mature style, the mural's subject is the history of the state. It guides viewers chronologically, beginning with the era of fur trading and trapping, through early farming, to a turkey shoot and even to a political gathering that shows small town democracy at work. This riveting section (our slide) includes his father, U.S. Rep. Maecenas Benton (1903-05), giving a speech. Most notably, it also shows a woman changing a babys diaper (cropped in our slide), and a portrait of Jordan W. Chambers, a prominent black civic leader in both St. Louis and national politics. He is depicted directly in front of the father, alone, in a white hat, more than 30 years before the Voting Rights Act of 1965 was signed into law.
  5. Other panels show a more mechanized Missouri, with scenes of coal mining, the cattle industry, farming with tractors, and a steam boat.  Stand-alone panels feature scenes from Mark Twains The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, as well as Jesse and Frank James robbing a bank. Still other panels depict slavery and the 1838 expulsion of Mormons from the western part of the state, as well as a lynching, which capture uglier aspects of Missouris history.
  6. Bentons style of painting made common people into heroes. He gave them big bodies with lots of muscles and painted them using deep, rich colors. However, the mural first sparked controversy among the legislators with its bold and vivid scenes of everyday Missouri life. Surviving attempts to whitewash it, Benton's mural is now a source of pride.
  7. The dynamic, undulating composition writhes restlessly across the canvas, carrying the eye onto the next episode of the state's history, while space and action are oriented in several directions at once.
Not so fun fact: His heirs recently sued Kansas Citys UMB Bank for mismanaging his estate (December 2019).

Dorothea Lange, Migrant Mother, 1936,
Farm Security Administration, Library of Congress

Social realist photography and documentary, WPA photography
  1. Dorothea Lange is a social realist photographer and photojournalist known for her compelling and poignant studies of sharecroppers, migrant workers, and other marginalized people during the Great Depression.
  2. In the 1930s the federal government established agencies to deal with the conditions of the Great Depression. The Federal Art Project of the Works Progress Administration was one such program. In 1935 the FSA and Department of Agriculture, led by Roy Stryker, sought to inform Americans of the wretched conditions of migratory laborers and employed 6 photographers: Lang, Shahn, and Evans were three. They used what Stieglitz termed "Straight" photography truthful reality with no manipulation to the photographs for artistic effect.
  3. Migrant Mother shows Florence Thompson - mother of 10, who is only 32 years old. It is an image that captures the suffering of an entire generation. It has been called "The Madonna of the Depression." One of the rare visualizations that captures the suffering of an entire era and a whole sociological group, transcending the individual to reach the universal.
  4. Depicts a tired, destitute mother, surrounded by her children, two of whom turn their heads away, seeking refuge from the harsh world. There is care and concern expressed on mother's face, fatigue expressed by the hand that supports the chin.
  5. This is "straight" photography, but artistic choices made: not all children are included, as Lange was concerned that showing more than three would stir current resentment about overpopulation among the poor; tightly cropped to focus on the tired mother
  6. Lange traveled to many parts of the country, taking photos for the FSA that were intended as documentation, but are art as well. Her photographs document the plight of migrant farm laborers who fled CA looking for work, the mother captures the fears of an entire population of disenfranchised people bearing the weight of family and financial responsibilities. This image contradicts the essentially positive image of agrarian life in Regionalist works.
  7. This at Nipomo Camp where 2500 migrant workers were starving. Within days after it was printed in San Francisco newspaper, food was rushed to the hungry at Nipomo and eventually migrant relief camps were opened.
Margaret BourkeWhite, Fort Peck Dam, Montana, photograph for the first cover of Life magazine, 1936

American Photojournalism / Documentary Travel Photography
  1. This photograph was the cover-image for the first issue of LIFE Magazine. If any Charter Subscriber is surprised by what turned out to be the first story in this first issue of LIFE, the magazines editors wrote in the Nov. 23, 1936, issue, he is not nearly so surprised as [we] were. Photographer Margaret Bourke-White had been dispatched to the Northwest to photograph the multimillion dollar projects of the Columbia River Basin. What the editors expected were construction pictures as only Bourke-White can take them. What the editors got was a human document of American frontier life which, to them at least, was a revelation.
  2. Bourke-Whites iconic photograph of a highways supports atop the dams towering face is reminiscent of the battlements of a castle, with two small figures at the base for scale. The image is often described as showing a monument for the machine age, in which technology has the power to dwarf mankind. 
  3. The dam was built as part of a New Deal project designed by FDR to put Americans to work in the wake of the Great Depression. 
  4. LIFE was part of the surge of illustrated magazines published in much of the US and Europe. Illustrated magazines used photography in four ways: 1) visual reportage and photojournalism, used to simplify stories; 2) advertising photography, product propaganda used to modernize daily life and coalesce new identities (eg the New Woman); 3) travel photography, developed by women photographers in the prewar period; and 4) portrait photography. Bourke-Whites photographs for this issue of LIFE straddle the line between photojournalism and travel photography, relating the epic story of the dams building and aldo picturing the more intimate lives of the people in the nearby town of New Deal (yes, that was really the towns name). 
  5. In her 1963 autobiography, Bourke-White recalled that New Deal was a pinpoint in the long, lonely stretches of northern Montana so primitive and so wild that the whole ramshackle town seemed to carry the flavor of the boisterous Gold Rush days. She continued, reflecting on the feeling of working at LIFE at the time, The world was full of discoveries waiting to be made.
  6. Bourke-Whites work at the time often explored the impact of technology on society. In addition to work for corporate clients, Bourke-White traveled to the Soviet Union in the early 1930s to document the countrys new manufacturing towns, and co-authored You Have Seen Their Faces (1937), a documentary photography book focusing on the impoverished lives of sharecroppers in the South.
Fun fact: For You Have Seen Their Faces, rather than publishing interviews with or statements by their subjects, Bourke-White and her co-author Erskine Caldwell wrote a dialogue to accompany the images. In other news, Caldwell advocated eugenics and the sterilization of poor white people in Georgia. So, theres that.

Meret Oppenheim, Object, 1936
Museum of Modern Art, New York

French Surrealism
1. Oppenheim arrived in Paris as an art student in 1932 when she was not yet twenty; introduced to Surrealist circle by Giacometti; began to take part in the groups exhibitions in 1935 and modeled for a number of photographs by Man Ray
2. As a movement, Surrealism was not particularly hospitable to women, except as a terrain onto which male artists projected their erotic desires and psychic fears. Oppenheim is one of the few Surrealist women artists (also Tanning, Carrington), producing a wide range of paintings, drawings, sculpture and poetry.
3. Her by far most famous work is this cup, plate and spoon covered with fur of a Chinese gazelle, which has become the archetype of a Surrealist object (its subtitle is Luncheon in Fur).
4. The work supposedly germinated in a caf conversation with Picasso about Oppenheims designs for jewelry made of fur-lined metal tubing. When Picasso remarked that one could cover just about anything with fur, she quipped, even this cup and saucer. (ok I dont know if we need to give Picasso credit for this, xx Flo)
5. This emblem of domesticity metamorphosed into a hairy object that is both repellent and eroticized, the consummate fetish. Conjuring both desire and dread, Object revels in Freudian erotic ambivalence and sexual anxiety.
6. For the Surrealists, such domestic objects in unsettling juxtapositions served to crack the veneer of civilized society, revealing the sexual, psychological, and emotional drives burning just beneath the surface.
7. Object Caused a sensation when first exhibited in 1936, first in Paris, at the inaugural exhibition of Surrealist objects organized by Breton, and then in New York, at MoMAs show Fantastic Art, Dada and Surrealism (1936)

Joan Mir, Object, 1936
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

Surrealism
  1. Fetishistic nature of the doll leg typifies Surrealist eroticsm
  2. The surrealist juxtaposition of disparate objects was meant to elicit surprise and trigger further associations in the mind of the viewer. While Duchamps notion of found objects is a play here, Mirs composition is not indifferent in its juxtapositions like Duchamp. This object is carefully and whimsically constructed, with a fish swimming around the  brim of the bowler hat, the hanging ball seeming to balance the bird on its perch.
  3. To the surrealists, found objects were direct already existing embodiments of our inner desires, they just needed to be found in chance encounters. In Object Mir stages this encounter and derives new meaning from the objects gathered. While each object has a meaning, name and story if on its own, when grouped, these all lose their identity, and must adopt a new one. The idea was to disorient the viewer through the juxtaposition of disparate, even inappropriate pairings to fuel the viewer and artists imagination in creating a new narrative around such groupings.

Oscar Domnguez, Untitled, 1936
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

Surrealism (decalcomania)
1.     Spanish artist best known for his loosely rendered Surrealist paintings. He was influenced by avant-garde European painters such Rene Magritte, Giorgio de Chirico and Yves Tanguy. In 1933, he met Andr Breton and took part a year later in the Surrealist exhibition held in Copenhagen.
2.     Decalcomania is a decorative technique by which engravings and prints may be transferred to pottery or other material. Its invention has been attributed to Simon Franois Ravenet in the 1750s, an engraver from France who later moved to England and perfected the process he called decalquer (to copy by tracing).
3.     Domnguez popularised it as a Surrealist automatic technique in 1936, using gouache spread thinly on a sheet of paper or glass, which is then pressed onto another surface such as canvas. 
4.     Domnguez originally exclusively used black gouache, though included colors later in his practice. 
5.     Domnguezs technique influenced several other artists including Max Ernst and Hans Bellmer. While Domnguez referred to his work as decalcomania with no preconceived object, Ernsts saw in decalcomania a random act that  could ignite his imagine, which he would build into with elements of realism to create forms suggestive of mythical creatures of landscapes.
Leonora Carrington, SelfPortrait (The White Horse Inn), 193738

Surrealism
  1. Carrington was a British-born Mexican artist and novelist. She shared the Surrealists' interest in the unconscious mind and dream imagery. To these she added a unique blend of cultural influences, including Celtic literature, Renaissance painting, Mexican folk art, medieval alchemy, kabbalah, and Jungian psychology.
  2. Carrington spent her childhood on the family estate in Lancashire, England and often fought against the rigidity of her upbringing. There she was surrounded by animals, especially horses, and she grew up listening to her Irish nanny's fairytales and stories from Celtic folklore, sources of symbolism that inspired this work and many others.
  3. Painted when she was only 20, between 1937-1938, Carrington's Self-portrait depicts an interior with a gold-curtained window, through which we see a landscape with a white horse in the distance, recalling Alberti's 1435 "Treatise on Painting," and windows as a signal of the fictive poetics of painting.
  4. She is in the center firmly facing the viewer. Clad in white jodhpurs for riding, a hand extended towards a triple-breasted hyena that mirrors her gaze and posture.  Carrington's fingers "measure" and "touch" the squared spaces of the floor, while her wild mane of hair echoes the coloring of the hyena's coat.  She is perched on the edge of an armchair, her back to a white tailless rocking horse flying behind her. The sly detail of the skirted chairs little blue arm that echoes her hand and the tiny boots modelled on her own shoes suggests bourgeois suffocation and incipient mischief.
  5. Horses were prominent in Carringtons oeuvre, representing freedom and independence. Her interest in Celtic mythology meant she was familiar with the Celtic fertility goddess Epona, who rode a white horse. She also frequently used the hyena as a surrogate for herself, as she was drawn to this animal's rebellious spirit and its ambiguous sexual characteristics. 
  6. The painting's doublings and its contrast between restriction and liberation, may allude to the dramatic break with her family during her romance with Max Ernst (1937-40). The dreamlike scene, distorted perspective, enigmatic narrative, and autobiographical symbolism demonstrate the artist's attempt to reimagine her own reality. Given the subject of Carrington's own fable, the galloping horse seen through the window becomes a liberated surrogate self.
  7. Carrington also explored these themes in her writings. In her first published short story, "The House of Fear," (1938) Carrington portrays a horse in the role of a psychic guide to a young heroine. In two other stories the protagonists befriend, respectively, a hyena and a rocking horse, both with magical powers.
  8. The tendency for women artists to be overshadowed by their male partners was particularly fraught for Surrealists. Nonetheless, her legacy as an integral figure of the movement, long career, and her engagement with the Womens Liberation movement in Mexico has secured her a place in history.
Frank Lloyd Wright, Johnson Wax Administration Center, Racine WI, 19361939

Art Moderne (Streamline Moderne) emerging out of Prairie Style
  1. Although the Great Depression of the 1930s Dampened the economy, Wright's career continued unabated. Wright omitted historicism and revolutionized architectural design. His 2 major sources of inspiration were nature and Asian art (went to Japan in 1905). Influenced by Arts and Crafts Movement and Robert Morris (leader of movement in England), he sought to create total architectural environments.
  2. Administration Building, S.C. Johnson & Son, Inc. is a new design for the modern workplace. The focus of the building is the interior. He sealed it off from the surrounding industrial environment and created a space to work that resembled a cathedral of worship. Light fills the interior from skylights. The large secretarial section has tapering 'toadstool' columns.
  3. Wright created a total environment, designing everything from furniture to windows. Wright also designed the steel furniture: to achieve his desired unity of building and furnishings he made desks with rounded ends, echoing the rounded exterior corners of the building.
  4. Design ignores the outside world (as did the Larkin Building, which had only small exterior windows to shield against the ugly outside world, and a large interior courtyard to light the building. Also like the Larkin Building, this is a sealed environment lit from above)
  5. In a break from his earlier Prairie Style, this work features curvilinear forms (Art Moderne)
  6. One enters the building through a covered space that suddenly opens up into this expansive space. This compression/release of space a concept he reprised in many designs (including the Guggenheim Museum).
  7. Pyrex glass tubing a major construction element (modern materials)

David Siqueiros, Echo of a Scream, 1937
Museum of Modern Art, New York

Mexican Muralism
  1. David Alfaro Siqueiros believed in the politically transformative power of a social art movement, along with Diego Rivera and Jos Clemente Orozco. This group of muralists drew on Mexicos precolonial past, and in 1924, signed a declaration repudiating easel painting as an aristocratic, colonial form. They favored monumental art in all its forms, because it is public property...art must no longer be the expression of individual satisfaction, which it is today, but should aim to become a fighting, educative art for all. To this end, the muralists often depicted the lives and history of the proletariat in their work. Siqueiros, Rivera and Orozco became known in the US in the 1920s. 
  2. Siqueiros came to the US in 1932, in order to experience a technological civilization, and taught at an art school in LA. In 1936, he established the Siqueiros Experimental Workshop  in New York dedicated to modernising the methods and materials of artmaking, and to promoting the aims of the Communist Party of the United States. Siqueiros hoped to develop new ways of executing propagandistic murals, including spraying paint through stencils, and pouring, dripping, and splattering paint. Influenced by Surrealism, free association, automatism, and psychoanalysis, the course included an exercise in which a canvas was placed on the ground and paint was thrown on it directly from the cans of paint, which had had a hole poked into them. This was, for Siqueiros, a first step of artistic creation, in which the artist had to engage with the work using his entire body. He called this the "controlled accident" in painting. The workshop attracted young artists from Latin America and the US, including Jackson Pollock, whose drip paintings show the influence of Siqueiros methods. 
  3. The workshop closed in April 1937, when Siqueiros joined the Republican Army to fight in the Spanish Civil War against Francisco Francos fascist coup. 
  4. Siqueiros based Echo of a Scream on a news photo of a child in the aftermath of a bombing in the Sino-Japanese war. The childs scream - depicted as an enlarged, hovering version of its head - hovers over the wreckage. 
  5. Echo is rendered in enamel on wood, substantial but not necessarily monumental at 48 x 36
  6. After returning to Mexico City in late 1938, in 1940 Siquieros was forced into exile after being directly involved in an attempt to assassinate Leon Trotsky (who was then in exile in Mexico City.
Pablo Picasso, Guernica, 1937

Late Cubism
1. The mural-size painting Guernica (11 x 20 feet) was inspired by the atrocities of the Spanish Civil War, specifically, the destruction of the Basque town of Guernica by Hitlers bombers in the service of the Spanish fascists: the attack was a training mission designed to test a new bombing tactic to intimidate and terrorize the resistance (with fighter planes then killing defenseless civilians trying to flee). 1600 civilians (a third of the population) were wounded or killed.
2. Made for the Spanish Republican Pavilion of Paris Worlds Fair 1937 (theme: celebration of modern technology, ironically), commissioned by the newly elected Spanish Republican government
3. An antiwar icon: Although the size and multiple figures reference the long tradition of European history paintings, this painting challenges rather than accepts the notion of war as heroic.
4. Motifs: speared horse as a symbol of Spain; grief-stricken women shrieking over the body of her dead child, leaning out of burning house; fallen warrior (only male figure); all are screaming in horror, with tongues like daggers. Some scholars interpret the horse and bull as representing the deadly battle between the Republican fighters (horse) and Francos fascist army (bull).
5. Although Picasso used motifs such as the screaming horse or agonized figures derived from his Surrealist distortions of the 1920s, the structure is based on the Cubist grid and returns to the more stringent palette of Analytic Cubism. Guernica is Picassos most powerfully expressionist application of Cubism.
6. The palette of black, white and gray gives the image a documentary quality (lending it the immediacy of photography), further emphasized by the textured pattern in the center of the painting that creates the illusion of newsprint (may reflecting Picassos initial encounter with the event in a newspaper report).

Joan Mir, Still Life with Old Shoe, 1937
The Museum of Modern Art, New York

Surrealism
  1.  Mir created Still Life with Old Shoe in Paris over a four-month period of intense concentration, working from life for the first time in many years. It was painted the year after he left Spain at the onset of the Spanish Civil War in 1936, the anxiety of the moment communicated through the acidic colors, and the black clouds that appear foreboding.  This work is often compared to Picasso's Guernica, both because of its despair and of the nowadays consequences of any war. The shapes in the horizon look like dark clouds, forecasting the tragedy to come.
  2. It is both a still life and a landscape: the irregular back edge of the tabletop can be read as a horizon line. The objects are not to scale, and they are isolated in discrete cells, creating a formal rupture that calls to mind Mirs work in collage.
  3. The trauma of war created the sense that surrealism was no longer a viable escape, leading Miro to revisit direct observation briefly before committing himself to abstraction in 1940. In this image however, he maintaining the aspect of abstraction that allowed for various interpretations on the part of the viewer.  
  4. Here his subjects are an old shoe, a piece of bread and a fork stabbed into an apple. These are identifiable but still defy interpretation as a whole. Some argue that the objects are intentionally poor and humble, representing the ordinary person who suffers as a result of the civil war, standing as a tragic symbol.
  5. The black opaque shapes read as both flat and as voids, or rips in the field

Degenerate Art Exhibition, Munich, 1937 
(Room 3 showing Dada Wall)

1.     As the Nazis gained power in Germany during the late 1920s, the party sought to bring all areas of society into line with its policies. Any art that did not accord with Nazi ideology was seized from public museums. By the time they assumed control of the government in 1933, a campaign to rid the country of artworks deemed degenerate was already underway, and more than 20,000 artworks were removed from state exhibitions.
2.     In its early stages the Nazi campaign against degenerate art was directed largely at Expressionism, which was considered too sympathetic toward negro culture. By the mid-1930s, anything considered avant-garde, cosmopolitan and Bolshevik or as representing Jewish influence was denounced as impure  and dangerous. 
3.     Of the works that were seized, 740 were exhibited in 1937 at the Degenerate Art exhibition, which opened in Munich before touring the country. The aim of the exhibition was to educate the public on the art of decay, and to demonstrate that modernist tendencies such as abstraction are the result of genetic inferiority  and societys more decline. The aim was to defame not only suspect artists but also curators who had acquired their work.
4.     The deliberately chaotic installation (works displayed without frames and partially covered by derogatory slogans) included labels indicating the costs of the works, condemning the use of public fund for the purchase of putrefaction. The exhibition included works Gauguin, Van Gogh, Kirchner, Kandinsky, and Klee among others.
5.     The program was overseen by Hitlers minister of propaganda, Josef Goebbels. He initially announced that all of the seized art would be burned, but in the end a public bonfire consumed less than 5000 works while the rest were auctioned in Switzerland.
Constantin Brancusi, Endless Column, 193738

1. Brncui was a Romanian sculptor, painter and photographer who worked in France. He is considered the father of modern sculpture, known for radically simplified figurative forms that sought to capture "the essence" in bronze, marble, stone, and wood.
  2. Hailed as one of the great works of 20C sculpture, Endless Column was commissioned in 1935 by the Women's League of Gorj to honor the fallen soldiers who defended Trgu-Jiu against a German force during WWI. It is a column of 16 zinc, brass-clad, cast-iron modules threaded onto a steel spine, it soars more than ninety-eight feet (30 meters) into the air. Installed near his native village in Romania in 1938, it is the centerpiece of the tripartite sculptural memorial also including The Gate of the Kiss and Table of Silence. This was Brncui's only foray into public sculpture.
  3. Despite the ensemble's artistic importance, it was considered degenerate art during the Communist era. A failed attempt to pull the column down left it tilted and cracked, exposing its interior to the elements. The ensemble was poorly maintained for years. After being placed on the World Monuments Funds watch list in 1996, it was fully restored in 2000. 
  4. Its evolution took many forms.  Brancusi focused on the column as a pedestal before he realized its potential for vertical expansion. He made several versions, carving a prototype out of oak in 1918 (now at MoMA). In 1920 he carved a nine-module wood version that rose over twenty-three feet, which was set up in the garden of his friend, photographer Edward Steichen.
  5. The design consists of a single symmetrical element, a rhomboid module, repeated to produce a continuous rhythmic line. The elevation consists of fifteen rhomboid beads, flanked at either end by half modules performing a staggering optical illusion, giving the appearance of being embedded in the soil and appearing to intertwine with the sky, ascending into infinity.
  6. It recalls ancient obelisks but also draws upon forms in Romanian folk art.
  7. Endless Column references the axis mundi, or axis of the world, a crucial belief of many traditional cultures embodying the connection between heaven and earth. This focus reflects Brancusi's affinity for the sacred, cosmic, and mythical.  
  8. Its simplicity, directness, and modularity helped to define the foundational principles of modern abstract sculpture, and its reliance upon repeated modules was very important for Minimalist artists in the 1960s.

Burgoyne Diller, Second Theme, 193740
The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

De Stijl - but American
  1. Although realism dominated the American scene between the wars, Diller maintained an abstract style. In 1936 the American Abstract Artists Group was organized and held annual exhibitions dedicated to promoting abstraction, with emphasis on experiments related to Constructivist and Neo-plasticist abstraction
  2. Diller exhibited with the AAA and was the 1st American to develop an abstract style based on de Stijl.
  3. Mondrian's Neo-Plastic principles are the source of Diller's art. However, his personal style integrates color and line so that overlapping lines become overlapping color planes in images like Second Themes. Thus he created a complex sense of space different from Mondrian.
  4. Influenced by the works of Piet Mondrian from the 1910s and 1920s and Russian Constructivism, Diller devised his own abstract formats in the 1930s. Divided into groups called "first," "second," and "third" themes, Diller's three series explore the movement generated by different arrangements of geometric forms within a square canvas. "Second" theme pictures, such as this, feature a grid system within which rectangular bands of differing widths extend across the canvas.
  5. Basic formal elements: a palette limited to the primary colors, black, and white; gridlike compositions of rectilinear elements; and an interest in relationships of hue, position, and size among those elements.
  6. Proponents of De Stijl advocated pure abstraction and universality by a reduction to the essentials of form and colour; they simplified visual compositions to vertical and horizontal, using only black, white and primary colors.

Walter Gropius and Marcel Breuer,
Walter Gropius House, Lincoln, MA, 1938

New England Bauhaus / International Style
  1. Walter Gropius was the founding director of the Bauhaus from 1919 to 1928. According to Gropius manifesto for the school, "the Bauhaus strives to reunite arts and crafts sculpture, painting, applied art, and handicrafts as the permanent elements of a new architecture". (Faculty included Paul Klee, Johannes Itten, Josef Albers, Herbert Bayer, Lszl Moholy-Nagy, Otto Bartning and Wassily Kandinsky.) Gropius fled Germany in 1934 for England before ultimately settling in the US. 
  2. Gropius and Marcel Breuer - his protg from the Bauhaus - moved to Cambridge, MA in 1937 to teach the at the Harvard Graduate School of Design. The Gropius House was completed in 1938 - the year that Gropius became head of Harvards architecture department. Gropius and his family lived in the house during most of Gropius tenure at Harvard until he died in 1969. 
  3. The house was the first sign of what was considered the International Style appearing in Americas residential milieu. 
  4. Gropius recalled that when I built my first house in the U.S.A. - which was my own - I made it a point to absorb into my own conception those features of the New England architectural tradition that I found still alive and adequate. This fusion of the regional spirit with a contemporary approach to design produced a house that I would never have built in Europe with its entirely different climatic, technical and psychological background. He combined materials consistent with other architecture in the region, including a common brick facade and local clapboard, with manufactured glass windows and stark white paint. 
  5. Breuer designed a large portion of the furniture for the house, much of which featured his signature bent chrome tubes.
Alexander Calder, Lobster Trap and Fish Tail, 1939

American abstract sculpture / proto-kinetic sculpture

1. Calders characteristic works of the 1930s and 40s are wind-generated abstract constructions, either standing or hanging, made of plates of metal or other materials suspended on strings or wires (christened mobiles by Marcel Duchamp).
2. In 1931, at Arps suggestion, Calder joined Abstraction- Cration and began to introduce motion into his constructions. At first he induced movement by hand cranks or small motors, but eventually the sculptures were driven merely by currents of air.
3. Lobster Trap and Fish Tail is one of the largest hanging mobiles and an example of his extremely sophisticated constructions of the late 30s.
4. Whereas his motorized mobiles still reflect the influence of Mondrian, geometric abstraction, and Constructivism, Lobster Trap uses free, biomorphic forms reflecting the work of his friends Mir and Arp. Calders production moved easily between geometric or Neo-plastic forms and those associated with organic Surrealism.
5. Lobster Trap was commissioned by MoMA and is 9 feet (2.9 m) in diameter. The torpedo-shaped element at top could be a lobster cautiously approaching the trap, represented by a delicate wire cage balancing at one end of a bent rod. Dangling from the other end is a cluster of fan-shaped metal plates suggestive of a school of fish.
6. After WWII, Calder would pursue an international career and expand his early abstract constructions to an architectural scale.
7. Calder liberated sculpture from being a static art form: There were precedents for this kineticism in sculpture, as we have seen, in the work of Gabo, Rodchenko, and Moholy-Nagy, but no artist developed the concept as fully or ingeniously as Calder. Important precursor to kinetic art of the late 50s and 60s.

Jacob Lawrence, Harriet Tubman worked as a water girl to cotton pickers; she also worked at plowing, carting, and hauling logs, 193940
Harriet Tubman Series No. 7
Hampton University Museum, Hampton, Virginia

Harlem Renaissance
  1. Lawrence moved to Harlem in the 1930s and studied at the Harlem Art Center, absorbing Aaron Douglass work from which he developed his distinctive colorful stylized figurative style and central concert with representing the history and social struggle of Black Americans.
  2. Much of his work of the late 30s was in series format, chronicling the lives of black heroes such as this one of Harriet Tubman. The series was composed of 31 paintings organized into 6 sections Tubmans birth, her life as a slave, her escape, her leadership of the Underground Railroad, her experience among the abolitionists, and her Civil War. This one early in the series describes the arduous labor that Tubman underwent while enslaved.
  3. In his figuration, Lawrences narrative and formalism work in conjunction, e.g. here, Tubmans muscular arms that perform the described labor are enlarged and her squared shoulders run parallel to the log that she saws visualizing the way this strenuous labor has shaped her body. Were Tubman to stand, she would burst from the frame of the image, as she would do from the confines of slavery soon after this panel in the narrative.
  4. Lawrence wrote all the accompanying captions to the images including quotes pulled from Sarah Bradfords book, Harriet the Moses of Her People which was a sentimental account of Tubmans experience from an author seeking to raise funds to support Tubman and her work.
  5. Lawrence was later asked to make his series of paintings of Tubman and accompanying captions into a childrens book in 1968 titled Harriet Tubman and the Promised Land.

Frida Kahlo, SelfPortrait with Thorn Necklace, 1940
University of Texas, Austin

Mexican Modernism

1.     Kahlo was known for her self-portraits, rich with autobiographical details and cultural symbols. She began painting while bedridden after a bus accident, following which she struggled with medical issues and infertility. This portrait was created directly following her divorce to Diego Rivera, and is one of many in which she documents the physical and emotional pain caused by her unstable marriage. 
2.     There are religious overtones in this image, incorporating both Christian and Aztec symbology. She paints herself as a Christian martyr, wearing the crown of thorns worn by Christ, enduring the pain of her failed marriage. The butterflies in her hair are further interpreted as symbols of resurrection. 
3.     The hummingbird holds resonance to her Mexican heritage, in which hummingbirds are used as love charms, but the hummingbird depicted here is black and lifeless (depicting end of her marriage). It could also symbolize Huitzilopochtli, the Aztec god of war.
4.     On her shoulder sits a black cat, a symbol of bad luck and death gazing directly at the viewer. On her left is a monkey, one of her pets gifted to her by Rivera. The monkey, a symbol of the devil, tugs at the thorn necklace, inflicting pain upon her. 
5.     The scene is set in a lush but suffocatingly dense jungle. Kahlo often used vibrant flora and fauna as background for her self-portraits to create a claustrophobic space teeming with fertility.
Helen Levitt, New York, c. 1940

Street Photography

  1. Levitt was an American photographer and filmmaker, particularly noted for her street photography around New York City.
  2. While teaching art classes to children in the mid-1930s, Levitt became intrigued with the transitory chalk drawings that were part of the New York children's street culture. She purchased a hand-held Leica camera (with a right-angle viewfinder) and began to photograph these chalk drawings, as well as the children who made them. During the 1930s to 1940s, the lack of air conditioning meant people were outside more, which invested her in street photography.
  3. Levitt was mentored by Walker Evans, and they worked together in 1938-39, taking pictures in the subway. She was also influenced by Cartier-Bresson, whose work she saw at the Julien Levy Gallery and whom she accompanied on a day of shooting in New York. This image of children playing with a broken mirror is reminiscent of Cartier-Bresson's "decisive moment."
  4. This image and others from East Harlem were published in A Way of Seeing (1965), which included an essay by James Agee: "[Viewers] who particularly like children will find here as much to meditate, and understand, or be mystified by, as anyone, so far as I know, has ever managed to make permanent about children."
  5. Levitt's playful and poetic photographs, made over the course of sixty years on the streets of her native New York City, have reflected her humor and inventiveness as much as they have honestly portrayed her subjectsmen, women, and children acting out a daily drama on the sidewalks and stoops of New York.
  6. Levitt had several solo exhibitions in the 1940s, and a second wave of recognition in the 1960s. Though best known for her black-and-white images, she received two Guggenheim Fellowships to document New York with color photographs.

Jacob Lawrence, The Migration Series, Panel No. 1: During World War I there was a great migration north by Southern African Americans, 194041
The Phillips Collection, Washington, D. C.

Harlem Renaissance And Dynamic Cubism
  1. Lawrence (1917-2000) was an African-American painter known for his portrayal of African-American life. As well as a painter, storyteller, and interpreter, he was an educator. Lawrence referred to his style as "dynamic cubism", though by his own account the primary influence was not so much French art as the shapes and colors of Harlem. He brought the African-American experience to life using blacks and browns juxtaposed with vivid colors.
  2. Lawrence was 23 when he finished it. It was exhibited in New York at the Museum of Modern Art, and brought him national recognition when he was 25
  3. The series depicted the Great Migration of African-Americans from the rural South to the urban North. Between two world wars, African Americans migrated to urban, industrialized north, fleeing racial and economic oppression. Lawrence's parents part of this exodus as was he. "I was part of the migration, as was my family, my mother, my sister, and my brother...I grew up hearing tales about people 'coming up,' another family arriving." This gave rise to the New Negro Movement which encouraged African Americans to become politically progressive and radically conscious. It stimulated a flowering of black art and culture known as the Harlem Renaissance, since its capital was Harlem, NYC.
  4. No. 1, from The Migration of the Negro series is the 1st panel in a series of 60 (each with text) which were published in November 1941 Fortune magazine, later shown in Edith Halpert's Downtown Gallery.
  5. His works addressed social issues of the day and he depicted black history through narrative painting series. At 23 years old, Lawrence became the first African-American artist to gain acclaim from whites in the segregated New York art world.
  6. 1st panel set in the south, a train station filled with black migrants streaming through portals labeled with northern and Midwest cities. It has a boldly abstract style and shows influence of Cubism and African American folk art.
  7. The "hard, bright, brittle" aspects of Harlem during the Great Depression inspired Lawrence as much as the colors, shapes and patterns inside the residents' homes. "Even in my mother's home," Lawrence told historian Paul Karlstrom, "people of my mother's generation would decorate their homes in all sorts of color
*Worth noting that Lawrence changed the title in 1993 from "The Migration of the Negro" to "The Migration Series"

Edward Hopper, Nighthawks, 1942
Art Institute of Chicago

American Social Realism
  1. Hopper was mainly active in New York, and rejected any association with the Ashcan School or American Regionalism, the latter of which, he said, caricatured America in their paintings. 
  2. A particular sensitivity to light defined Hoppers work. 
  3. Hopper was interested in stage set design, and a number of his paintings of simplified faades have a perhaps related feeling, as though recently emptied of or awaiting action. 
  4. Hopper said that Nighthawks was inspired by a restaurant on New Yorks Greenwich Avenue where two streets meet. Fluorescent lights began to be used widely in the early 1940s, and the all-night diner emits an eerie glow. 
  5. Hopper eliminated any reference to an entrance, and the viewer, drawn to the light, is shut out from the scene by a seamless wedge of glass. The four figures seem separate and remote both from the viewer and from one another. Hopper denied that he purposefully infused this or any other of his paintings with symbols of human isolation and urban emptiness, but he acknowledged that in Nighthawks unconsciously, probably, I was painting the loneliness of a large city.
  6. The feeling of isolation pervading Hoppers work, combined with his sense of architectures geometry, has been compared to Surrealists like de Chirico. 
Fun fact: Hoppers wife Jo was the model for the red-haired woman in the red dress.
Roberto Matta, Disasters of Mysticism, 1942

American Surrealism / Proto-Abstract Expressionism
1. Surrealism was exported to New York in the 1930s (promoted, amongst others, by Peggy Guggenheim), although it was initially received with suspicion as a product of leftist European artists (this was during the time of the Great Depression and political isolationism). By 1942, however, the center of Surrealist activity had shifted to New York as artists fled the war in Europe.
2. Chilean-born Matta studied architecture in Le Corbusiers Paris office and joined the Parisian Surrealists in 1937, but was younger than most of his European colleagues; emigrated to the US in 1939 (on same boat as Tanguy!); one-man show at Julien Levy Gallery helped establish his reputation and had a strong impact on American experimental artists.
3. Together with Motherwell, Mattas long career helped forge a link between European Surrealism and American Abstract Expressionism. Matta's style and willing exploration of the Surrealist philosophy of "automatic composition" heavily influenced the development of the Abstract Expressionist schools exploration of action painting.
4. Disasters of Mysticism exemplifies Mattas work from the 40s. Although it has roots in Masson and Tanguy, its nocturnal mysticism and vision of an ever-changing universe of outer space is a powerful excursion into uncharted territory. It is an apocalyptic scene, conveying confusion and angst, reflecting the psychic damage caused by Europes ongoing wars.
Frederick Kiesler, Installation view of the Surrealist Gallery in Art of This Century, New York, 1942

Surrealist architecture
  1. While living in Europe, collector and patron Peggy Guggenheim had amassed an impressive collection of surrealist art which she brought back to the US upon the outbreak of WW2. Back in New York, she established a gallery called Art of This Century where she exhibited and sold work by the surrealists alongside work by Americans, exposing American audiences to European avant-garde movements, and providing a venue for American artist to thrive alongside the more established European modernists. For her 1942 exhibition she commissioned Kiesler to build a specially designed curved space in which to exhibit the work.
  2. Kiesler was a young associate of the De Stijl group who had become known for his avant-garde theater designs
  3. For Art of This Century he divided the exhibition into four spaces, one for temporary shows and three for fixed exhibitions of the collection. Each fixed space, exhibiting Abtract, Kinetic and Surrealist art respectively had distinct qualities that echoed the art each room contained (e.g. The Kinetic gallery displayed Paul Klees work on a conveyor belt)
  4. The surrealist gallery was composed of bowed walls made of gum-wood, from which Kielser projected Surrealist paintings supported by batlike struts at different angles; meanwhile his biomorphic chairs doubled as sculpture stands. Like the Surrealists, he sought to dissolve the boundaries between art, space and life, explaining the decision to exhibit the works without frames, and hung from the ceiling instead of affixed to the walls
  5. He also wanted to control the lighting and illuminate one side at a time for two minute each to have the gallery pulse like your blood, aligning Kiesler with the surrealist vision of an intrauterine architecture proposed by Dali, Tzara and Matta in the 30s. He wrote We must have walls like wet sheets that get out of shape and fit our psychological fears.
Piet Mondrian, Broadway BoogieWoogie, 194243

Neoplasticism
1.     Mondrian arrived in New York in 1940 from Paris, one of the many European artists who moved to the United States to escape WWII. He immediately fell in love with Manhattan, where he spent the rest of his life, and with boogie-woogie music, to which he was introduced on his first evening in New York. 
2.     A major stimulus for Mondrian was the lights at night, when the skyscrapers were transformed into  a brilliant pattern of light and shadow, blinking and changing. He loved the tempo and dynamism of the city, the excitement and change, and felt compelled to translate the rhythms in his paintings. 
3.     He was drawn to the Neoplastic effect created by skyscrapers rising from narrow canyons of streets and the rigid grid of its plan. Applying this doctrine of Neoplasticism to his paintings, he restricted his compositions to the most basic kinds of lines, straight horizontals and verticals, and similarly limited the color range to the primary triad with black, white and grey in between. 
4.     The impact of the city and music is most evident in Broadway Boogie-Woogie, where he departs radically from the formula he had used for more than 20 years. He omits the black, linear structure balanced against color areas. The process is instead reversed the grid itself is in color,and the ground is a single plane of off-white. Bouncing against  each other, the tiny blinking blocks of color create a vital and pulsing rhythm, an optical vibration that jumps between intersections evoking traffic on the streets of New York.
5.     In New York, Mondrian devised a method of composing with commercially available colored tapes that he could easily shift around until he was satisfied with the composition to commit to paint the  canvas. His working process was thus  governed by an experimental and intuitive approach. 
6.     His appreciation of boogie-woogie may have sprung partly from the fact that he saw its goals as analogous to his own: destruction of melody which is the destruction of natural appearance; and construction through the continuous opposition of pure means dynamic rhythm.

Naum Gabo, Linear Construction in Space, No. 1 (Variation), 1943
The Phillips Collection, Washington, D.C.

Bauhaus / International Constructivism

  1. Naum Gabo was an influential sculptor, theorist, and key figure in Russia's post-Revolution avant-garde and the development of twentieth-century sculpture.
  2. He had originally trained to be an engineer. In 1920, he and his brother Antoine Pevsner published the Realisticheskii manifest (Realistic Manifesto) in Moscow, which articulated their theories on Constructivism and solidified Gabos role as a pioneer of modern sculpture.
  3. During his time in Germany, he contributed significantly, though indirectly, to Moholy-Nagy's ideas on light, space, and movement at the Bauhaus. While not a member of Bauhaus faculty, he lectured there in 1928 and published in their magazine.
  4. His principal innovation of the 1940s was a construction in which webs of taut nylon filament were attached to interlocking sheets of Lucite, a clear plastic, that attained a transparency and weightlessness unprecedented in sculpture. Like a drawing in space, the nylon filaments reflect light and gracefully articulate the void as positive form, transforming the space into a "malleable material element." The result is a virtually symmetrical sculpture composed of transparent and intersecting vertical planes, exposing the works axial center.
  5. He made several versions of these in different scales, justifying that each piece was an original because it could not be repeated mechanically or cast. The number distinguishes it from others made subsequently, while 'Variation' indicates that it differs from the original in having a stepped-back (or winged) treatment on two sides instead of having all four sides the same.
  6. In this piece the stepped-back treatment is very pronounced (Phillips Collection, Washington, DC.)
  7. Gabos duplication of forms and insistence on everyday materials (not marble, clay, or bronze) is akin to the methodical processes of industrial production.
  8. Utopian ideals underscore his Constructivist works. Rejecting the past and freeing art from the imitation of nature, he believed that his sculptures helped build a more perfected social and spiritual life. His sculptures were not just transparent in surface quality; in dematerializing mass and surface, he meant to suggest the universal and infinite and provide a conduit to a new social order.
  9. Critic Herbert Read said his work hovered between the visible and the invisible, the material and the immaterial, becoming the crystallization of the purest sensibility.
Wilfredo Lam, The Jungle, 1943

Afro-Cuban Mysticism and Surrealism and Cubist Influence
  1. Wilfredo Lam (1902-1982) was born in Cuba to a Chinese father and a European-African mother, he studied art first in Havana and, in 1923, in Madrid. In Spain he fought on the side of the Republicans during the Civil War, a fact that endeared him to Picasso when he moved to Paris. Lam spent eighteen years in Europe (1923-41), which deeply affected his artistic vision. While there, he befriended Picasso and also established himself as an integral member of the Surrealist movement. He explored imagery that was heavily influenced by Picasso, Cubism, and African art. Lam left Paris because of World War II, eventually traveling with Breton to Martinique, where they were joined by Masson.
  2. The artistic and cultural traditions of Lam's homeland and Europe converged when he returned to Cuba and renewed his familiarity with its light, vegetation, and culture. In The Jungle the presence of the woman-horse, who in Afro-Cuban mysticism refers to a spirit in communication with the natural world, mirrors Lam's own confrontational dialogue with the so-called primitive interests expressed in advanced European painting. His work is an example of this confluence of two cultures.
